headline: Review: ‘Karl Marx City’ Revisits the Everyday Terror of Dictatorship

headline: Review: ‘After Auschwitz’ Looks at Six Survivors and Their Lives

headline: Review: ‘Phillauri,’ an Indian Rom-Com With an Epic Sweep

headline: Review: ‘I Called Him Morgan,’ a Jazz Tale of Talent and Tragedy

headline: Review: ‘Dig Two Graves,’ but the Goodbye Is Only Temporary

headline: Review: ‘Saban’s Power Rangers,’ With a Color-Coded Makeover

headline: Review: ‘Prevenge,’ Orchestrated by a Fiendish Fetus

headline: Review: ‘A Woman, a Part’ and a Quest to Reconnect

headline: Review: ‘Song to Song,’ Terrence Malick’s Latest Beautiful Puzzle

headline: Review: Intimate Struggles Come to Life in ‘After the Storm’

headline: Review: ‘Beauty and the Beast’ Revels in Joy and Enchantment

headline: Review: Fiction and Nonfiction Blur in ‘Actor Martinez’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Actor Martinez

headline: Review: Give a Student Some Offal, and You’ll Regret It in ‘Raw’

headline: Review: Love as the World Wars, in ‘The Ottoman Lieutenant’

headline: Review: In ‘Apprentice,’ Teaching the Fine Art of Execution

headline: Review: Israel Is the Focus of ‘The Settlers’ and ‘Ben-Gurion: Epilogue’

headline: Review: A Father Dies, and Duty Weighs on a Son in ‘Nakom’

headline: Review: At ‘Table 19,’ Random Wedding Guests Straining to Laugh

headline: Review: A Crisis of Faith and a Trip to God’s B&B in ‘The Shack’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Shack

headline: Review: ‘Before I Fall,’ a Melodramatic ‘Groundhog Day’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before I Fall

headline: Review: In ‘Wolves,’ a High School Athlete Can’t Outrun Clichés

headline: Review: In ‘Canners,’ One Man’s Trash Is Another’s Nickel Treasure

headline: Review: ‘Kiki’: The Vogueing Scene, Still a Refuge for Gay and Transgender Youth

headline: Review: ‘Dying Laughing,’ About Bombing Onstage, or, Conversely, Killing

headline: Review: In ‘As You Are,’ a Nod to Nirvana, and a Loaded Gun

headline: Review: ‘Bitter Harvest’ Offers a Clunky Lesson in Ukrainian History

headline: Review: In ‘Paraguay Remembered,’ Does Time Heal All Wounds?

headline: Review: ‘My Life as a Zucchini,’ an Oscar Nominee With Depth and Soul

headline: Review: Two Friends Dance a Wary Tango in ‘Lovesong’

headline: Review: Ice Cube and Charlie Day Face Off in ‘Fist Fight’

headline: Review: ‘American Fable,’ Pastoral With a Wolf Howling

headline: Review: In ‘How Heavy This Hammer,’ Life Takes a Toll on Dad

headline: Review: Saving Dad, and Finding Herself, in ‘My Name Is Emily’

headline: Review: Matt Damon Battles Clusters of Monsters in ‘The Great Wall’

headline: Review: ‘Don’t Hang Up’ Has a Menace on the Line

headline: Review: ‘Left on Purpose’ Follows a Man Who Plans to Kill Himself

headline: Review: In ‘Rings,’ Best Not Go to the Videotape

headline: Review: ‘I Am Not Your Negro’ Will Make You Rethink Race

headline: Review: ‘This Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous,’ a Self-Made Cover Girl

headline: Review: In ‘A Good American,’ Examining Sept. 11 and Data Collection

headline: Review: Robert De Niro as ‘The Comedian,’ a Has-Been Seeking a Comeback

headline: Review: ‘Mr. Gaga’ Doesn’t Sing but Has His Own (Dance) Language

headline: Review: In ‘The Salesman,’ Scenes From a Marriage in Tehran

headline: Review: A Long-Buried Family Secret Explodes in ‘The Daughter’

headline: Review: Alice Returns in ‘Resident Evil: The Final Chapter’

summary_short: In the sixth entry in Paul W. S. Anderson’s dystopian franchise, Milla Jovovich’s character is back in zombie land, aided by her former nemesis the Red Queen.

headline: Review: ‘Kung Fu Yoga’ Features Jackie Chan Saving the Day

summary_short: Mr. Chan mugs and thwarts assailants in this harmless international romp.

headline: Review: ‘Lost in Florence’ Blends Romantic Fantasy and a Rough Sport
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost in Florence

headline: Review: ‘Midsummer in Newtown’ Revisits the Pain of Sandy Hook

headline: Review: Matthew McConaughey Mines Profane Capitalism in ‘Gold’

headline: Review: ‘A Dog’s Purpose,’ With Many Lives and Many Clichés
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Dog’s Purpose

headline: Review: In ‘The Last Family,’ a Polish Artist’s Tragic Home Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Family

headline: Review: Shah Rukh Khan as ‘Raees,’ a Villain but Still a Do-Gooder

headline: Review: ‘The Red Turtle,’ Life Marooned With an Ornery Reptile

headline: Review: The French Countryside Holds Surprises in ‘Staying Vertical’

headline: Review: ‘XXX: Return of Xander Cage’ Deploys Vin Diesel on a New Mission
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of XXX: Return of Xander Cage

headline: Review: Cannibalism, Torture and Apocalypse in ‘We Are the Flesh’

headline: Review: ‘The Founder,’ the Story of a Supersize Businessman

headline: Review: 1 Teenage Boy and 3 Mothers in ‘20th Century Women’

headline: Review: ‘Saving Banksy’ Affirms Graffiti’s Populist Values

headline: Review: Turning the World On, the LSD Way, in ‘The Sunshine Makers’

headline: Review: In ‘Mr. Donkey,’ a Village School’s Ruse Farcically Backfires

headline: Review: ‘The Unspoken’: If You Move Here, Find a Realtor Fast
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unspoken
summary_short: This thriller features a creaky building where something eerie once happened, and where Jodelle Ferland plays the nanny to a boy who has just moved in.

headline: Review: ‘American Pastoral,’ Philip Roth’s Fiery 1960s at Low Heat
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Pastoral
summary_short: Ewan McGregor’s directorial debut is a shallow but watchable gloss on this Roth novel, conjuring a searing image of the disintegrating American dream.

headline: Review: In ‘Supersonic,’ the Band Oasis and Its Combative Brothers
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Supersonic
summary_short: This documentary looks at the rock group’s founding members, Liam and Noel Gallagher, through older footage and animated re-creations.

headline: Review: ‘The Pickle Recipe’ Is a Sweet and Sour Caper
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pickle Recipe
summary_short: In this comedy, a grandson in need of money plots with an uncle to steal the recipe for his grandmother’s famous pickles.

headline: Review: ‘Boo! A Madea Halloween’ Finds Tyler Perry in the Usual Costume(s)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boo! A Madea Halloween
summary_short: Mr. Perry’s most popular character is back again to crack wise and deliver advice in this comedy. He plays some other people, too.

headline: Review: In ‘Ouija: Origin of Evil,’ a Youngster Who Nails ‘Creepy’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ouija: Origin of Evil
summary_short: In this prequel to “Ouija,” Lulu Wilson delivers chills as a girl with a psychic link to a malevolent board game.

headline: ‘Moonlight’: Is This the Year’s Best Movie?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moonlight
summary_short: Our critic A.O. Scott says this film about a young black man’s coming of age is both a disarmingly personal film and an urgent social document.

headline: Review: Tom Cruise Has a Familiar Furrow in ‘Jack Reacher: Never Go Back’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack Reacher: Never Go Back
summary_short: Mr. Cruise returns as this title character to fight menace in Edward Zwick’s film.

headline: Review: Don’t Mess With the Dog in ‘In a Valley of Violence’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In a Valley of Violence
summary_short: A mysterious stranger rides into a decaying mining town with horse and collie. He didn’t mean to kick up trouble.

headline: Review: ‘Keeping Up With the Joneses’ Might Not Be Worth It
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Keeping Up With The Joneses
summary_short: This film about a spy couple has star power in Jon Hamm, but utilitarian construction and a lack of chemistry are downfalls.

headline: Review: ‘It Had to Be You’ Is a Witty Rom-Com With a 1950s Feel
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It Had To Be You
summary_short: Cristin Milioti plays an ambivalent woman weighing commitment in this film with a throwback touch.

headline: Review: In ‘The Uncondemned,’ Rwandan Rape Survivors Seek Justice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Uncondemned
summary_short: Facing an uphill battle, a small legal team puts a former Rwandan mayor on trial for his role in encouraging and ordering rapes during the country’s 1994 genocide.

headline: Review: In ‘Miss Hokusai,’ an Apprentice to the Artistic Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Hokusai
summary_short: This extraordinary film is a lively inquiry into the life of the daughter of the 19th-century Japanese painter Katsushika Hokusai.

headline: Review: In ‘Kevin Hart: What Now?,’ a Stadium Brimming With Brash Stand-Up
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kevin Hart: What Now?
summary_short: The comedian documents his popular 2015 tour in ways surprising and satisfying two-thirds of the time.

headline: Review: In ‘Christine,’ Why Did She Pull the Trigger? We Don’t Know
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Christine
summary_short: In this dramatization of a true story, Rebecca Hall is riveting as Christine Chubbuck, a television news reporter who killed herself on the air.

headline: Review: ‘Certain Women’ Are Worlds Unto Themselves
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Certain Women
summary_short: Kelly Reichardt’s film centers on a collection of women in a small town, and their individual tensions, sorrow and longing.

headline: Review: ‘Coming Through the Rye’ Tracks Down J.D. Salinger
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coming Through the Rye
summary_short: The film, written and directed by James Sadwith, is a fictionalized version of Mr. Sadwith’s meeting with J.D. Salinger.

headline: Review: A Crooked Cop Is Caught Between 2 Brutal Masters in ‘Asura: The City of Madness’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Asura: The City of Madness
summary_short: This film offers diversion but not sociological scope. Blood flows freely.

headline: Review: Stranded Migrants Are Easy Marks for a Madman in ‘Desierto’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desierto
summary_short: Lots of carnage and only a little back story equal a grim movie.

headline: Review: ‘Huntwatch’ Chronicles a Hard-Fought Battle to Protect Seals
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Huntwatch
summary_short: This film, one-sided in its approach, offers painful footage of the bludgeoning of pups in charting the decades-old movement against seal hunting.

headline: Review: For ‘Jack Goes Home,’ Cue the Horror Soundtrack
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack Goes Home
summary_short: Rory Culkin plays a magazine editor who returns to his hometown after his father is killed in a car crash, and delves into a past that’s deeply troubled.

display_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise
headline: Review: ‘Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise,’ a Life Well Lived
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise
summary_short: Photographs and film footage, as well as interviews with her son and artists who worked with her, add another dimension this documentary of a storied life.

headline: Review: In ‘The Accountant,’ Ben Affleck Plays a Savant With a Dark Secret
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Accountant
summary_short: The film stars Mr. Affleck as a genius on the autism spectrum whose proficiency with numbers leads him into a shady world.

headline: Review: ‘Godzilla’ Returns, Again, With a Wink
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shin Godzilla
summary_short: “Shin Godzilla” puts Tokyo in peril. Can the bumbling bureaucrats get their act together in time?

headline: Review: ‘By Sidney Lumet’ Puts the Director in Front of the Camera
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of By Sidney Lumet
summary_short: The documentary began as a series of interviews shot in 2008 in which the director talks about his life and work.

headline: Review: ‘Middle School,’ Where the Principal Is Mean and the Pranks Messy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Middle School
summary_short: This movie, adapted from a book from James Patterson’s library, follows a protagonist struggling with life in a new school and a nasty administrator.

headline: Review: An Undetonated Missile and Evil Spirits Lurk in ‘Under the Shadow’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under the Shadow
summary_short: In this horror film, a woman with a husband away on the front is left with her daughter, an unexploded missile and possibly a supernatural visitor.

headline: Review: ‘Voyage of Time,’ the Cosmology of Terrence Malick (the Short Version)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Voyage of Time
summary_short: Brad Pitt narrates a 45-minute Imax version of Mr. Malick’s documentary, a tour of astrophysics, biology, philosophy and religion. A feature-length cut will be released later to conventional theaters.

headline: Review: In ‘Mirzya,’ Echoes of ‘Romeo and Juliet,’ Lushly Shot
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mirzya
summary_short: Fine leading performances lift this film, which is based on a Punjab folk tale of star-crossed lovers.

headline: Review: ‘37,’ a Fictional Retelling of the Kitty Genovese Story
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 37
summary_short: This version of the story returns to the popular, but discredited belief that dozens of people deliberately ignored the cries of Ms. Genovese.

headline: Review: ‘The Great Gilly Hopkins,’ a Child’s Story Elevated by Grown-Ups
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Gilly Hopkins
summary_short: Although this film centers on an unruly foster child adapting to a new home, the real heart of the movie lies in the performances of Kathy Bates and Glenn Close.

headline: Review: ‘The Late Bloomer,’ About a Sex Therapist Who Missed Puberty
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Late Bloomer
summary_short: This comedy, directed by Kevin Pollak, searches somewhat desperately for laughs in the premise of 30-year-olds acting like frat boys.

headline: Review: In Nate Parker’s ‘The Birth of a Nation,’ Must-See and Won’t-See Collide
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Birth of a Nation
summary_short: This film about Nat Turner’s slave rebellion is an ambitious attempt to corral the contradictions of history within the conventions of popular narrative.

headline: Review: In ‘The Girl on the Train,’ a Boozy Emily Blunt Never Winks
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Girl on the Train
summary_short: In this adaptation of the best-selling mystery by Paula Hawkins, Ms. Blunt is one of three unreliable narrators, a heavy-drinking fantasist at that.

headline: Review: ‘Homeland: Iraq Year Zero’ Chronicles a War-Torn Family
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Homeland: Iraq Year Zero
summary_short: This two-part film from Abbas Fahdel gives a before-and-after account of his relatives’ lives around the time of the 2003 conflict.

headline: Review: In ‘Theo Who Lived,’ a Journalist Tells of His Capture by Al Qaeda
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Theo Who Lived
summary_short: A documentary follows Theo Padnos as he recreates his kidnapping and detainment by anti-American forces in Syria.

headline: Review: ‘M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story’ Recalls a Cricketer’s Ascent
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of M.S. Dhoni: The Untold Story
summary_short: The life of the captain of the winning 2011 World Cup team is recounted in this biopic from Neeraj Pandey.

display_title: Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children
headline: Review: In ‘Miss Peregrine’s Home,’ Chasing Grandpa’s Stories Down a Rabbit Hole
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Peregrine’s Home for Peculiar Children
summary_short: Tim Burton’s adaptation of the novel by Ransom Riggs describes the adventures of an adolescent who travels through time to prove his grandfather right.

headline: Review: ‘Harry & Snowman’ Recalls a Man and a Horse of Powerful Haunches
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harry & Snowman
summary_short: Ron Davis’s documentary is about Snowman, a white gelding and championship show jumper in his time, and Harry deLeyer, who raised him.

headline: Review: In ‘Amanda Knox,’ a Murder and Journalism Run Amok
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amanda Knox
summary_short: This documentary about the case of an exchange student killed in Italy focuses less on an accused killer and more on unprincipled journalism and unapologetic sexism.

headline: Review: Youthful Recklessness Finds Adventure on the Road in ‘American Honey’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Honey
summary_short: Andrea Arnold’s new feature (her first set in the United States), with a cast mostly of newcomers, follows a band of aimless youths around the country.

headline: Review: In ‘Denial,’ Confronting a Holocaust Revisionist in Court
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Denial
summary_short: The libel trial of a historian, brought by a Holocaust denier, is dramatized in this sober and methodical film. But the movie lacks an emotional flash point.

headline: Review: The Animated ‘Long Way North’ Finds a Girl on a Journey
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Long Way North
summary_short: The movie follows 14-year-old Sacha in the late 1800s as she goes off in search of her lost grandfather.

headline: Review: In ‘A Man Called Ove,’ Don’t Let That Scowl Fool You
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Man Called Ove
summary_short: Adapted from a best-selling Swedish novel, this film stars Rolf Lassgard as a gruff, unemployed railroad worker who befriends immigrants who are his new neighbors.

headline: Review: ‘Masterminds,’ a Tale of Grand Larceny and Meager Gray Matter
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Masterminds
summary_short: This comedy from Jared Hess stars Zach Galifianakis as a real-life felon who tried to steal millions of dollars in 1997.

headline: Review: ‘Passage to Mars,’ an Otherworldly Voyage on Earth
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passage to Mars

headline: Review: In ‘Deepwater Horizon,’ Oil, Fire and Greed
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deepwater Horizon
summary_short: Peter Berg’s film dramatizes a familiar story and stands as a work of popular narrative for an age of corporate impunity.

headline: Review: In ‘Queen of Katwe,’ a Pawn Finds Her Crown Through Chess

headline: Review: ‘Chicken People,’ Pampering Royalty That Clucks
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chicken People
summary_short: This documentary, directed by Nicole Lucas Haimes, looks at devotees of these fair fowl on the show circuit.

headline: Review: In ‘The Lovers and the Despot,’ a Harrowing Korean Ordeal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lovers and the Despot
summary_short: This documentary looks at how and why a South Korean actress, Choi Eun-hee, and a once successful film director, Shin Sang-ok, landed in North Korea.

headline: Review: In ‘Goat,’ Frat Brothers Unleash Their Sadistic Terror
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goat
summary_short: Nick Jonas and Ben Schnetzer star in this disturbing tale about the urge to belong, no matter what the cost.

headline: Review: In ‘I.T.,’ Smart House, Dumb Owner
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I.T.

headline: Review: ‘1000 Rupee Note,’ a Poor Widow’s Blessing and Curse

headline: Review: In ‘The Ruins of Lifta,’ a Dispute Amid the Rubble
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ruins of Lifta
summary_short: This documentary by Menachem Daum and Oren Rudavsky focuses on the fate of an old Arab village on the outskirts of Jerusalem.

headline: Review: In ‘Seed: The Untold Story,’ It’s Farmers Versus Big Business
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seed: The Untold Story
summary_short: This documentary raises alarm about declining crop diversity, genetically altered seeds and the ownership of nature.

headline: Review: In ‘The Dressmaker,’ a Femme Fatale Wants Vengeance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dressmaker
summary_short: Tilly Dunnage (Kate Winslet) returns to the dusty Australian hometown where she was bullied by a rich kid and blamed for his death.

headline: Review: ‘Storks,’ an Uneasy Return to Delivering Babies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Storks
summary_short: A new animated film, aimed at young children, has an infant that needs a home and a bird on a mission.

headline: Review: Denzel Washington Rides High in ‘The Magnificent Seven’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Magnificent Seven
summary_short: Ethan Hawke, Chris Pratt and Vincent D’Onofrio help round out the cast of this western remake, as outlaws who band together to protect a terrorized town.

headline: Review: ‘Defying the Nazis’: An American Couple on a Rescue Mission
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Defying the Nazis

headline: Review: ‘My Blind Brother,’ Who Is Also a Major Pain
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Blind Brother
summary_short: Sibling rivalry arises between an arrogant blind athlete and his helpful underdog brother when they end up in a love triangle with an appealing young woman.

headline: Review: ‘A Family Affair,’ or Airing Dirty Laundry
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Family Affair
summary_short: The Dutch documentarian Tom Fassaert pursues his own history, beginning with his 95-year-old grandmother in South Africa.

headline: Review: ‘Thank You for Your Service,’ Stories of Soldiers and Suicide
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thank You for Your Service

headline: Review: ‘Operation Avalanche,’ a Tale of Film Nerds on a Kubrick Caper

headline: Review: ‘Blair Witch’: Don’t Go Back Into the Woods

headline: Review: In ‘Southwest of Salem,’ 4 Women Convicted of Sexual Assault Fight for Justice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Southwest of Salem

headline: Review: ‘The Vessel’: Learning to Forge Ahead After Wrenching Loss
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Vessel
summary_short: Julio Quintana’s film centers on a young man who arouses ire when he sets out to build a boat after witnessing tragedies in his seaside village.

display_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week
headline: Review: ‘The Beatles: Eight Days a Week’ Taking the World by Storm
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Beatles: Eight Days a Week
summary_short: Ron Howard’s documentary explores the wild ride John, Paul, George and Ringo took in the early 1960s, helping to usher in the youth-culture age.

headline: Review: ‘Cardboard Boxer’: Homeless Man’s Redemption via a Diary
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cardboard Boxer
summary_short: Thomas Haden Church stars as a lonely skid row denizen whose life gains a new dimension after he finds a disheartened child’s diary.

headline: Review: In ‘Hillsong — Let Hope Rise,’ a Strumming Ministry Packs in Crowds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hillsong — Let Hope Rise

display_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket?...
headline: Review: A Sex-or-Guns Comedy That Might Make Aristophanes Wince
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Is That a Gun in Your Pocket?...
summary_short: “Is That a Gun in Your Pocket?...” is a clumsy comedy that transports the premise of “Lysistrata” to small-town Texas, with a twist.

headline: Review: ‘Silicon Cowboys’ Tracks the Rise of Compaq Computer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silicon Cowboys
summary_short: This documentary grounds itself in people and technology as it tells the story of a company that was bold at an opportune time in the 1980s.

headline: Review: ‘Snowden,’ Oliver Stone’s Restrained Portrait of a Whistle-Blower
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snowden

headline: Review: A Zany Renée Zellweger and Mystery Daddy in ‘Bridget Jones’s Baby’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bridget Jones's Baby
summary_short: The latest film in this series revolves around the pregnancy of Ms. Zellweger’s character and the two dreamboats most likely to be the father.

headline: Review: ‘When the Bough Breaks,’ Blame a Scary Pregnancy Surrogate
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When the Bough Breaks
summary_short: This movie, about a well-off couple and the woman they hire to carry their embryo, looks for suspense in a genre that has little left.

headline: Review: In ‘Kicks,’ the Promise (and Perils) of Those Air Jordans
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kicks

headline: Review: In ‘Demon,’ Wedding Jitters From the Uninvited Dead
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Demon
summary_short: A modern ghost story haunted by the Holocaust, this film by the Polish director Marcin Wrona reconceptualizes the Jewish mythology of the dybbuk.

headline: Review: In ‘As I Open My Eyes,’ Feeling a Revolution Coming
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As I Open My Eyes
summary_short: A headstrong singer comes of age on the eve of Tunisia’s Jasmine Revolution.

headline: Review: Sully Landed the Plane. Then He Had to Endure the Spotlight.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sully
summary_short: “Sully,” Clint Eastwood’s film about US Airways Flight 1549, largely involves what happens after he, his crew and his passengers are plucked from the Hudson.

headline: Review: ‘Author: The JT Leroy Story’ Renders a Literary Charlatan
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Author: The JT Leroy Story
summary_short: Jeff Feuerzeig’s documentary charts the invention of an underage H.I.V.-positive hustler, and how the famous and nonfamous were taken in until the hoax was exposed.

headline: Review: ‘Brother Nature’: Fish Out of Water With the Future In-Laws
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brother Nature
summary_short: Taran Killam and Bobby Moynihan of “Saturday Night Live” are among the cast in an unfunny comedy set in the woods.

headline: Review: In ‘The Wild Life,’ Island Critters School a Castaway
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wild Life
summary_short: This animated film, long on amiability if not complexity, features amusing animal characters learning to collaborate with a shipwrecked Crusoe.

headline: Review: In ‘Other People,’ a Son’s Anxieties Mount as Tragedy Looms
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Other People
summary_short: A deeply personal tale from the writer-director Chris Kelly, the movie follows a gay comedy writer in New York who returns home to care for his mother.

headline: Review: ‘Come What May,’ an Ode to French Villagers Displaced by War
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Come What May
summary_short: Christian Carion’s event-packed World War II film lines up an impressive cast but leans toward the sentimental and schematic.

headline: Review: ‘One More Time With Feeling’ Listens to Nick Cave’s Darkness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One More Time With Feeling
summary_short: Andrew Dominik’s 3-D black-and-white documentary focuses on the making of Mr. Cave’s 16th album, “The Skeleton Tree.”

headline: Review: ‘Starving the Beast’ Traces the Burdens of Higher Education Defunding
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starving the Beast
summary_short: This documentary by Steve Mims describes an ideological war over public higher education that is being conducted state by state.

headline: Review: ‘Equal Means Equal’ Asks How Far Women Have Really Come
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Equal Means Equal
summary_short: Kamala Lopez’s fact-packed documentary features legal experts, ordinary women and feminists like Eleanor Smeal and Gloria Steinem.

headline: Review: ‘White Girl,’ a Tale of Cocaine, Sex and Privilege
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of White Girl
summary_short: Elizabeth Wood’s film stars Morgan Saylor as a wild college ingenue who winds up struggling when her new drug-dealing boyfriend is arrested.

headline: Review: In ‘Zoom,’ Everyone Feels Certain Body Parts Are Too Small
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zoom
summary_short: Alison Pill, Jason Priestley, Gael García Bernal and Mariana Ximenes star in Pedro Morelli’s amusing mix of animation and live action.

headline: Review: A Baby in a Boat Changes Everything in ‘The Light Between Oceans’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Light Between Oceans
summary_short: Michael Fassbender and Alicia Vikander play an Australian couple who long for a child — and happen to find one — in this post-World War I romance.

headline: Review: ‘Max Rose’ Has Jerry Lewis Tearful Over a Hint of Infidelity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Max Rose
summary_short: Mr. Lewis, for all his outsize comic credentials, can be a formidable dramatic actor, but this film provides no space for the story’s darker corners.

headline: Review: In Kevin Smith’s ‘Yoga Hosers,’ Enlightenment Is Elusive
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yoga Hosers
summary_short: This film, the second in a comedy-horror trilogy, features a quirky Johnny Depp and two heroines named Colleen.

headline: Review: ‘The 9th Life of Louis Drax.’ So, Little Boys Get Nine Lives, Too?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The 9th Life of Louis Drax
summary_short: “The 9th Life of Louis Drax” starts with a disastrous ninth birthday and some unanswered questions.

headline: Review: Jokes, Not Punches, Land With a Thud in ‘Skiptrace’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skiptrace
summary_short: In “Skiptrace,” Jackie Chan tries the unlikely-buddy conceit again, this time with Johnny Knoxville.

headline: Review: In ‘Kickboxer: Vengeance,’ Duty Calls for an Unpracticed Fighter
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kickboxer: Vengeance
summary_short: In John Stockwell’s film, a man seeking to avenge his slain brother trains under a martial-arts master. Guess who: Jean-Claude Van Damme.

display_title: The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger
headline: Review: ‘The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger’ Lauds a Renaissance Man
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Seasons in Quincy: Four Portraits of John Berger
summary_short: These four film shorts, each by a different director, evoke aspects of a brilliant art historian and essayist living in the French Alps.

headline: Review: War Made Terrifyingly Palpable in ‘Citizen Soldier’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Citizen Soldier
summary_short: This documentary powerfully uses footage to track a group of American soldiers during a tour of duty in Afghanistan in 2011.

headline: Review: ‘Uncle Kent 2,’ How’s Your Tolerance for Hipster Milquetoasts?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Uncle Kent 2
summary_short: Kent Osborne returns as the starring character in this sequel to the 2011 film “Uncle Kent.”

headline: Review: Jason Statham in ‘Mechanic: Resurrection,’ a Hit Man on Cruise Control

headline: Review: In ‘Right Now, Wrong Then,’ a Double Take and Its Choices

headline: Review: In ‘The Neon Demon,’ Beauty Masks a Rotting Core

headline: Review: In ‘Breaking a Monster,’ a Plea to Play Heavy Metal

summary_short: Jake is a filmmaker frustrated with parenthood and lonely after a divorce. What better way to solve this existential crisis than to make a movie about his life?

headline: Death Calls, but So Does the Environment
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Will for the Woods
summary_short: “A Will for the Woods” is a documentary about natural burial that focuses on a psychiatrist as he prepares for his death.

headline: Friendship Ripens Into ... Well, You Know
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What If
summary_short: “What If” is a romantic comedy in which the small matter of a large live-in boyfriend gets in the way.

headline: Metaphysical Sleight of Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magic in the Moonlight
summary_short: In Woody Allen’s “Magic in the Moonlight,” a magician is summoned to the French Riviera to expose a young clairvoyant who has won over a rich family.

headline: From Baby Fat to Stubble: Growing Up in Real Time
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boyhood
summary_short: Richard Linklater’s tender and profound film, which follows a boy and his family over a dozen years in real time, is a meticulously textured work set to the rhythm of life.

headline: A Badge, a Car, a Vest and Most of the Rest
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let's Be Cops

headline: Halle Berry as a Woman of Many Faces

headline: Pity the Poor Working Artist in Las Vegas
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Step Up All In
summary_short: The dance film “Step Up All In” tackles the travails of the working artist.

headline: An Expert in Disaster
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Into the Storm

headline: The Invisible but All-Seeing Servant

summary_short: In “The Maid’s Room,” a live-in maid in the Hamptons gains some leverage over her employers.

headline: Too Many Cooks Spoil the Village

summary_short: French haute cuisine clashes with Indian cooking in “The Hundred-Foot Journey,” starring Helen Mirren and Om Puri.

headline: A Family With Problems, Not All of Them Obvious

headline: He Feels Good, Sometimes

headline: Young Missourians, Hard Times

headline: Yee-Ha! Space Cowboy Rides to the Rescue

display_title: Rabindranath Tagore: The Poet of Eternity
headline: A Bengali Poet Sings Again

summary_short: A one-hour film intended for schools and students focuses on Tagore’s greatness as a universal soul.

headline: A Search and Destroy Thyself Mission

headline: She Has Seen Too Much, and It Shows

headline: All Tribalism and Treachery, Dude

headline: Deep in Her Gut, She Knows She’s Not Ordinary

headline: When Grumpy Met Sappy

headline: A Long and Winding History of Gaming

headline: Pay Your Taxes, Kill the Neighbors

headline: Oops! Pushed the Wrong Button

headline: Fire Flight

headline: They’re Out to Get Him, Whoever They Are

headline: As Boy Woos Girl, Whimsy Is in the Picture

headline: A Family Gathers, and So Does the Dysfunction

headline: Neighbors Who Need Good Fences
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dawn of the Planet of the Apes

headline: For One Team, It’s Sink or Swim
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Underwater Dreams
summary_short: Students from a low-income high school in Arizona win a robotics competition and reflect on their victory in “Underwater Dreams.”

headline: A Fugitive Who Stops to Smell the Flowers

headline: If Gatsby Were Coming of Age Today ...

headline: The Genre, if Not the Song, Remains the Same

headline: Those 3-D Effects Are the Bee’s Knees

headline: Wanderlust as the Enemy of Love

headline: A New York Cop Walks the Satan Beat

summary_short: A New York police officer teams up with a priest to combat demonic possession in the horror movie “Deliver Us From Evil.”

headline: More Than One Shot at a Good Day

headline: When Life Offers Lemons, Zest Them

headline: In the Suburban Night, a Creature Awaits

headline: Let the Mass Destruction Begin

headline: Secrets of the Universe, Embedded in Pop Ditties

headline: Comedy and Carnage

display_title: The Pleasures of Being Out of Step
headline: From Liner Notes to Front Lines of Advocacy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pleasures of Being Out of Step

headline: Torn by Three Loves and Styles of Jousting

headline: What Happens in Vegas ...

headline: After Challenging Hitler, It All Goes to the Dogs

headline: You’re Just Too Good to Be True

headline: Every Dish Is a Plat du Jour

headline: A Car Is Stolen, Setting Off an Angry Pursuit

headline: One Generation Passes; Another One Grumbles

headline: He’s a Great Pet, Even if He Does Singe Your Hair

headline: A Woman Is Courted, but the Suitor Is Her Father

headline: A Young Man’s Dark-Roasted Day

headline: Just Like the Last One, Only Different

headline: It Takes Some Heat to Create Movie Stars

headline: Killed in Action by Aliens, Over and Over Again

headline: A Passionate Symbol, Even Without the World Cup

headline: Young Love, Complicated by Cancer

headline: Bringing Blood to the Neighborhood

headline: Crossing Borders Through Cinema

headline: Navy Pilots Under the Gun

summary_short: The one-man comedy juggernaut Seth MacFarlane directed himself in this western spoof.

headline: Dumped by Her Prince, So Watch Out

headline: Its Devotees Are Diverse, and You Can Dance to It

headline: Anything to Save Their Pensions

headline: Misdiagnosis? You’d Be Angry, Too

headline: Lifetime Anguish Is the High Cost of Courage

headline: On the Range, With a Conscience

summary_short: Kirk Hanna, the focus of the documentary “Hanna Ranch,” appeared in “Fast Food Nation.”

headline: Hapless Meal Tickets, Plucked From India

headline: Dad’s Watching Us? Call Social Services

headline: Wicked Witch Is Dead, but Here Comes a Jester

summary_short: A cast of familiar characters embarks on a rescue mission in the animated “Legends of Oz: Dorothy’s Return.”

summary_short: The documentary “The American Nurse,” a tribute to the profession, focuses on five who work across life’s spectrum, from labor and delivery to hospice.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of NOW: In the Wings on a World Stage

headline: A Man and His Elephant, and Flying Fists

summary_short: A sequel to “The Protector” revolves around another kidnapping of the sacred elephant Khon.

headline: Insert an Emoticon Here

summary_short: The comedy “Friended to Death” uses a noxious protagonist to look at social media.

headline: Revisiting Familial Territory

headline: On the Trail of a Gene That Kills

headline: The Mysterious Adventure of the Good Night’s Sleep

headline: Young Hands Steering the Family Tractor

headline: Possessed by Demons, and a Nutty Professor
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Quiet Ones

summary_short: Sylvia Caminer’s “Tanzania: A Journey Within” documents a trip a young American woman takes with her Tanzanian friend, back to his homeland.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Passenger

headline: Struggling to Escape the Bronx’s Grasp
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grand Slammed

headline: Drunk, Ornery and With a Gun in His Hands

headline: Moving In? Beware the Other Residents
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Haunted House 2
summary_short: Marlon Wayans stars in “A Haunted House 2,” his second stop in this horror-spoof franchise.

headline: Competing to Be a Phallic Symbol

headline: A Plea for Equal Pay for Equal Pedaling

headline: I Am My Own Monster (Technology Rules!)

headline: A Bear, Her Cubs and the Wilderness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bears
summary_short: Disney’s “Bears” is the chronicle of a year in the hungry life of one bear and her two cubs in the Alaskan wilderness.

headline: His Résumé Before the Age of 4: ‘I Saw Jesus on a Horse’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heaven is for Real
summary_short: The 2010 best-selling book “Heaven Is for Real” has made it to the screen, starring Greg Kinnear.

headline: In a Scary Uniform, Subverting a March to Death
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walking with the Enemy
summary_short: “Walking With the Enemy” is based on the real-life story of a Hungarian Jew who saved lives during World War II by posing as a Nazi officer.

headline: Domesticated Macaws Reclaiming Their Wild Side
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rio 2
summary_short: In “Rio 2,” a mated pair of blue macaws and their brood leave Rio for the lush perils of the Amazon rain forest.

headline: Writing a Playbook That Ensures Glory
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Draft Day
summary_short: Kevin Costner plays the beleaguered general manager of the Cleveland Browns in “Draft Day.”

headline: On the Wall, Who’s the Deadliest One of All?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Oculus
summary_short: Karen Gillan and Brenton Thwaites play siblings seeking clues to their parents’ fate in a tale alternating between time periods.

headline: Wooing the Boss With a Spicy Dance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cuban Fury
summary_short: In “Cuban Fury,” the British comic Nick Frost stars as a former child salsa-dancing champ who brushes up on his skills to woo his new American boss.

headline: Nonstop Carnage, Indonesian-Style
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Raid 2: Berandal
summary_short: Neither the undercover drama in “The Raid 2” nor its two-and-a-half-hour length bog down its numerous bracing and bloody brawls.

headline: Courage, Loyalty, Honor, Kablooey
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain America: The Winter Soldier
summary_short: Producers describe “Captain America: The Winter Soldier,” a sequel in the comic-book-based franchise, as a blend of action film and political thriller.

headline: Futzing and Flirting as Armageddon Unfolds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goodbye World
summary_short: In “Goodbye World,” a violent breakdown in society prompts friends to reunite at the home of a couple who live off the grid.

headline: Open Marriage Trying to Induce Same
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10 Rules for Sleeping Around
summary_short: “10 Rules for Sleeping Around,” about one couple who allow each other to fool around and another that doesn’t, combines nudity and jokes, but fails to be a sex comedy.

headline: The Profits and Losses of Fugitive Tracking
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Retrieval
summary_short: In “The Retrieval,” written and directed by Chris Eska, a black youngster working for Civil War bounty hunters helps them capture black fugitives.

headline: Review: A Search for Meaning in ‘Garnet’s Gold’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Garnet’s Gold
summary_short: This documentary by Ed Perkins chronicles a search for a stash of gold, but also ends up telling a larger story about one man’s life.

headline: Review: In ‘The Hand That Feeds,’ Workers Rise Up at a Hot & Crusty
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hand That Feeds
summary_short: This documentary chronicles labor organizing by low-paid employees at a Manhattan bakery-cafe.

display_title: Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen of Pointe à la Hache
headline: Oil and Water Mix, Then Emotions Flare
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vanishing Pearls: The Oystermen of Pointe à la Hache
summary_short: The documentary “Vanishing Pearls” looks at the small Gulf community of Pointe à la Hache, La., where the oyster industry has been devastated by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill.

headline: A Rock Star and a Roadie, Brothers After All
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mistaken for Strangers
summary_short: A scruffy documentary of the band the National’s 2010-11 European tour is less about the music than about left-field interviews with bemused band members.

headline: A Boyhood Summer of Darkness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hide Your Smiling Faces
summary_short: Daniel Patrick Carbone’s haunting debut feature offers a dark vision of boyhood adventure in a great outdoors fraught with peril.

headline: Rain, Heavy at Times
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Noah
summary_short: Russell Crowe stars in “Noah,” Darren Aronofsky’s adaptation of the Old Testament story, which brings blockbuster spectacle and narrative liberties to the story.

headline: Amid Chants of ‘¡Huelga!,’ an Embodiment of Hope
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cesar Chavez
summary_short: Diego Luna’s “Cesar Chavez” reconstructs the emergence of the United Farm Workers organization in the 1960s and focuses on the movement’s leader, who died in 1993.

headline: Gang Wars, Iraq Warfare
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Greencard Warriors
summary_short: “Greencard Warriors” follows a family that will do almost anything for papers.

headline: Carnage and Chaos, Heavy on the Gore
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sabotage
summary_short: Arnold Schwarzenegger leads a gang of marauding Drug Enforcement Administration undercover thugs in “Sabotage,” and the bodies and bullets fly.

headline: A Spelling Bee Bully With Decades on His Rivals
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Words
summary_short: “Bad Words,” Jason Bateman’s feature-directing debut, is a would-be gonzo comedy with a tough exterior and a marshmallow center.

headline: Bittersweet Chocolate on the Pillow
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grand Budapest Hotel
summary_short: On its surface, “The Grand Budapest Hotel” is a caper, but this Wes Anderson film is also concerned with a complicated slice of 20th-century European culture with some very ugly history.

display_title: What Is a Man Without a Mustache?
headline: Random Bits of Whimsy in Croatia in 'What Is a Man Without a Mustache?'
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Is a Man Without a Mustache?
summary_short: Quirks of fate give shape to "What Is a Man Without a Mustache?," a pleasant if inconsequential romantic comedy from the Croatian director Hrvoje Hribar.

headline: Facing Eviction, He Can’t Resist a Dare
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cheap Thrills
summary_short: “Cheap Thrills” is a dark comedy about two friends who fall into a rough game with a wealthy couple they meet at a bar.

headline: Pursuing Sex With a Bad Boy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It Felt Like Love
summary_short: “It Felt Like Love” considers the dangers of teenage desire through the experiences of a coltish 14-year-old girl who randomly fixes on a weed-smoking tough guy.

headline: Muppets, a Front for Bigger Schemes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Muppets Most Wanted
summary_short: “Muppets Most Wanted,” an international caper, includes shots at Russians and the sly skewering of our European allies.

headline: Review: In ‘Divergent,’ Jolted Awake by Fear and Romance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Divergent
summary_short: In its movie incarnation, Veronica Roth’s dystopian novel “Divergent” has high-stakes action, a gutsy teenage heroine who is an outlier, and romance between warriors.

headline: A Cop With a Secret
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of McCanick
summary_short: Cory Monteith plays a street hustler in “McCanick,” the story of a cranky police detective (David Morse) with something to hide.

headline: Welcome Home. Just Avoid the Headgear
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Awakened
summary_short: “Awakened,” a thriller starring Julianne Michelle, follows a woman who has returned to her hometown to investigate her mother’s death.

headline: Returning, in His Own Way, to the Killing Fields
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Missing Picture
summary_short: In “The Missing Picture,” the director Rithy Panh uses figurines and the usual documentary devices to relay his personal story regarding Cambodia’s killing fields.

display_title: Tyler Perry's The Single Moms Club
headline: A Cranky Bonding Agent for Society’s Oil and Water
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's The Single Moms Club
summary_short: Thrown together after their children misbehave in school, five very different women form a support group in “Tyler Perry’s The Single Moms Club.”

headline: Writing a New Romance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shirin in Love
summary_short: In “Shirin in Love,” a young Iranian-American journalist who feels lukewarm about her fiancé rushes headlong into a relationship with the son of an interview subject.

headline: Preserving Culture in the Amazon
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Xingu
summary_short: “Xingu” tells how three brothers, hoping to protect indigenous people in the Amazon, helped create a sprawling national park in Brazil.

headline: Oil Money, and Where It Flows
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Men
summary_short: Rachel Boynton’s documentary “Big Men” is about the 2007 discovery of oil off the coast of Ghana and the perfect storm of avarice that develops around it.

headline: The Killer Online
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Den
summary_short: In “The Den,” directed by Zach Donohue, a graduate student researching video-chat culture witnesses a murder online.

headline: Fast Cars, and Racing for Revenge
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Need for Speed
summary_short: Aaron Paul stars in “Need for Speed,” a B movie based on a video game series that might be best seen at a drive-in.

headline: Where Performance Enhancers Are Legal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Better Living Through Chemistry
summary_short: A rather dull married pharmacist (Sam Rockwell) and a gorgeous, equally married customer (Olivia Wilde) make for an explosive compound in “Better Living Through Chemistry.”

headline: The Glory of Rome, the Sweetness of Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Beauty
summary_short: In “The Great Beauty,” a sybaritic writer, now 65, considers the essence of Rome and his place in it.

headline: Exploring the Blot on a Newspaper’s Record
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Fragile Trust
summary_short: Samantha Grant’s documentary, “A Fragile Trust,” comes a decade after the fraud scandal at The New York Times perpetrated by the reporter Jayson Blair.

headline: A Pakistani Fiancé Meets the Indian Parents
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Total Siyapaa
summary_short: In “Total Siyapaa,” an Indian woman brings her fiancé home to meet her family, a crew that seems more malicious than madcap.

headline: A Dog and His Boy Take a Joy Ride Through History
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Peabody & Sherman
summary_short: A supersmart dog and his adopted human son set out for time-traveling adventures in “Mr. Peabody & Sherman,” the 3-D, big-screen adaptation of Jay Ward’s animated cartoon.

headline: A Miracle Drug or Quackery?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Second Opinion: Laetrile at Sloan-Kettering
summary_short: Eric Merola’s documentary “Second Opinion: Laetrile at Sloan-Kettering” examines a disputed drug.

display_title: Double Play: James Benning and Richard Linklater
headline: Duet for Directors, in a Conversational Key
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Double Play: James Benning and Richard Linklater
summary_short: The film directors Richard Linklater and James Benning chat about their shared interests in the documentary “Double Play.”

headline: Poignant in Tooth and Claw
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ernest & Celestine
summary_short: “Ernest & Celestine,” about a mouse and a bear, offers the childhood comfort of a miniature world.

headline: The Greatest Story, Retold
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Son of God
summary_short: Adapted from “The Bible,” a History channel mini-series, “Son of God” depicts the last days of Jesus.

headline: Eggs Over Easy, With a Side of Weird
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Odd Thomas
summary_short: The hero of “Odd Thomas,” an adaptation by Stephen Sommers of the Dean Koontz novel, is a short-order cook who sees dead people and finds their murderers.

headline: An Unreliable Hero Aboard a Troubled Flight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Non-Stop
summary_short: Liam Neeson stars as an unsettled air marshal trying to prevent murders in the air in “Non-Stop.”

headline: Waiting With Bittersweet Anxiety for Their Moment
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Standbys
summary_short: The director Stephanie Riggs follows the tribulations of three actors who are on call to step in for a star in a stage show.

headline: For a Kurdish Woman, No Way Out
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Candle, Two Candles...
summary_short: In “One Candle, Two Candles ...,” the heroine is pressured to marry a rich older man.

headline: Lava and Lust
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pompeii
summary_short: In Paul W. S. Anderson’s gladiator disaster film “Pompeii,” the lone survivor of a Celtic tribe becomes a slave, but his horse-whisperer talents helps redirect his fate.

headline: Down and Armed in Paris, Teenager in Tow
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3 Days to Kill
summary_short: In “3 Days to Kill,” Kevin Costner plays a much-put-upon C.I.A. assassin in Paris with bad guys to dispatch and child-care issues.

headline: In Soulful Devotion, Glimmers of Doom
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wind Rises
summary_short: The animated film “The Wind Rises,” which Hayao Miyazaki says will be his last, is a poetic yet somber depiction of Jiro Horikoshi as a young warplane designer.

headline: Shedding the Cliché of High School Sex
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Date and Switch
summary_short: “Date and Switch,” directed by Chris Nelson, is a new entry in the high school movie pool.

headline: Demons at Work in Snowy Magic of New York
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Winter's Tale
summary_short: The film adaptation of “Winter’s Tale” partakes of wide-eyed mystical wonder but pitches helplessly into ridiculousness.

headline: Fantasy Girl at Your Service
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lucky Bastard
summary_short: In “Lucky Bastard,” a contest in which the winner is invited to have sex with an actress from a pornographic film has grim consequences.

headline: Once a Lowlife, Always a Lowlife
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Easy Money: Hard to Kill
summary_short: In “Easy Money: Hard to Kill,” the second film of a Swedish franchise, a former glamour boy escapes from prison and tries unsuccessfully to eke an honest existence.

headline: A Couplet Fantasy Denied
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adult World
summary_short: In “Adult World,” an aspiring 22-year-old poet takes the only job she can find, as an assistant in a pornographic bookstore, but persists in a fantasy about literary renown.

headline: With a Dentist’s Chair and a Chicken Mask, a Girl Can’t Say No
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of About Last Night
summary_short: “About Last Night,” a raucously entertaining remake, follows the difficulties faced by two couples, one sensitive and well behaved, the other outrageously naughty.

headline: Hellbent on Fusing His Soul With Hers
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Endless Love
summary_short: “Endless Love, based on the 1979 novel by Scott Spencer, focuses on an all-consuming relationship between a boy and a privileged girl whose parents are deeply concerned about it.”

headline: Less Redemption, More Tears
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of RoboCop
summary_short: An ordinary man gets a new life in “RoboCop,” directed by José Padilha.

headline: Aw, He Seemed So Nice and Sexy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Truth
summary_short: “Truth” focuses on a troubled young man who gives into his dark side after falling for someone he met on the Internet.

headline: Bloody Trouble at School
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vampire Academy
summary_short: “Vampire Academy,” based on Richelle Mead’s young adult series, uses many familiar themes of the bloodsucking genre.

headline: But You Can’t Deny Destiny
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hasee Toh Phasee
summary_short: In “Hasee Toh Phasee,” a wedding is approaching, but the groom has some things on his mind, including his fiancée’s long-estranged sister.

headline: After a Bad Breakup, Anything Goes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love & Air Sex
summary_short: “Love & Air Sex,” which follows two couples whose relationships have recently dissolved, is set in a city teeming with singles and air sex competitions.

headline: A Jumbled Journey Through a Curious Marketplace
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 7 Boxes
summary_short: A pushcart delivery boy in Paraguay takes a job for a shady butcher, and chaos ensues in this film directed by Juan Carlos Maneglia and Tana Schémbori.

headline: Now They’ll Love Me, a Twin Sister Schemes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pretty One
summary_short: “The Pretty One” stars Zoe Kazan as a pair of twins, one mousy and insecure, the other vivacious. When the popular twin dies in a car accident, her sister decides to assume her identity.

headline: Toying With Ideas Outside the Manual
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lego Movie
summary_short: “The Lego Movie” flirts with flouting its marketing imperative even as it embodies it.

headline: Dreamscapes of a Nightmarish Conflict
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mars at Sunrise
summary_short: Jessica Habie’s “Mars at Sunrise” distills the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to a single duel.

headline: A-Team Tracks Nazi Plunder
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Monuments Men
summary_short: In “The Monuments Men,” George Clooney stars as an art historian who leads a quirky crew in a World War II operation to recover troves of artworks stolen by the Nazis.

headline: Your Child Is Choosing a College; Time to Tag Along
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of At Middleton
summary_short: The romantic comedy “At Middleton” is also a delicate film about two people confronting their flawed marriages.

headline: For One-Night Lotharios, It’s Time to Face the Truth
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of That Awkward Moment
summary_short: In the sex comedy “That Awkward Moment,” three best buddies make a pact not to be emotionally tangled with women, but then proceed to break the rules.

headline: Is It Love, or Stockholm Syndrome?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Labor Day
summary_short: In “Labor Day,” set in a small town in 1987, an escaped criminal takes shelter with a woman and her son and soon wins them over.

headline: He’s in Love, but No Closer to Figuring It Out
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brightest Star
summary_short: The drama “Brightest Star” focuses on romantic relationships, using a young man as the focus.

headline: Thrilling to the Brrroom of a Renegade Cohort
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 12 O'Clock Boys
summary_short: The documentary “12 O’Clock Boys” follows a youth through his initiation into a group of dirt bike riders who like to taunt the police.

headline: An Old Town With New Problems
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's Better to Jump
summary_short: “It’s Better to Jump” allows Arab residents to express their concerns about the gentrification of their city, part of which is a Unesco World Heritage site.

headline: Everyone Wants a Piece of This Wandering Monster
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I, Frankenstein
summary_short: Aaron Eckhart plays a version of Mary Shelley’s monster in the new film “I, Frankenstein,” also starring Bill Nighy.

headline: The Holocaust Lives on in a Fractured Family
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Papirosen
summary_short: “Papirosen,” a documentary by the filmmaker Gastón Solnicki, follows generations of his Polish-Argentine family.

headline: How Love Survives Altered Expectations
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Run & Jump
summary_short: When an Irish husband, father and craftsman suffers a stroke, his family, and an outsider, reflect the changed balance of the household.

headline: It’s a Guy Thing
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 24 Exposures
summary_short: A photographer who takes what he calls “fetish photos” is the subject of “24 Exposures.”

headline: You May Already Be a Winner. Or Not.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nebraska
summary_short: “Nebraska,” Alexander Payne’s fourth film set at least partly in his home state, stars Bruce Dern, Will Forte and June Squibb in a comedy that gets under a cantankerous older man’s skin.

headline: In a Teenage Snake Pit, a Chance to Be Trendy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of G.B.F.
summary_short: Every mean girl needs a gay male best friend; at least that’s what the teenagers in “G.B.F.” believe.

headline: She’s Having My Baby, Satan Croons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Devil's Due
summary_short: “Devil’s Due” centers on a couple who discover they’re expecting a baby after a honeymoon outing that they can’t fully recall. Hmm.

headline: Sea, Sky, Spray and a Love Triangle
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer in February
summary_short: “Summer in February,” directed by Christopher Menaul, focuses on a love triangle involving the painter A. J. Munnings at an artists’ colony in Edwardian England.

headline: These Criminals Are Throwbacks
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Nut Job
summary_short: The animated feature “The Nut Job” centers on a gang of humans trying to rob a bank, and a group of squirrels attempting a heist of a nut store.

headline: Deception and Uncertainty Feed a Murky Justice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reasonable Doubt
summary_short: In “Reasonable Doubt,” a prosecutor thinks he has committed a fatal hit-and-run and then tries to derail the prosecution of a man fingered for the death.

headline: You Have the Right to Remain Funny
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ride Along
summary_short: Kevin Hart plays a man aspiring to be a police officer, and Ice Cube plays a veteran on the force in this buddy cop comedy.

headline: One Good Man to Save the World
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit
summary_short: Paramount reboots an action franchise, casting Chris Pine in a role previously played by Alec Baldwin, Harrison Ford and Ben Affleck.

headline: A Confused Boy Wants to Play, Even When Others Want to Fight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When I Saw You
summary_short: In “When I Saw You,” a young Palestinian boy runs away from a refugee camp in 1967 and ends up with a band of volunteer soldiers preparing to fight Israelis.

headline: Wrestlers in Leather: What More Is Required?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Legend of Hercules
summary_short: “The Legend of Hercules,” directed by Renny Harlin, has lots of abs and Kellan Lutz as the title demigod.

headline: Buying Peace of Mind With a Pistol
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Loves Her Gun
summary_short: After a violent mugging, a young New York woman moves to Austin, Tex., in search of peace and security in “Loves Her Gun.”

headline: Everyone’s a Drag, Except That Cool New Neighbor
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Truth About Emanuel
summary_short: “The Truth About Emanuel,” a difficult teenager becomes fascinated with a mysterious woman who moves in next door with her new baby.

headline: Coming-of-Age in Wartime
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Bloom
summary_short: “In Bloom,” Georgia’s entry for the Best Foreign Language Film Oscar, tracks the lives of two girls in Tbilisi in 1992, during the newly independent country’s civil war.

headline: A Korean Who’s More Than He Seems
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Suspect
summary_short: “The Suspect” centers on a former North Korean operative who is on the run after being framed for the murder of his boss.

headline: No Heavy Lifting for These Gym Rats
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dumbbells
summary_short: Were you longing for a gross-out comedy about fitness centers? Do you need to see more Fabio on screen? “Dumbbells” is here.

headline: Splitsville, a Land of Diabolical Lawyers
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Divorce Corp
summary_short: The documentary “Divorce Corp.” argues that lawyers and courts collude to make divorces as expensive and drawn-out as possible.

headline: She’s Hard as Nails, He’s Noir and Nasty
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cold Comes the Night
summary_short: “Cold Comes the Night” pits a young motel owner against a criminal who takes her and her daughter hostage to recover a fortune in cash.

headline: It’s a Jungle Out There, From Snakes to Mine Monsters
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chander Pahar
summary_short: “Chander Pahar” centers on a Bengali boy who sets out in search of gold and diamond mines and confronts a cave monster.

headline: The Danish Prince and His Family Drama
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hamlet
summary_short: Bruce Ramsay’s “Hamlet” is set in an upper-class, buttoned-down home in postwar London.

headline: I Remember Mama, the Pot Smuggler
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free Ride
summary_short: A mother with two daughters finds work in Florida as a marijuana smuggler, in this semiautobiographical drama written and directed by Shana Betz.

headline: Home Fires, Acridly Burning
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of August: Osage County
summary_short: The word “acting” is inadequate for what the cast of “August: Osage County” is doing. It’s more of a thespian cage match.

headline: Soldiers Fighting, but Coping Most of All
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lone Survivor
summary_short: Mark Wahlberg stars as an American soldier in Afghanistan in a film based on Marcus Luttrell’s memoir.

headline: Disembodied, but, Oh, What a Voice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Her
summary_short: “Her,” directed by Spike Jonze, centers on a lonely soul who is drawn out by the female voice of his computer operating system.

headline: Melancholy Odyssey Through the Folk Scene
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inside Llewyn Davis
summary_short: “Inside Llewyn Davis” is an intoxicating, somewhat surreal ramble through the Greenwich Village folk scene in 1961.

headline: Revelers, Pause to Meet Yourselves
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1
summary_short: A bawdy college kegger has a possible extraterrestrial mystery in “+1.”

headline: Recalling a Disaster Without Uttering a Word
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Flood
summary_short: “The Great Flood” uses music and stark images to tell about the destruction and aftermath of the 1927 Mississippi River flood.

headline: Quick, Get the Camera: Fido’s Levitating
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paranormal Activity: The Marked Ones
summary_short: “The Marked Ones,” the fifth film in the “Paranormal Activity” franchise, aims for a new market with the same special effects.

headline: When the Visitors Don’t Walk So Lightly on the Land
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gringo Trails
summary_short: “Gringo Trails,” a documentary by Pegi Vail, considers the impact adventure tourists have on the exotic locations they visit.

headline: A Cold, Appraising Eye, Spying Treasure

headline: The Mother Country Knows Best

headline: A Big Nest, Bursting With a Family’s Vices

headline: Violence and Thievery Find Room for Honor

headline: Microcosm of Society, Seeking an Anchor

headline: A Horror Movie Parody

headline: As Sea Gulls Hover, Three Old Friends Reunite for a Funeral

headline: Unpacking the Pandora’s Box of Technology

headline: First He Is Killed, and Then He Tells His Tale

headline: A Boyhood Friendship Fractured by War

headline: These Law Enforcers Will Stop at Nothing

headline: That House Grandma Left Her Is a Mess

headline: The Black, the White and the Angry

headline: ‘No Means No,’ and More From Wise Grandparents

headline: The Wretched Lift Their Voices

headline: The Calm Before the Kablooey

headline: Might Makes Him Mr. Right

headline: Happy Birthday, You Miserable Achievers

headline: Into the Wild, Whether They Want to or Not

headline: Trading Wig and Floppy Dress for a Badge

headline: In Harm’s Way in Istanbul

headline: It’s Aliiiive! And Wagging Its Tail

headline: The Tyrant as Tourist

headline: When There Really Is Not a Drop to Drink

headline: Wry and Subtle Jesting? Not Here, Knucklehead

headline: Flexing His Way Through a Borrowed Plot
