headline: The Camera Doesn’t Lie, Does It?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Archie's Final Project
summary_short: In “Archie’s Final Project,” the protagonist’s life is one big movie, with both comic and troubled sides, but the film’s message about teenage angst is completely serious.

headline: From a School Band, Soul and Funk, and Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thunder Soul
summary_short: “Thunder Soul” features a Houston high-school music director who turned his school’s band into a celebrated funk institution.

headline: Throwing a Digital-Age Curveball
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moneyball
summary_short: Brad Pitt plays Billy Beane, the baseball executive who challenged traditions of the game, in “Moneyball.”

headline: At Least His Abs Get a Workout
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Abduction
summary_short: Taylor Lautner stars in “Abduction.” There is also a plot, of sorts.

headline: Special Ops Agent, Lured Back From Retirement
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Killer Elite
summary_short: Jason Statham and Robert De Niro portray elite mercenaries in “Killer Elite.”

headline: Finding a New Tail for Winter
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dolphin Tale
summary_short: Morgan Freeman and Nathan Gamble star in “Dolphin Tale,” a film inspired by an actual dolphin rescue.

headline: ‘The Weird World of Blowfly’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Weird World of Blowfly
summary_short: “The Weird World of Blowfly,” traces the musician Clarence Reid’s career as his alter ego Blowfly.

headline: ‘Prince of Swine’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prince of Swine
summary_short: Nell Ruttledge plays a young lawyer on a legal crusade to make a misogynistic producer and his ilk pay for their ways in “Prince of Swine.”

headline: ‘My Afternoons With Margueritte’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Afternoons with Margueritte
summary_short: Gérard Depardieu is the village idiot who is transformed by a literary old woman in “My Afternoons With Margueritte.”

display_title: I Don't Know How She Does It
headline: Even a Things-to-Do List Seems to Be Multitasking
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Don't Know How She Does It
summary_short: In “I Don’t Know How She Does It,” Sarah Jessica Parker portrays a woman who “has it all,” though the movie inadvertently makes her character’s supposedly golden life look like a living hell.

headline: A Veneer to Hide Crumbling Poise
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy, Happy
summary_short: Wearing a satirical smirk, “Happy, Happy” sets out to puncture the clichéd image of Scandinavians as rosy-cheeked choristers bonded in communal togetherness.

headline: Fasten Your Seat Belts, the Chevy Is Taking Off
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drive
summary_short: “Drive,” directed by Nicolas Winding Refn, is about an unnamed virtuoso driver, played by Ryan Gosling, and his Chevy Impala getaway car.

headline: ‘Berlin 36’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Berlin '36
summary_short: “Berlin 36” loosely recounts how the Nazis plotted to keep a Jew off the German Olympic team in 1936.

headline: His Credit Cards and Fancy Words Can’t Help Him Here
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Straw Dogs
summary_short: Rod Lurie’s remake of Sam Peckinpah’s “Straw Dogs” moves the story from England to Mississippi.

headline: Upheaval in a Family That Hopes to Stand Out
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Position Among the Stars
summary_short: Leonard Retel Helmrich’s documentary “Position Among the Stars” completes his trilogy about an Indonesian family.

headline: Music to the Ears of the City Reeling From 9/11
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Love We Make
summary_short: Ten years after the event, “The Love We Make” documents a rock concert in honor of rescue workers.

headline: ‘One Fall’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Fall
summary_short: Marcus Dean Fuller stars in and directed “One Fall,” about a man with who impossibly survives a fall from a cliff and develops healing powers.

headline: A Bollywood Bride, but Who’s the Groom?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mere Brother Ki Dulhan
summary_short: The romantic comedy “My Brother’s Bride” centers on a heroine who is a far cry from her demure sisters of yore.

display_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star
headline: Making the Most of the Very Least, and Other Lessons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star
summary_short: “Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star” follows a dreamer who discovers a physical characteristic that helps make him an unlikely success in pornographic films.

headline: A Tale of Jacob, Esau and Muscles
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Warrior
summary_short: Gavin O’Connor’s “Warrior” follows two estranged brothers who are separately preparing for a mixed martial arts tournament.

headline: A Nightmare Pox on Your Civilized World
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Contagion
summary_short: “Contagion,” Steven Soderbergh’s smart, spooky thriller about contemporary plagues, is a paranoid freakout for the antigovernment, Tea Party age.

headline: Popular Ascendance to Grim Downfall
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu
summary_short: Andrei Ujica’s documentary “The Autobiography of Nicolae Ceausescu” is a cinematic tour de force that tracks the rise, reign and grim fall of that executed Romanian dictator.

headline: From Michigan to Afghanistan, and Back
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Where Soldiers Come From
summary_short: “Where Soldiers Come From” follows young military recruits from Michigan to Afghanistan and back.

headline: Finding Romance in All Kinds of Places
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love In Space
summary_short: Aaron Kwok and René Liu star in the comedy “Love in Space.”

headline: There’s Something Odd About This Hospital
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grave Encounters
summary_short: “Grave Encounters” is a mockumentary set in a familiar setting, a spooky old asylum.

headline: Muslim High School Football Players Stay Close to Home
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fordson: Faith, Fasting, and Football
summary_short: In “Fordson: Faith, Fasting, Football,” Muslim high school players face their crosstown rivals.

headline: Easy Money From Body Parts
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burke and Hare
summary_short: “Burke & Hare,” a ghoulish comedy, is a droll take on one of the most notorious mass-murder cases of the 19th century.

headline: Fear and Loathing at Parker Prep
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beware the Gonzo
summary_short: “Beware the Gonzo,” the feature directorial debut of Bryan Goluboff, follows a student uprising against a high school’s vile clique of alpha teenagers and its smug principal.

headline: Huge Teeth and Teenie-Weenie Bikinis
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shark Night 3D
summary_short: “Shark Night 3D” is the latest entry in the bobbing-and-bloodbath category.

headline: Pay Attention, Houston: We Have Company
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Apollo 18
summary_short: In the science-fiction thriller “Apollo 18,” a secret mission to the Moon turns out to be filled with otherworldly dangers.

display_title: I'm Glad that My Mother is Alive
headline: The Aftershocks of an Adoption Long Ago, Felt by Everyone Involved
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I'm Glad that My Mother is Alive
summary_short: “I’m Glad My Mother Is Alive,” directed by the father-son team of Claude and Nathan Miller, focuses on the psychological profile of a boy who finds the woman who gave him up for adoption.

headline: Robert Duvall Is Back in the Saddle, Playing a Mentor to a Young Golfer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seven Days in Utopia
summary_short: In “Seven Days in Utopia,” an ambitious young professional golfer runs his car onto the property of a weather-beaten rancher.

headline: In the Green Zone, Armed With a Bottle of Hot Sauce
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saving Private Perez
summary_short: Beto Goméz’s “Saving Private Pérez” takes a comedic approach to its underlying theme: what constitutes a hero in today’s Mexico.

headline: A Sly Corporate Dance That Turns Into a Duel
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Crime
summary_short: Alain Corneau’s “Love Crime” works as a devilish satire on power and eros in the executive suite.

headline: In a City’s Plague Years, Caring for Their Own
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Were Here
summary_short: “We Were Here” is an unblinking chronology of the AIDS epidemic, recounted by five people who lived through it and watched countless friends and lovers die.

headline: He’s Always Around, Showing Off His Muscles
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bodyguard
summary_short: In “Bodyguard” the Bollywood star Salman Khan flexes frequently, and the audience goes wild.

headline: Heroic Past Erodes in Present
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Debt
summary_short: Helen Mirren, Tom Wilkinson and Ciaran Hinds play three aging Mossad operatives revisiting their actions during the cold war in John Madden’s latest film, “The Debt.”

headline: Navigating Between Faith and Skepticism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Higher Ground
summary_short: Vera Farmiga stars in this film, her directorial debut, a drama that weighs the merits of faith against a secular sensibility.

headline: She Walks in Beauty, and Brings Along a Bazooka
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Colombiana
summary_short: In “Colombiana,” directed by Olivier Megaton, Zoe Saldana takes her place among big-screen heroines who play very rough.

headline: They Have Coveted Christmas Meat, Now How Do They Eat It in Peace?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tales From the Golden Age
summary_short: “Tales,” overseen by Cristian Mungiu, is a hearty satirical guffaw of gallows humor that illustrates how laughter helped buoy the spirits of an oppressed citizenry.

headline: Joke Is on the Siblings of a Modern Holy Fool
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our Idiot Brother
summary_short: A goofy man-child of a brother ends up exposing the hypocrisy and unhappiness of everyone around him.

display_title: Don't Be Afraid of the Dark
headline: A Renovation Uncovers Nastier Things Than Dust
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Don't Be Afraid of the Dark
summary_short: “Don’t Be Afraid of the Dark” is a reimagining of the 1973 television movie that terrified Guillermo del Toro as a boy.

display_title: Shut Up Little Man! An Audio Misadventure
headline: ‘Shut Up Little Man!’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shut Up Little Man! An Audio Misadventure
summary_short: Matthew Bate’s “Shut Up Little Man!” is a dandy little documentary.

headline: Documentary on Shipbreakers, and Where Tankers Go When They Die
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iron Crows
summary_short: Destruction meets beauty, and optimism meets poverty, in the images and words of the film “Iron Crows.”

display_title: Spy Kids: All The Time in The World
headline: Very Busy Mom Faces a Bigger Mission
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spy Kids: All The Time in The World
summary_short: The fourth “Spy Kids” installment, written and directed, as always, by Robert Rodriguez, introduces a new family.

headline: Powers of Hidden Persuasion
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Programming the Nation?
summary_short: Jeff Warrick’s “Programming the Nation?” takes a jaundiced look at so-called subliminal techniques in advertising and mass media.

headline: Emma and Dex and July 15
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Day
summary_short: “One Day,” directed by Lone Scherfig, follows a man and a woman for more than 20 years, with the action taking place on a single date, July 15, every year.

headline: Those Good, Old Vampires, and Now They’re in 3-D
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fright Night
summary_short: “Fright Night,” directed by Craig Gillespie and a remake of the 1985 vampire film with the same name, takes its time getting to its fiery finish.

headline: Keep Hold of Your Head, Lest He Lop It Off With the Others
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Conan the Barbarian
summary_short: “Conan the Barbarian,” starring Jason Momoa as the title character, delights in gore and swords.

headline: Boxing in the Blood and Bones
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Born and Bred
summary_short: Justin Frimmer’s “Born and Bred” offers a vérité portrait of three young Mexican-American boxers in East Los Angeles.

headline: The Serial-Killer Story Takes a New Twist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Horrible Way to Die
summary_short: Adam Wingard’s “Horrible Way to Die” turns a typical idea into an unexpectedly novel thriller.

headline: A Life Herding Yaks, Modernity on the Horizon
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer Pasture
summary_short: Lynn True, Nelson Walker and Tsering Perlo followed a young family living as Tibetans have for 4,000 years, but aware of the pressures of modern life.

headline: A Brush With Internet Fame
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Damn!
summary_short: “Damn!” is more than just a documentary about a quirky New York gubernatorial candidate.

headline: A TV Host Seeks Fluff, but Real Life Intrudes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story
summary_short: Yousry Nasrallah’s “Scheherazade, Tell Me a Story” resets “The Arabian Nights” in modern-day Cairo.

headline: Death Will Not Be Cheated
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Final Destination 5
summary_short: Few horror cycles are as consistently true to their formulas as “Final Destination 5,” which hits all its marks.

headline: A Town Built for 30
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darwin
summary_short: “Darwin” is Nick Brandestini’s portrait of a tiny California town nestled amid the arid landscapes of Death Valley.

headline: A Tutorial on Tolerance, With Beats and Upbeats
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Glee The 3D Concert Movie
summary_short: “Glee: The 3D Concert Movie” notes just how terrific it is to be yourself.

headline: A Battle for India’s Soul
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aarakshan
summary_short: In “Aarakshan,” a teacher in India battles the hucksters who want to make education a commodity available only to the privileged.

headline: Menu for Trouble: Pizza, a Stripper and Slackers With Weapons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 30 Minutes or Less
summary_short: In “3o Minutes or Less” Jesse Eisenberg plays a pizza delivery man forced into a bank heist by a couple of slackers. It’s supposed to be a comedy.

headline: ‘The Maids’ Now Have Their Say
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Help
summary_short: “The Help,” Tate Taylor’s movie set in civil-rights-era Mississippi, shifts between black maids and their employers.

headline: About That Wish: What if It Came True?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Change-Up
summary_short: In the farcical bromance “The Change-Up,” an uptight corporate lawyer ends up in the body of what used to be called a “toxic bachelor.”

display_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes
headline: Looking Apocalypse in the Eye
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rise of the Planet of the Apes
summary_short: “Rise of the Planet of the Apes” is both an origin story for its 1968 predecessor, “Planet of the Apes,” and an amusingly cheerful film about the end of humanity.

headline: Appeasing Nazis and a Wife
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Protektor
summary_short: In “Protektor,” Jana Plodkova stars as a Jewish starlet in Czechoslovakia worried about her career during the Nazi occupation.

display_title: Magic Trip: Ken Kesey's Search for a Kool Place
headline: Stoned Archive: Wild Ride Of the Merry Pranksters
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Magic Trip: Ken Kesey's Search for a Kool Place
summary_short: Alex Gibney and Alison Ellwood’s documentary “Magic Trip” chronicles the 1964 acid-fueled cross-country bus journey of the author Ken Kesey and his friends.

headline: To the Victors, Vengeance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Habermann
summary_short: “Habermann,” by Juraj Herz, is a wartime soap opera based on the expulsion of ethnic Germans from parts of Europe.

headline: Great Outdoors Beckons as a Test of Manhood
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of True Adolescents
summary_short: Mark Duplass stars in Craig Johnson’s film “True Adolescents,” which explores the sexual discomfort of boys and men not entirely secure in their masculinity.

headline: Blue Travelers in the Big City
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Smurfs
summary_short: “The Smurfs” mixes animation and actors, including Neil Patrick Harris and Hank Azaria, to give characters from the 1980s TV show a New York adventure.

headline: Gay in Amsterdam in the 1980s
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House of Boys
summary_short: In “House of Boys” the director Jean-Claude Schlim looks at coming of age at the onset of AIDS.

headline: Fellowship of the Links
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Golf in the Kingdom
summary_short: “Golf in the Kingdom,” directed by Susan Streitfeld, brings the cult novel by Michael Murphy to the screen.

headline: What’s a Guy to Do if His Wife Cheats on Him? Head to the Mall
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy, Stupid, Love
summary_short: “Crazy, Stupid, Love,” packed with appealing stars, is essentially a study in the varieties of masculine sexual confusion.

headline: Extraterrestrials Land at the O.K. Corral
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cowboys & Aliens
summary_short: In “Cowboys & Aliens,” Daniel Craig rides into the New Mexico Territory and wrangles extraterrestrials that look like cousins of the monsters from the “Alien” films.

headline: Best of All Possible Worlds: When Life Gives You Mud, Take a Mud Bath
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Optimisti
summary_short: “The Optimists” consists of five vignettes, each of whose cynical stories of humble people embracing absurd illusions illustrate the universal impulse to believe in a better future, no matter what.

headline: Grant a Few Rights, See What Happens?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ironclad
summary_short: Paul Giamatti plays King John, who signed the Magna Carta and regretted it, in “Ironclad,” a medieval battle film directed by Jonathan English.

headline: The Horror of Yesterday and the Everyday of Today
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sarah's Key
summary_short: “Sarah’s Key,” directed by Gilles Paquet-Brenner, is an adaptation of a best-selling novel by Tatiana De Rosnay, following a journalist’s investigation into a Holocaust tale.

headline: It’s Just Sex. We’re Just Friends. You Know the Rules. Etc., Etc.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Friends with Benefits
summary_short: Will Gluck’s “Friends With Benefits,” starring Mila Kunis and Justin Timberlake, is a romantic comedy about romantic comedy.

headline: A Look at West Indies Cricket
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fire In Babylon
summary_short: “Fire in Babylon” is a history of the West Indies’ dominance of international cricket in the 1970s and ’80s and the symbolic weight its teams carried in a post-colonial era.

headline: Hey, Brooklyn, Where’d You Get Those Muscles?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captain America: The First Avenger
summary_short: “Captain America,” like its unapologetically corny hero, is propelled by unpretentious and plucky ingenuity.

headline: An Unsatisfying Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Little Help
summary_short: “A Little Help” stars Jenna Fischer as a Long Island dental hygienist whose life is deteriorating around her.

headline: Wishing On, and Seeking Out, a Star
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hollywood to Dollywood
summary_short: In “Hollywood to Dollywood,” Gary and Larry Lane, gay identical twins, travel from Los Angeles to the Dollywood theme park in Pigeon Forge, Tenn.

headline: Hundred Acre Gang Is Back in Town
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Winnie the Pooh
summary_short: This “Winnie the Pooh” has no bells and whistles: it is comfortable with itself and confident in its ability to amuse and beguile young viewers.

headline: An Evangelist, an Atheist and an Act That Tests Faith
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Salvation Boulevard
summary_short: The accidental shooting of an atheist professor puts a former Deadhead turned man of faith at odds with his church.

display_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2
headline: Class Dismissed
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2
summary_short: Childhood ends with tears and howls and swirls of smoke, the shock of mortality and bittersweet smiles in the grave, deeply satisfying final movie in the “Harry Potter” series.

headline: No Sleep for a Beauty Who Seeks Adventure
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sleeping Beauty
summary_short: In Catherine Breillat’s “Sleeping Beauty” the princess doesn’t fall into a 100-year slumber, she hits the road for some adventure.

headline: Government Oversight in Farming
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Farmageddon
summary_short: In the documentary “Farmageddon,” Kristin Canty seeks to show that agribusiness is employing government agencies to harass independent farmers.

headline: Dating Tips From Friends at the Zoo? Of Courserous
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Zookeeper
summary_short: Rejection makes the heart more likely to seek advice from trusted friends in “Zookeeper,” a movie about relationships of the platonic and romantic kind.

headline: A Treatise on Issues of the Workplace. Not.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Horrible Bosses
summary_short: In “Horrible Bosses,” a foul-mouthed and frequently funny new comedy of male resentment directed by Seth Gordon, employees plot revenge.

headline: Amid War, Fierce Adversaries of the Creepy-Crawly Variety
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flying Fish
summary_short: The Sri Lankan filmmaker Sanjeewa Pushpakumara’s debut feature, “Flying Fish,” follows three largely unconnected stories of civilians struggling in his war-torn country.

headline: Swimming in Blood
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cold Fish
summary_short: Sion Sono’s “Cold Fish” is a deliciously warped wallow in misogyny, depravity and manipulation.

headline: Seeking a Path to Justice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crime After Crime
summary_short: “Crime After Crime” favors the personal over the political, creating a no-frills portrait of a stoic and remarkably unembittered woman.

headline: Stymied in Middle Age, Reaching for a New Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Larry Crowne
summary_short: In “Larry Crowne” Tom Hanks and Julia Roberts are grown-ups who more or less act their age as they overcome monetary and emotional setbacks.

headline: Cinderella Goes to Europe, and Cute Meets Culture
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monte Carlo
summary_short: In “Monte Carlo,” Selena Gomez plays a Texas Francophile who travels to France and Monte Carlo with her eager friend and reluctant older stepsister.

headline: Exploring Love’s True Nature
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Etc.
summary_short: “Love Etc.” tries to explore the true nature of love in the city through the lives of eight New Yorkers.

headline: Indian Cinema With an Indie Sensibility
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delhi Belly
summary_short: Starting with the pride of place given the digestive problem of the title, “Delhi Belly” thumbs its nose at propriety.

headline: When Fools Rush In
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Double Dhamaal
summary_short: “Double Dhamaal” is a mind-contracting Hindi comedy that seems to take its cues from the Three Stooges, the Keystone Kops and every Bollywood cliché it can chew up and spit back as farce.

headline: Following in the Shadows of a Very Shadowy Man
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aurora
summary_short: Cristi Puiu stars in and directs “Aurora,” an enigmatic feature about human relations in present-day Romania.

headline: One Small Step for Man, One Giant Leap for Autobots
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transformers: Dark of the Moon
summary_short: “Transformers: Dark of the Moon” is among Michael Bay’s best movies and by far the best 3-D sequel ever made about gigantic toys from outer space.

headline: Bystanders to China’s Transition
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beijing Taxi
summary_short: The filmmaker Miao Wang follows three cabbies in “Beijing Taxi,” her documentary about working-class Chinese life.

headline: A Mission to See
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vincent Wants to Sea
summary_short: Clinical disorders are just unredeemed tickets to self-realization in “Vincent Wants to Sea.”

headline: Chinese History, Straight From the Source
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jian guo da ye
summary_short: Filmed for the Communist Party’s 90th anniversary in China, “Beginning of the Great Revival” has battles but little blood.

headline: The Call of the Wild, Heeded With Tenacity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Turtle: The Incredible Journey
summary_short: In “Turtle,” the loggerhead, a threatened species, embarks on a quarter-century life voyage, a trip that covers thousands of miles and is fraught with life-and-death dangers.

headline: Of Spirituality and a Quest for Romance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Raw Faith
summary_short: The documentary “Raw Faith” features two things seldom seen on a movie screen: spirituality that doesn’t sound maniacal, and older adults who are exploring romance.

headline: Sidekick Tries to Tow a Sequel
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cars 2
summary_short: Mater the tow truck, voiced by Larry the Cable Guy, is front and center in Pixar’s new four-wheeled adventure.

headline: Bridging Loneliness in Mexico City
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leap Year
summary_short: “Leap Year” is a slow flare of emotional agony that follows Laura, a freelance writer, and her one-night stands.

headline: When the Teacher Gets High Marks in the Raunchy and the Profane
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Teacher
summary_short: Cameron Diaz has found her down-and-dirty element in “Bad Teacher,” a broad comedy that threatens to get ugly and more or less succeeds on that threat.

headline: A Couple United in Self-Absorption
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Love Affair of Sorts
summary_short: “A Love Affair of Sorts” is a critique of what we already know so well: we’re self-absorbed and shallow.

headline: Life in the Big House: The Danish Experience
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of R
summary_short: The Danish drama “R,” set in a maximum-security prison, isn’t the goriest example of its genre, but it is challenging nevertheless.

headline: In Brooklyn, Pushing Back Against a Redevelopment Plan
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle for Brooklyn
summary_short: “Battle for Brooklyn,” a documentary by Michael Galinsky and Suki Hawley, chronicles the Atlantic Yards project and the work of a resident who has fought against it.

headline: Allergic to Homework and Possibly Smitten
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Art of Getting By

headline: A Frankenstein Story for the Digital Age
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Teknolust
summary_short: A minor addition to the tiny genre of feminist science fiction films, "Teknolust" is a benign, digital-age Frankenstein story about a mousy genetic research scientist, Rosetta Stone (the stunning Tilda Swinton, struggling to look plain by donning a curly wig and oversized glasses), who uses her own DNA to create three color-coded clones.  Written and directed by Lynn Hershman Leeson, who guided Ms. Swinton to a more effective performance in the 1998 "Conceiving Ada," "Teknolust" has a lot on its mind but little on the ball when it comes to transforming thematic notions into dramatic concepts.  The most aggressive of the clones, Ruby, becomes infatuated with an irritatingly incompetent copy shop employee (ok, we got it) played by the perpetually twitchy Jeremy Davies.  Love, it seems, will help her to become real, like some sort of hormonally charged Pinocchio.  There's some potential for entertainment here, but Ms. Leeson's emphatic direction draws much of the fun from the comedy elements.  Even Ms. Swinton, usually the most restrained and elegant of performers, can be found mugging outrageously as she strains to put over the less-than-convulsive laugh lines. — Dave Kehr

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen

headline: In the Beginning, God Created Yuks
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Year One
summary_short: Harold Ramis’s “Year One” is a thoroughly, sometimes gaggingly broad and sly conceptual laugh-in.

headline: Ticked Off
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under Our Skin
summary_short: “Under Our Skin” is scary enough to make the faint of heart decide never to venture into the woods or to lie on the grass again without protective covering.

headline: From the Corporate Jungle to Wild Alaska: Taming the Savage Boss
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Proposal
summary_short: Like most Hollywood romantic comedies these days, “The Proposal” is all about bringing a woman to her knees.

headline: Making a Living Handling Death
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Departures
summary_short: “Departures” is overlong, predictable in its plotting and utterly banal in its blending of comic whimsy and melodramatic pathos.

headline: Marry in Haste, Repent at Decaying Castle With Possessive Mater
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Easy Virtue
summary_short: In its cold-eyed assessment of the English aristocracy “Easy Virtue” has none of the lurking Anglophilia found in Merchant-Ivory movies.

headline: My Brother, My Partner in Crime
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brothers Bloom
summary_short: “The Brothers Bloom” is the movie equivalent of an elaborate juggling act whose performers keep dozens of pins wheeling in the air.

headline: A Documentary Filmmaker Who Turned the Camera on Himself
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Windmill Movie
summary_short: “The Windmill Movie” is a version of the autobiography of Richard P. Rogers that might have been.

headline: Stand Clear of the Closing Doors
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Taking of Pelham 123
summary_short: “The Taking of Pelham 1 2 3,” an energetic updating of the 1974 mass transit thriller, takes account of how much the character of New York has changed.

headline: French Political Thriller as Allegory, but There’s a Bazooka in the Closet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Le Combat dans l'ile
summary_short: “Le Combat dans l’Île” is the latest in what seems to be an endless parade of obscure or half-forgotten French films to find their way to Film Forum.

headline: Parties and Pain
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last International Playboy
summary_short: Grown men behaving like emotional infants are seldom fun to be around, a truism that “The Last International Playboy” does nothing to disprove.

headline: Up in the Air
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blast!
summary_short: “Blast!” is about a bunch of nerds in Sweden mucking about with an unfathomable contraption attached to a hot air balloon.

headline: What They Did for Work (Love, Too)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Every Little Step
summary_short: In “Every Little Step,” life imitates art, art reflects life, and the distinctions threaten, quite pleasantly, to blur altogether.

headline: My Big Fat Crowded Athens Tour Bus
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Life in Ruins
summary_short: “My Life in Ruins,” Nia Vardalos’s first movie in five years, might as well be titled “How Georgia Got Her Kefi Back.”

headline: Trapped Way Back in Time With a Bunch of Dopey Dinosaurs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Land of the Lost
summary_short: The only marginally interesting, if unsurprising, thing about “Land of the Lost” is that a lot of money has been spent on yet another cultural throwaway.

headline: Terror Outside the Ring
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kassim the Dream
summary_short: The documentary “Kassim the Dream” recounts the unusual life story of the boxer Kassim Ouma.

headline: Dudes Doing Vegas: Eating and Other Stuff
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hangover
summary_short: In “The Hangover,” Bradley Cooper, Ed Helms and Zach Galifianakis incarnate familiar masculine stereotypes in ways that manage to be moderately fresh.

headline: Sorting Out an Inheritance: Three Siblings Dissect the Stuff of Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summer Hours
summary_short: “Summer Hours,” in spite of its potentially dowdy subject matter, is packed nearly to bursting with rich meaning and deep implication.

headline: Mud and Guts
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drag Me to Hell
summary_short: “Drag Me to Hell” has a tonic playfulness that’s unabashedly retro, an indulgent return to Sam Raimi’s goofy, gooey roots.

headline: The House That Soared
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Up
summary_short: In its opening stretch the new Pixar movie “Up” flies high, borne aloft by a sense of creative flight and a flawlessly realized love story.

display_title: Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian
headline: Dad’s at Another Museum. Does That Make Him an Exhibitionist?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian
summary_short: The paradox of “Night at the Museum: Battle of the Smithsonian” is that a movie so bursting with novelty can feel so utterly familiar.

headline: Step Up but Stand Clear of the Guy in the Fat Suit
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dance Flick
summary_short: The belly laughs in “Dance Flick” leave you feeling liberated and not guilty.

headline: Heavy Metal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Terminator Salvation
summary_short: “Terminator Salvation” feels both comfortable with its limitations and justly proud of its accomplishments.

headline: When Love Registers at a Motel, Send Wine
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Management
summary_short: “Management” is a sweet-natured comedy that refuses to obey the commercial dictates of Hollywood by allowing its characters to determine their own zany destinies.

headline: Holy Mystery! Mayhem at the Vatican
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Angels & Demons
summary_short: “Angels & Demons,” without being particularly good, is nonetheless far less hysterical than “The Da Vinci Code.”

headline: How the Ball Bounces, on the Field and Off
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rudo y Cursi
summary_short: In “Rudo y Cursi,” two brothers struggle with fame, wealth and the caprices of life in a media-saturated consumer culture.

headline: Violence Embodied in a Boxer’s Rise and Fall
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyson
summary_short: Mike Tyson describes the murderous clarity he carried into the ring in “Tyson.”

headline: Magician’s Twisting Road Comes to Bittersweet End
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Is Anybody There?
summary_short: Michael Caine uses his dramatic powers as an aging magician in “Is Anybody There?”

headline: Tracing Scars From Wounds to a Minority
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Being Jewish in France
summary_short: Yves Jeuland’s documentary “Being Jewish in France” is more than three hours long, and its emotional peak comes relatively early.

headline: A Story of Hardship and Hope
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revue
summary_short: “Revue” melds disparate images of Soviet life during the 1950s and ’60s into a luminous time capsule of patriotic fervor and political fealty.

headline: A Franchise Goes Boldly Backward
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Star Trek
summary_short: The latest spinoff from the influential TV show is a testament to television’s power as mythmaker.

headline: Blaxploitation Returns
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Next Day Air
summary_short: With a script that snaps and characters that pop, “Next Day Air” nears neo-blaxploitation perfection.

headline: Portrait of a Fashion King: Palazzos, Pugs and Peons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valentino: The Last Emperor
summary_short: Watching “Valentino: The Last Emperor” is a little like gorging on chocolate and Champagne.

headline: A Patagonian Dream of a Day at the End of a Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Window
summary_short: Portentous dreams infiltrate the Argentine director Carlos Sorín’s film “The Window.”

headline: Two Men on the Road, Together and Yet Alone
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eldorado
summary_short: “Eldorado” is a road movie that poignantly juggles absurdism and melancholy.

headline: Planetary Peril
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle for Terra
summary_short: In this 3-D animated space picture, humans invade a peace-loving planet populated by squiggly beings.

headline: I, Mutant, Red in Face and Claw
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of X-Men Origins: Wolverine
summary_short: “X-Men Origins: Wolverine,” with its ungainly, geeky title and its relatively trim running time, helps explain just what makes this guy so intriguing and unusual.

headline: Cold, Hard Science
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ice People
summary_short: This reserved, tough-minded documentary sinks something of the feel and routine of a scientific expedition into your bones.

headline: He Loved Too Often but Not Wisely
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghosts of Girlfriends Past
summary_short: “Ghosts of Girlfriends Past” is a junky-looking romantic comedy that’s neither remotely romantic nor passably comic.

headline: Happily Married, but Still a Stalker’s Perfect Target
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Obsessed
summary_short: “Obsessed,” a clanking, low-rent imitation of “Fatal Attraction,” lacks both the original film’s imagination and moral ambiguity.

headline: Struggle and Rescue, a Duet in Sharps and Minors
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Soloist
summary_short: Some of the lost souls in “The Soloist,” a big studio movie about a one-man rescue mission, look as thin as the crack pipes clamped between their lips.

headline: Back to the ’80s, for Assorted Hookups in a Wasteland of Privilege
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Informers
summary_short: The main characters in “The Informers” are not so much characters as symbols of, well, of some pretty bad stuff.

headline: Birmingham Brawler in the Big City
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fighting
summary_short: You might expect a movie called “Fighting” to be a blunt, literal affair, and in the case of Dito Montiel’s new film, you would not be wrong.

headline: Diamond in the Rough
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sugar
summary_short: “Sugar” is infused with a deep affection for baseball, the rhythms of which are captured by a narrative pace and editing style that quicken and relax as necessary.

headline: He Might Lack a Ticker, but He’s Still a Time Bomb
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crank: High Voltage
summary_short: “Crank: High Voltage,” starring Jason Statham as a man with a machine instead of a heart, is boorish, bigoted and borderline pornographic.

headline: Fighting Injustice in Small-Town Texas
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Violet
summary_short: “American Violet,” which is based on real events that took place in late 2000, has the quasi-documentary feel of a well-made television drama.

headline: Those Cheekbones! That Wind-Swept Hair! OMG, It’s Zac Efron!
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 17 Again
summary_short: An adult transforms into his teen idol, er, adolescent self in “17 Again.”

headline: The News on Paper, and Other Artifacts
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of State of Play
summary_short: The chance to explore the swiftly changing culture of Web-age journalism is one of several intriguing possibilities that “State of Play” squanders.

headline: Desperate Lives Crisscross in Train-Hopping Journey
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sin Nombre
summary_short: The caressing, honeyed light in “Sin Nombre” beautifies and softens every ugly moment in this equivocating story about geographic and moral border crossings.

headline: Bonding Amid Blood Splatters: Two Sisters and Their Messy Lives
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sunshine Cleaning
summary_short: A better title for “Sunshine Cleaning,” directed by Christine Jeffs from a script by Megan Holley, would be “Sundance Recycling.”

headline: A Happy Ersatz Family, in a Yurt
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hyazgar
summary_short: Silence, interrupted only by the periodic violent howls of the wind and animal mewls and bleats, pervades the otherworldly landscape of “Desert Dream.”

headline: Possess Glittery Magic Orb, Do Martial Arts, Save World
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dragonball Evolution
summary_short: “Dragonball” has been perfectly designed to blow the mind of a 10-year-old boy.

headline: A Dark Glimpse From Eddie Adams’s Camera
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An Unlikely Weapon
summary_short: Like many documentaries about talented people who did important things during amazing times, “An Unlikely Weapon: The Eddie Adams Story” tends to fall into repetitive fawning.

headline: Mall Crisis? Call Security. Then Again, Maybe Not.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Observe and Report
summary_short: If you thought Abu Ghraib was a laugh riot then you might love “Observe and Report.”

headline: OMG! Hannah on the Big Screen
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Montana: The Movie
summary_short: Does “Hannah Montana: The Movie” translate well from television?

headline: Old-Timer Has Fans Falling at His Feet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Buck Howard
summary_short: “The Great Buck Howard” is an agreeable show business satire with a warm heart.

headline: Lesser-Known Mobsters, as Brutal as the Old Ones
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gomorrah
summary_short: “Gomorrah” is a corrosive and ferociously unsentimental fictional look at Italian organized crime.

headline: Humble Hope in Hard Times
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pope's Toilet
summary_short: “The Pope’s Toilet” cloaks religious critique in the scrappy tempo of irremediable poverty and irrepressible enterprise.

headline: Fictional Realities
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forbidden Lie$
summary_short: Cool-headed, lighthearted and outrageously entertaining, “Forbidden Lie$” is documentary-as-striptease.

headline: Coming of Age on the Midway
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adventureland
summary_short: The story of a young man’s coming of age never gets old, at least when it is told with the kind of sweetness and intelligence “Adventureland” displays.

headline: Fraught Family Dynamics
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lifelines
summary_short: Written and directed by Rob Margolies, “Lifelines” starts promisingly, but soon gives way to a compressed, schematic psychodrama endemic.

headline: Burning Rubber One More Time
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fast & Furious
summary_short: This example of presummer pop diversion will be best appreciated by future audiences flabbergasted by its unabashed revelry in fossil-fuel consumption.

headline: Criminal Takes Policeman on Big-City Scavenger Hunt
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 12 Rounds
summary_short: Renny Harlin’s “12 Rounds” satisfies, on the most primitive level, the expectations for a second-rate action flick.

headline: Life Lessons Learned in Bucolic Classrooms
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Country Teacher
summary_short: The film’s portrayal of farm life as a rugged pastorale lends “The Country Teacher” a foundation of visceral truth.

headline: 3-D Fun With a Beefed-Up Bride and a Dumb Blob Named B.O.B.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monsters vs. Aliens
summary_short: “Monsters vs. Aliens” cheerfully converts two major sources of cinematic terror into wacky, goofy, familiar figures.

headline: A Family Plot
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Haunting in Connecticut
summary_short: “The Haunting in Connecticut” gives you the creeps, the giggles and the groans in almost equal measure.

headline: Effervescent Espionage With Two Irresistible Forces
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Duplicity
summary_short: However you describe it, “Duplicity” is superior entertainment, the most elegantly pleasurable movie of its kind to come around in a very long time.

headline: 20-something Sloth and Larceny
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skills Like This
summary_short: “Skills Like This” gazes indulgently on 20-something aimlessness and the comfort of assigned roles.

headline: Best Man Wanted. Must Be Rush Fan.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Love You, Man
summary_short: “I Love You, Man” is a fitfully funny comedy that owes much to Judd Apatow.

headline: Extinction Looms! Stop the Aliens!
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knowing
summary_short: With “Knowing,” it’s probably not a good sign when, at a screening, spectacles of mass death and intimations of planetary destruction are met with hoots and giggles.

headline: In Deepest Brooklyn, Affairs of the Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Two Lovers
summary_short: Though it is set in the present, “Two Lovers” takes place in what often feels like an earlier incarnation of New York.

display_title: The Last House on the Left
headline: Death’s Door
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last House on the Left
summary_short: “The Last House on the Left” is a study of operatic vengeance and dueling family values.

headline: One Wish Before Dying, but Plenty of Obstacles
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cake Eaters
summary_short: In “The Cake Eaters” superior acting elevates a small, overcrowded ensemble piece set in rural upstate New York into something a little deeper.

headline: Save the Cute Little Extraterrestrials! Save the Earth!
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Race to Witch Mountain
summary_short: Such folks will not find much to groove on in “Race to Witch Mountain, ” but it will amuse some of their young counterparts until summertime.

headline: Centerfold Sentiments
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss March
summary_short: Mostly“Miss March” feels tame, right down to the film’s softhearted message of true love.

headline: Learning to Be the Future of France
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Class
summary_short: The young bodies crowding “The Class,” an artful, intelligent movie, come in all sizes, shapes and colors.

headline: Guitars, Whores and Sin: The World of the Fadista
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fados
summary_short: “Fados” is Carlos Saura’s big-screen film about the musical genre that is the soul music of Portugal.

headline: For a Cold War, a Blue Superhero (and Friends)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Watchmen
summary_short: Zack Snyder’s film version of “Watchmen” is a grim and grisly excursion into comic-book mythology.

headline: A Preppy and a Shaggy Dog
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sherman's Way
summary_short: Like an annoying new puppy, “Sherman’s Way” just wants to run around in circles and lick your face. After a while, though, you kind of fall in love with it.

headline: Connecting Narratives, Neighbors and Souls
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Explicit Ills
summary_short: In “Explicit Ills,” the director, Mark Webber, doesn’t immediately reveal the story’s structure or his intentions.

headline: New Girl Comes to Town: Cue Adolescent Dramatics
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Beautiful Person
summary_short: “La Belle Personne,” directed by Christophe Honoré, combines an earnest respect for literature with a romantic, pop sensibility.

headline: Four-Legged Survivors of Hurricane Katrina
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mine
summary_short: One from the heart, the documentary “Mine” relates yet one more wrenching, infuriating story about Hurricane Katrina.

headline: A Documentary Gives ‘Going to the Mat’ New Meaning
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enlighten Up!
summary_short: “Enlighten Up!” explores its subject with a light touch and welcome sense of humor.

display_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
headline: Looking for Her Father, Finding New Targets for Her Feet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li
summary_short: Daddies and daughters lend a wistful emotional core to “Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li,” an otherwise generic martial-arts movie with video-game credentials.

headline: In the Jonas Brothers Dimension
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience
summary_short: “Jonas Brothers: The 3D Concert Experience” isn’t a movie so much as a devotional object, a kind of secular fetish designed to induce rapture.

headline: All About Robert Blecker
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Robert Blecker Wants Me Dead
summary_short: “Robert Blecker Wants Me Dead,” a documentary by Ted Schillinger, goes to the heart of the death penalty debate.

headline: Three Wise Men, Bumbling Their Way to Bethlehem
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Cant dels ocells
summary_short: The lovely and strange “Birdsong” (“El Cant dels Ocells”) is less a retelling of the Nativity story than a dream about it.

display_title: Tyler Perry's Madea Goes to Jail
headline: Plus-Size Matriarch’s Stretch in the Slammer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's Madea Goes to Jail
summary_short: The best parts of “Madea Goes to Jail” are the title character’s motormouthed harangues. The rest of it is a fairly clumsy tale of sin and redemption.

headline: Teenage Boys in Pursuit of Pompoms
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fired Up!
summary_short: “Fired Up!” is at once funnier than it should be and more witless than it should have been.

headline: A Broken Soul Wandering Aimlessly on the Long Path to Redemption
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I've Loved You So Long
summary_short: In the drama “I’ve Loved You So Long,” Kristin Scott Thomas’s furious honesty rules out easy, unearned redemption.

headline: Oceans of Fun
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Under the Sea 3D
summary_short: No computer-designed animatronic invention can begin to match the beauty and grace of the oceanic life photographed in “Under the Sea 3D.”

headline: A Slice of Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Friday the 13th
summary_short: The undying “Friday the 13th” franchise gets a surprisingly decent reboot in this stylish, playful example of the decapitated hottie genre.

headline: A Bank That Specializes in Payback (and Not the Kind With Interest)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The International
summary_short: “The International,” a sleek travelogue thriller, at least flirts with timeliness, winking at an angry and anxious public mood.

headline: When Retail Therapy Can’t Cure What Ails You
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Confessions of a Shopaholic
summary_short: Like the flailing American economy, “Confessions of a Shopaholic” wants to eat its cake and have its spiritual redemption too. (Talk about timing!)

headline: Cornered in a Parallel World
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coraline
summary_short: “Coraline” lingers in an atmosphere that is creepy, wonderfully strange and full of feeling.

headline: Special Abilities
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Push
summary_short: Imaginatively filmed by Peter Sova, “Push” has a dizzying, chaotic energy that pulls you along.

headline: For Inspector Clouseau, That Diamond Is Forever
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pink Panther 2
summary_short: Hoary slapstick routines, invariably rushed, are all there is in “The Pink Panther 2.”

headline: Restoring a Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life. Support. Music.
summary_short: If you can get past the excruciating title, “Life. Support. Music.” is a blessedly nimble journey from loss to reclamation.

display_title: He's Just Not That Into You
headline: Young Women Forever Stuck at Square One in the Dating Game
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of He's Just Not That Into You
summary_short: Imagine an action flick in which the hero spends the entire movie chasing the villain without the satisfaction of smashing his enemy to smithereens.

headline: Two Bickering Sisters, a Stepmom and an Ominous Garbage Can
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Uninvited
summary_short: “The Uninvited” sounds like the name of a generic horror movie, which is more or less what it is.

headline: Tales of a Spike-Heeled Dialoguer in a Land of Okey-Dokeys
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of New in Town
summary_short: The flat romantic comedy “New in Town” has no idea of how to play its cards.

headline: Vigilante Daddy Avenges Kidnapping
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taken
summary_short: “Taken” starts in low gear and almost immediately stalls out.

headline: Ill-Fated Romance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Between Love & Goodbye
summary_short: “Between Love & Goodbye” tells of the ill-fated romance between a pair of East Village transplants with 2 percent body fat, zero personality and even less chemistry.

headline: Hard Knocks, Both Given and Gotten
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wrestler
summary_short: “The Wrestler” shows that, in both movies and wrestling, the line between reality and play-acting may be less clear than we assume.

headline: Innocence Is Lost in Postwar Germany
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Reader
summary_short: “The Reader” is a scrupulously tasteful film about an erotic affair that turns to love.

headline: Freedom Fighter in Life Becomes Potent Symbol in Death
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Milk
summary_short: Harvey Milk was an intriguing, inspiring figure. And “Milk” is a marvel.

headline: Grief Leads to a Journey in a World of Whimsy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Toe Tactic
summary_short: Depending on your tolerance for relentless whimsy and unflagging eccentricity, “The Toe Tactic” will make you gurgle with delight or groan with exasperation.

display_title: Blessed Is the Match: The Life and Death of Hannah Senesh
headline: War Hero and Martyr in the Prime of Her Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blessed Is the Match: The Life and Death of Hannah Senesh
summary_short: Roberta Grossman’s “Blessed Is the Match: The Life and Death of Hannah Senesh” documents courage, but steers clear of character.

headline: Saluting the Rebel Underneath the T-Shirt
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Che: Part Two
summary_short: Nearly four and a half hours long, spanning more than a decade and reconstructing a pair of brutal insurgencies, “Che” surely deserves the name of epic.

headline: The Americans Arrive and Cultures Collide
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of California Dreamin'
summary_short: “California Dreamin’ ” is a rambunctious, closely observed comedy of cultural collision.

headline: Clash of the Monsters: The Origins of a Feud
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Underworld: Rise of the Lycans
summary_short: “Underworld: Rise of the Lycans,” a prehistory to the first two “Underworld” movies, rewinds to when the werewolves rebelled against their vampire masters.

headline: Novel’s Characters Leap From the Page, Literally
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Inkheart
summary_short: “Inkheart,” a muddled film adaptation of a children’s best seller by Cornelia Funke, celebrates the magic of books, but it can also be taken as a cautionary tale.

headline: Two Faces in the Crowd, Raging Against the Crab Grass
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revolutionary Road
summary_short: “Revolutionary Road,” a waxworks edition of the furiously unsentimental novel by Richard Yates, tracks the unraveling of a handsome young suburban couple in the 1950s.

headline: Mr. Frost, Meet Mr. Nixon
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frost/Nixon
summary_short: It’s twinkle versus glower in the big-screen edition of Peter Morgan’s theatrical smackdown “Frost/Nixon.”

headline: Pictures More Influential Than Words
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Photograph
summary_short: In “The Photograph,” an unlikely friendship eases an old man’s death and a young woman’s life.

display_title: Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms
headline: Where Guns Fall From the Sky
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms
summary_short: “Dealing and Wheeling in Small Arms” is a depressing, scattershot survey of the spread of weaponry around the world, especially in Africa.

headline: Watch Out for That Pickax; It’s Hurtling From the Screen
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Bloody Valentine
summary_short: A strange synergy of old and new, “My Bloody Valentine 3D” blends cutting-edge technology and old-school prosthetics to produce something both familiar and alien: gore you can believe in.

headline: Sometimes Groucho’s Cigar Is Not Just a Cigar
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pervert's Guide to Cinema
summary_short: In “The Pervert’s Guide to Cinema,” the Slovenian philosopher Slavoj Zizek subjects more than 40 mostly classic films to psychoanalytic scrutiny.

headline: An Elderly Loner Seeks Distraction
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sublet
summary_short: Bad as it is, nothing in “The Sublet” warrants derision — nor, to be frank, your time.

headline: A Hapless Security Guard Runs Amok
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paul Blart: Mall Cop
summary_short: Fat people are funny. Fat people who fall over are funnier. Fat people who fall over and have humiliating working-class jobs? Stop, you’re killing me!

headline: A Rapper’s Tale, Larger Than Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Notorious
summary_short: Anyone looking for a dispassionate, evenhanded account of the life of Biggie Smalls will be disappointed, perhaps even dismayed, by “Notorious.”

headline: A Tale of Love and Liberation (Puppy and Otherwise)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hotel for Dogs
summary_short: “Hotel for Dogs” is a cuter-than-cute, sweeter-than-sweet family film about animal-loving kids who embark on a crusade to rescue all the stray pooches in a fictional city.

headline: A Kung Fu Extravaganza
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chandni Chowk to China
summary_short: “Chandni Chowk to China” seamlessly adds kung fu to the usual blend of comedy, dance and melodrama.

headline: A Society in the Forest, Banding Together to Escape Persecution
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Defiance
summary_short: Edward Zwick’s stiff, musclebound new movie tells the true story of the Bielski partisans, who fought the Nazis and rescued hundreds of Jews through the darkest years of war and genocide.

headline: The Clock You Hear? It’s Not Big Ben, Buddy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Chance Harvey
summary_short: There’s something irresistible about watching two people fall in love, even in contrived, sniffle- and sometimes gag-inducing films like “Last Chance Harvey.”

display_title: Testament: The Bible in Animation - Jonah
headline: In Mozambique, a Road to Self-Discovery
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Testament: The Bible in Animation - Jonah
summary_short: With “Sleepwalking Land,” the filmmaker Teresa Prata creates an affecting portrait of life during wartime.

headline: Star Log: Trippy Sci-Fi Mash-Up Alert!
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mock Up on Mu
summary_short: By turns absorbing, confounding, exhausting and altogether stranger than most fiction, “Mock Up on Mu” comes close to defying categorization.

headline: Playing at Life With Dad’s Loaded Dice, at Home and in Las Vegas
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yonkers Joe
summary_short: “Yonkers Joe” tells the story of a card sharp with guilt pangs and his 20-year-old son with Down syndrome.

headline: Mengele, the Holocaust and Horror Movie Staples
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unborn
summary_short: In “The Unborn,” a young woman attracts creepy bugs and a demonic spirit.

headline: Under the Microscope: A Marriage Sorely Tested
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Not Easily Broken
summary_short: “Not Easily Broken” presents a world in which women no longer regard men as heroes.

headline: Two Weddings and a Furor
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bride Wars
summary_short: Do Hollywood studio executives think that women have a gene for tulle? Neural receptors just for Vera Wang? I wondered this as I was watching “Bride Wars.”

headline: Hope for a Racist, and Maybe a Country
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gran Torino
summary_short: “Gran Torino” shows an urgent engagement with the tougher, messier, bigger questions of American life.

headline: There She Is, Miss ... Well, Actually, It’s Mr.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pageant
summary_short: “Pageant” goes behind the scenes, dreams, breakdowns, freakouts, sequins, glitter and fabulous falsies of the Miss Gay America pageant.

display_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
headline: It’s the Age of a Child Who Grows From a Man
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Curious Case of Benjamin Button
summary_short: “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button” sighs with longing and simmers with intrigue while investigating the philosophical conundrums and emotional paradoxes of its protagonist’s condition.

headline: Mission Imperative: Assassinate the Führer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Valkyrie
summary_short: “Valkyrie” transforms World War II into a boy’s adventure.

headline: Returned From the Dead, Ducking Villains and Vixens
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Spirit
summary_short: What is most striking about “The Spirit” is how little pleasure it affords, in spite of its efforts to be sly, sexy, heartfelt and clever all at once.

headline: Going to the Dog and Getting a Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marley & Me
summary_short: To watch “Marley & Me” is to tune in to an era that seems so close and yet so distant.

headline: Once Upon a Time, There Was a Resentful Handyman Who Agreed to Baby-Sit
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bedtime Stories
summary_short: In “Bedtime Stories” the pain of this artistic limbo is written all over Adam Sandler’s character, a resentful hotel handyman named Skeeter.

headline: Between Heaven and Earth, Room for Ambiguity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doubt
summary_short: The air is thick with paranoia in “Doubt,” but nowhere as thick, juicy, sustained or sustaining as Meryl Streep’s performance.

headline: Orphan’s Lifeline Out of Hell Could Be a Game Show in Mumbai
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Slumdog Millionaire
summary_short: A gaudy, gorgeous rush of color, sound and motion, “Slumdog Millionaire” doesn’t travel through the lower depths, it giddily bounces from one horror to the next.

headline: Nowhere Man, Listen Up: You Have to Stop Saying No
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yes Man
summary_short: “Yes Man” is too sluggish and slapdash a vehicle for its star’s prodigious wackiness.

headline: Killer Soup, and a Mouse to the Rescue
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Tale of Despereaux
summary_short: “Despereaux” is a pleasantly immersive, beautifully animated, occasionally sleepy tale.

headline: An I.R.S. Do-Gooder and Other Strangeness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seven Pounds
summary_short: “Seven Pounds” may be among the most transcendently, eye-poppingly, crazily awful motion pictures ever made.

display_title: Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic
headline: Mixing Art and Science to Get Doomsday
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic
summary_short: The enthralling documentary “Wonders Are Many: The Making of Doctor Atomic” follows the creation of a lofty operatic collaboration.

headline: Forlorn Husband Makes the Right Moves
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rab Ne Bana Di Jodi
summary_short: “Rab Ne Bana di Jodi” deftly blends comedy — the ruling tone of the new Bollywood — with melodrama, the ruling tone of the old.

display_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still
headline: It’s All Over, Earthlings (Don’t Flee to New Jersey)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Day the Earth Stood Still
summary_short: In “The Day the Earth Stood Still,” the alien Klaatu has a mission: to help exterminate the human race.

headline: Seasonal Sentiment With Latin Flavoring
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nothing Like the Holidays
summary_short: “Nothing Like the Holidays” is an efficient home-for-Christmas ensemble comedy trimmed with plastic teardrops.

headline: Something Rotten in the State of Jhamora (Ask Freddie Prinze Jr.)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delgo
summary_short: This barely animated love story suffers from more than just a lack of originality. Dreary battles and apathetic voice work conspire in a sedition-oriented plot that not even six writers are able to invigorate.

headline: Treated Like a Dog, in War and Madness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adam Resurrected
summary_short: Jeff Goldblum’s tour-de-force performance is not enough to transmit a steady emotional current through “Adam Resurrected.”

headline: Pale Boy and Pale Vampire in a Still, Wintry Landscape
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let the Right One In
summary_short: “Let the Right One In” takes the morbid unhappiness of its young characters seriously.

headline: A Writer and Speaker Specializing in Everything
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doc
summary_short: “Doc,” a nonfiction feature about the life of the novelist, inventor and cult figure Harold Louis Humes, is one part cultural analysis, three parts home movie.

headline: Got Their Musical Mojo Working
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cadillac Records
summary_short: “Cadillac Records” is a rollicking and insightful celebration of Chicago blues in its hectic golden age.

headline: Kidnapping, Suicide and Other Family Matters
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nobel Son
summary_short: “Nobel Son” is an aggressively noisy exercise in style over substance about nasty people doing nasty things to one another in (sigh) Southern California.

headline: Young New Yorkers With Old Ideas
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Let Them Chirp Awhile
summary_short: “Let Them Chirp Awhile” is a painfully unsympathetic take on postcollegiate New Yorkers who think themselves artists but don’t have an original thought in their heads.

headline: A Comic-Book Avenger Strikes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Punisher: War Zone
summary_short: You will see “Punisher: War Zone” or not, and it will make about as much sense to you either way.

headline: Awe, Revulsion and Affection for Those Particles Unto Which Thou Shalt Return
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dust
summary_short: “Dust” is an eccentric and profoundly informative documentary.

headline: When Laws and Liberties Test Each Other’s Limits
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The End of America
summary_short: “The End of America” is an unsettling documentary polemic about the erosion of civil liberties in the wake of 9/11.

headline: When Faith Meets Feminism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secrets
summary_short: “The Secrets” is a religious soap opera and feminist cri de coeur.

headline: Clothes Make the Man, and Sometimes Improve His Fight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transporter 3
summary_short: To chart the differences between “Transporter 3” and its two predecessors is as pointless as trying to parse its flimsy plot.

headline: Two Unmerrymakers in a Grueling Land of Social Awfulness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Christmases
summary_short: “Four Christmases” is refreshingly tart and lean, forgoing the usual schmaltz and syrup of the season.

headline: Oh Give Me a Home Where the Cowboys and Kangaroos Roam
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Australia
summary_short: “Australia” is a pastiche of genres and references wrapped up into one horse-galloping, cattle-stampeding, camera-swooping, music-swelling, widescreen package.

display_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas
headline: Horror Through a Child’s Eyes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Boy in the Striped Pajamas
summary_short: See the Holocaust trivialized, glossed over, kitsched up, commercially exploited and hijacked for a tragedy about a Nazi family. Better yet and in all sincerity: don’t.

headline: The Love That Dare Not Bare Its Fangs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Twilight
summary_short: It’s love at first look instead of first bite in “Twilight,” a deeply sincere, outright goofy vampire romance for the hot-not-to-trot abstinence set.

headline: Canine TV Action Star Discovers That Life Is the Best Reality Show
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bolt
summary_short: “Bolt” is at once a knowing, satirical sendup of the Hollywood fame-and-fantasy machinery and a sleek product of the Disney-Pixar industrial complex.

headline: Convulsions of a Family and an Abandoned Country
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Betrayal
summary_short: “The Betrayal (Nerakhoon)” is quiet, contemplative and impressionistic, which makes the story it has to tell all the more powerful.

headline: Ah, Home for the Holidays and Extra Helpings of Family Dysfunction
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Christmas Tale
summary_short: After two and a half hours in the thrilling, exhausting company of the characters in “A Christmas Tale,” the intimacy we feel with them is wired with surprise.

headline: Dreamer, Live in the Here and Now
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Synecdoche, New York
summary_short: To say that Charlie Kaufman’s “Synecdoche, New York” is one of the best films of the year is such a pathetic response to its soaring ambition that I might as well pack it in right now.

headline: The Upside of Seeing the Bright Side
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Happy-Go-Lucky
summary_short: “Happy-Go-Lucky” is closely tuned to the pulse of communal life, to the rhythms of how people work, play and struggle together.

headline: Back in 1968, When a Tie Was No Tie
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harvard Beats Yale 29-29
summary_short: Kevin Rafferty makes the case for remembrance and for the art of the story in his preposterously entertaining documentary “Harvard Beats Yale 29-29.”

headline: Rotten Tomatoes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dukes
summary_short: “The Dukes” tastes like pasta sauce that has sat on the shelf long after the expiration date on the can.

headline: Even After the Books, Pottermania Rocks On
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Are Wizards
summary_short: The filmmaker Josh Koury has latched onto a great subject for “We Are Wizards,” his peek at some of the more engaged fans circulating in the Harry Potter world.

headline: From Child Soldier to Hip-Hop Artist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War Child
summary_short: “War Child,” a documentary about the hip-hop artist Emmanuel Jal, is a bit ragged and repetitive.

headline: Lonely Old Men and Drugged Young Virgins
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of House of the Sleeping Beauties
summary_short: Not even the august presence of Maximilian Schell can dispel the odor of fusty smut that clings to “House of the Sleeping Beauties.”

headline: 007 Is Back, and He’s Brooding
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quantum of Solace
summary_short: “Quantum of Solace” prompts the question: Is revenge the only possible motive for large-scale movie heroism these days?

headline: Those Darn Kidults! The Menace of Eternal Youth
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Role Models
summary_short: Judd Apatow neither wrote nor directed “Role Models.” But he might as well have.

headline: Reunited for a Road Trip and an R&B Curtain Call
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Soul Men
summary_short: “Soul Men” is a raucous, rambling comedy, offering some laughs, some groans and a feast for fans of the musical idioms it mocks and celebrates.

headline: Duck! The Penguins Are Flying the Plane
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa
summary_short: There’s a generally more diverting entertainment waddling along the edges of “Madagascar: Escape 2 Africa” than the larger one lollygagging on screen.

headline: Out of Rehab, Wreaking Havoc
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rachel Getting Married
summary_short: The wonderful thing about “Rachel Getting Married” is how expansive it seems, in spite of the limits of its scope and the modesty of its ambitions.

headline: Intimate Table Talk for All to Ponder
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stages
summary_short: The phrase “divorced couple” sounds like an oxymoron, but there’s really no other way to describe the Dutch ex-spouses whose table talk dominates “Stages.”

headline: Love Beyond Boundaries
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Can't Think Straight
summary_short: Plugging the same two actresses into different Sapphic scenarios may be a valid filmmaking strategy but it can be an extremely boring one.

headline: Beware of the Darkness, and Those Ugly Clothes
