link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Haunting of Molly Hartley
summary_short: God and Satan duke it out for the soul of a young girl in “The Haunting of Molly Hartley,” an unexpectedly cynical addition to the teen-scream genre.

display_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno
headline: Skin Flick? Nah, It’s a Love Story
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zack and Miri Make a Porno
summary_short: “Zack and Miri Make a Porno,” in spite of its lewdness, follows a gee-whiz romantic-comedy formula that would not be out of place on the Disney Channel.

headline: United by Shared Ambivalence
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monks: The Transatlantic Feedback
summary_short: “Monks: The Transatlantic Feedback,” an ambitious but unfocused documentary, bids to immortalize this short-lived if influential group.

headline: A Boy Gone, a Mother Scorned
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Changeling
summary_short: When it works best, “Changeling” is a feverish and bluntly effective parable of wronged innocence.

headline: A Satirical Look at Hollywood Lives, Viewed Through a Cynical Lens
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Just Happened?
summary_short: The title of Barry Levinson’s new movie, “What Just Happened,” is not phrased as a question, but if it were it would demand another question in response: “Who cares?”

headline: Guns N’ Poses: Thugs, Drugs and Style in Shady London
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of RocknRolla
summary_short: Guy Ritchie reshuffles a worn-out deck in “RocknRolla,” a return to the shady stylings that characterized his earlier flicks.

headline: Tale of a Marathon and Its Guiding Hand
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Run For Your Life
summary_short: A new documentary offers a salutary and touching reminder that the race, like nearly everything else great about New York City, was the creation of a stubborn visionary.

headline: Grand Guignol, by Way of the Tool Shed
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saw V
summary_short: The latest and least of the “Saw” films is just plain boring and even a little tame — albeit by the standards of a genre that helped bring the phrase “torture porn” into the lexicon.

headline: Lost Luggage Is the Least of Their Worries
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Passengers
summary_short: “Passengers” is a supernatural thriller so mechanically inept and lacking in suspense that it doesn’t even pass muster as lowbrow Halloween-ready entertainment.

headline: Life Inside
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of News From Home/News From House
summary_short: Amos Gitai gets a lot of mileage out of a small metaphor in the third film in which he looks at people who have lived in a house in West Jerusalem over the decades.

headline: Atrocities Magnified
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Soviet Story
summary_short: The filmmaking in “The Soviet Story” is so overwrought that at times the movie comes across as comical.

headline: A Band of Loyal Brothers, Not All of Them Honorable
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pride and Glory
summary_short: “Pride and Glory,” directed by Gavin O’Connor, plods across familiar ground. It’s yet another movie about the fraternal disorder of the police.

headline: Gay Wedding Bells
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Noah's Arc: Jumping the Broom
summary_short: The television series “Noah’s Arc” has yielded, “Sex and the City” style, its own feature: an agreeable melodrama unlikely to reach an audience beyond that of the show.

headline: Omigosh, Real Guys Love Sports and Musical Theater
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of High School Musical 3: Senior Year
summary_short: How lovely the American high school experience might be if it offered even a smidgen of the euphoria in “High School Musical 3: Senior Year.”

display_title: Stranded: I've Come From a Plane That Crashed in the Mountains
headline: When Survival Hinged on Team Spirit
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stranded: I've Come From a Plane That Crashed in the Mountains
summary_short: Gonzalo Arijón’s documentary “Stranded” offers an incontrovertible argument for the necessity of team spirit in the face of catastrophe.

headline: Oliver Stone’s Vision Thing: Bush, the Family
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of W.
summary_short: “W.” does something most journalism and even documentaries can’t or won’t do: it reminds us what a long, strange trip it’s been to the Bush White House.

headline: A Lone Avenger, Jampacked With Righteous Anger
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Max Payne
summary_short: “Max Payne” is content to be an efficient vehicle for the delivery of a familiar range of sensations, some of which almost rise to the level of feelings.

headline: Scot. Joe Scot.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flashbacks of a Fool
summary_short: Without Daniel Craig’s 007-enhanced profile, it’s unlikely that “Flashbacks of a Fool” would have appeared anywhere except the Netflix queues of his most rabid fans.

headline: Public Displays of Hormonally Charged Desperation
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex Drive
summary_short: The most notable thing about “Sex Drive” is that it reserves all its creativity for ways to revolt and ostensibly delight its target audience.

headline: Two Friends With Tall Tales
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Not Your Typical Bigfoot Movie
summary_short: In the once booming, now fading steel town of Portsmouth, Ohio, two friends share a talent for spotting the apelike creature most popularly known as Bigfoot.

headline: A Golden Dollop of Motherly Comfort
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Secret Life of Bees
summary_short: “The Secret Life of Bees” insists so strenuously on its themes of redemption, tolerance, love and healing that it winds up defeating itself.

headline: Infection’s Bad Symptoms
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quarantine
summary_short: “Quarantine,” yet another pseudo-documentary horror movie, delivers the heebie-jeebies with solid acting and perfectly calibrated shocks.

headline: Aspirations That Go Beyond Gangsterism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Talento de Barrio
summary_short: Daddy Yankee, a big star in the musical genre of reggaetón, takes his big-screen shot in “Talento de Barrio.”

headline: Seeking a Connection in a Barren Place
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Leon
summary_short: Moonlight, mist and thick tropical air permeate the landscape of “La León,” a sumptuous film about the swirling of desire in the Paraná Delta.

headline: The Gulf Between Persona and True Self
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nights and Weekends
summary_short: “Night and Weekends” observes the failing days of a relationship and an awkward, post-breakup reunion.

headline: Big Stars Wielding an Array of Accents, Fighting the War on Terrorism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Body of Lies
summary_short: Ridley Scott’s new movie, “Body of Lies,” raises a potentially disturbing question. If terrorism has become boring, does that mean the terrorists have won?

headline: The Football Formula: Take One Hero, Add Emotion, Watch Him Overcome
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Express
summary_short: “The Express” is an honorable example of a tried-and-true formula, aimed at a large cross-section of the moviegoing public: people who love football and hate racism.

headline: Fleeing a Dying Civilization, Toward Hope and Sunlight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of City of Ember
summary_short: At moments “City of Ember” suggests a mild satire of end-of-days ideology.

headline: Georgiana and Her Dull, Dallying Duke
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Duchess
summary_short: “The Duchess” is an overstuffed, intellectually underbaked portrait of a poor little rich girl.

headline: In Burkina Faso, Rebellion Stirs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delwende
summary_short: In “Delwende” the African filmmaker S. Pierre Yameogo tackles social injustice in present-day Burkina Faso with grace, economy and exquisitely controlled anger.

headline: Comic Right-Wing Broadside (Very Broad)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of An American Carol
summary_short: Cheap shots and mean spirits abound in “An American Carol,” a lazy satire of the radical left.

headline: Stealing Glances
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pleasure of Being Robbed
summary_short: The initial glimmer of hope “The Pleasure of Being Robbed” inspires with regard to the indie offshoot genre of mumblecore quickly dies.

headline: For Muddled Youth, Music to Live By
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nick & Norah's Infinite Playlist
summary_short: As thin as an iPod Nano, as full of adolescent self-display as a Facebook page, “Nick & Norah’s Infinite Playlist” strives to capture what it’s like to be young right now.

display_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People
headline: A Guide to Burning Your Bridges
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How to Lose Friends & Alienate People
summary_short: The crushingly unfunny and slopped-together “How to Lose Friends & Alienate People” has neither the ambition nor the intelligence to do justice to its source material.

headline: Splatter Matters
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tokyo Gore Police
summary_short: Propelled by geysers of blood and tidal waves of neuroses, “Tokyo Gore Police” plumbs wounds both cultural and physical to deliver splatterific social satire.

headline: An Everyman Inventor Fights the Detroit Goliaths
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flash of Genius
summary_short: “Flash of Genius” is a doggedly workmanlike variation of an old story: the lone crusader doing battle with the big bad establishment.

headline: Barking With Bite
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beverly Hills Chihuahua
summary_short: “Beverly Hills Chihuahua” approaches but never quite achieves a truly spectacular level of absurdity.

headline: Characters Who Learn to See by Falling Into a World Without Sight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blindness
summary_short: “Blindness” is not a great film. But it is, nonetheless, full of examples of what good filmmaking looks like.

headline: Believers, Skeptics and a Pool of Sitting Ducks
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Religulous
summary_short: “Religulous” is a film that aims for laughs, not a scientific survey of the roots of faith.

headline: Gunman Meets Widow. Trouble Starts.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Appaloosa
summary_short: “Appaloosa” shows a square jaw and a steely gaze, but also a smile and a wink.

headline: Immigrant Hoop Dreams
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The First Basket
summary_short: “The First Basket,” a functional (if narrowly interesting) recollects the rich history of Jewish participation in basketball.

headline: Waiting to Inhale on the Lost Coast
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Humboldt County
summary_short: So much pot is smoked in the agreeable drama “Humboldt County” that you may come away from it with a contact high.

headline: Putting Out House Fires, Reigniting Passions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fireproof
summary_short: “Fireproof” is a decent attempt to combine faith and storytelling that will certainly register with its target audience.

headline: On the Run From Terrorists and a Disembodied Voice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eagle Eye
summary_short: “Eagle Eye” is the latest evidence that sometimes, at the movies, more is less.

display_title: Wild Combination: A Portrait of Arthur Russell
headline: Strange and Soulful Music
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Combination: A Portrait of Arthur Russell
summary_short: The music of Arthur Russell fused minimalist drone to ethereal melody, cello thrum to warbling vocals, downtown braininess to universal pop.

display_title: Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story
headline: Layers of Political Strategy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story
summary_short: Like a trompe l’oeil painting, “Boogie Man: The Lee Atwater Story” deftly positions its subject as both the savior of the Republican Party and the Antichrist of American politics.

byline: By JEANNETTE CATSOULIS NATHAN LEE  NEIL GENZLINGER   LAURA KERN
headline: Sports Therapy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forever Strong
summary_short: “Forever Strong” was devised by committee, plotted by machine and acted on cruise control.

headline: Big Storm Is Brewing (Hurricane, Too)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nights in Rodanthe
summary_short: There’s no joy and not even much cruel laughter to be had from “Nights in Rodanthe.”

headline: Hollywood War, Revised Edition
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miracle at St. Anna
summary_short: “Miracle at St. Anna” exists in part to make the overdue point that African-American soldiers fought as bravely and as hard as the characters in Hollywood combat epics.

headline: Surprises and Epiphanies for Soldiers on a Road Trip
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lucky Ones
summary_short: With a smooth, light touch, “The Lucky Ones” focuses on the idea that the present and the people who factor into it are all we really have.

headline: Heimlich Maneuvers on the Way to Self
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Choke
summary_short: To visit the absurdist world of “Choke” requires that you dive through the looking glass into a labyrinth where personal identity is fluid.

headline: Culture Wars Waged in Suburban Bedrooms
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Towelhead
summary_short: In “Towelhead,” a provocative satire of a culture that is paradoxically hypersexual and puritanical, teenage sexuality makes everyone bonkers.

headline: Triangle With Crude Sides
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Best Friend's Girl
summary_short: Kate Hudson loosens her wholesome screen image a notch in her latest star vehicle, a racy comedy, which aims to be tasteless (it often is) and romantic (it mostly isn’t).

headline: A City in Flux
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taking Father Home
summary_short: “Taking Father Home” is a stunning introduction to a rare new talent.

headline: His Task: Help Strangers Die Happily Ever After
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Town
summary_short: The sharp comic timing and the offbeat chemistry of Ricky Gervais, Greg Kinnear and Téa Leoni keep “Ghost Town” afloat.

headline: Lurking in the Shadows of Suburbia, a Menacing Neighbor With a Gun
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lakeview Terrace
summary_short: Considered purely as a formal exercise, “Lakeview Terrace” is a passable piece of hackwork, with some adequately suspenseful passages.

headline: A Frankenstein Tale With a Twist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Igor
summary_short: There’s scant reward for sitting through “Igor,” an animated twist on the Frankenstein story that never sparks to life.

display_title: Tyler Perry's The Family That Preys
headline: Money Isn’t Everything When Values Are at Stake
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's The Family That Preys
summary_short: “Tyler Perry’s The Family That Preys” is a sudsy, interracial fable about the power of greed to destroy families and erode morality.

headline: Catfights and Class Struggles, but Not at Katz’s Deli
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Women
summary_short: Watching “The Women,” you wait in vain for a moment of snappy repartee, of fresh emotion, of grace or charm or pathos. You wait, by the way, for a very long time.

headline: A History Lesson and a Call to Arms
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Secrecy
summary_short: “Secrecy” prowls through the labyrinth of information suppression and, as might be expected in so murky a milieu, winds up a little lost.

headline: For Two Movie Titans, a Long-Awaited Clash
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Righteous Kill
summary_short: Time doesn’t so much pass in “Righteous Kill” as crawl, despite the usual overcutting, which tries to pump energy into the inert proceedings.

headline: Coens Ask the C.I.A. for a License to Laugh
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burn After Reading
summary_short: “Burn After Reading,” the clubby, predictably self-amused comedy from Joel and Ethan Coen, has a tricky plot, visual style, er, to burn, but little heart.

headline: An Assassin Arrives to Turn Off the Lights
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bangkok Dangerous
summary_short: Directed by the Pang brothers (Danny and Oxide), “Bangkok Dangerous” is a halfhearted remake of their 1999 picture of the same name.

headline: Plaid Suits, Prize Grapes and the Rise of Napa
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bottle Shock
summary_short: “Bottle Shock” reconstructs a watershed moment in the wine world’s acceptance of the Golden State.

headline: Only a Few More Smuggling Days Left Before Christmas? It’s Not a Wonderful Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frozen River
summary_short: Courtney Hunt’s somber film “Frozen River” ventures deep into the trenches where hard-working Americans struggle to put food on the table.

headline: Intrigue on an Ill-Fated Train, Moscow-Bound
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transsiberian
summary_short: “Transsiberian” is a handsomely remodeled variation of a cherished genre you might call the mystery-train movie.

headline: Tracking Paranoia and Injustice in 21st-Century America
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Pedal Uphill
summary_short: Applying a microscope to 21st-century America, “We Pedal Uphill: Stories From the States 2001-2008” sees a country mired in paranoia, injustice and intolerance.

headline: Chipmunks With Rabies? That Is So L L Not Cool J
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Disaster Movie
summary_short: “Disaster Movie,” the latest disposable parody of disposable Hollywood movies, has a shelf life of about five minutes, tops.

headline: Student Weekend of Raunch and Geek Empowerment
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of College
summary_short: Pity today’s teenage audience. Their latest cinematic temptation is yet another tiresome fraternities-are-wild offering.

headline: Savior or Sinner? It Can Be Tough to Tell
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Babylon A.D.
summary_short: The only explicable thing about “Babylon A.D.” is that it was not screened in advance for critics.

headline: Space in 3-D
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fly Me to the Moon
summary_short: “Fly Me to the Moon” bills itself as the first animated feature created expressly for 3-D. Too bad it wasn’t created expressly for, you know, pleasure or art.

headline: Extracurricular Lessons for Student and Teacher
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elegy
summary_short: “Elegy” is such a serious, oftentimes grave exploration of desire and the ways of aging that it’s a miracle the two central characters have as much sex as they do.

headline: Walking on Air Between the Towers
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Man on Wire
summary_short: James Marsh’s “Man on Wire” is a thorough, understated and altogether enthralling documentary.

headline: An Angry Thief's Small World Gets Smaller and Smaller
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Attitude
summary_short: Spoddy (Michael  Disend) is a small-time car thief who operates a garage in a sad, unidentified corner of the Bay Area.   Tall, reedy, manically energetic, Spoddy identifies with wild birds, and considers himself a cross between a hunting falcon and an endangered snowy egret.  He is given to long-winded, self-righteous denunciations of his fellow humans for what he perceives as their blind conformism, which makes him a very irritating person to be around.  Frequent cutaways to soaring sea gulls suggest that Spoddy is a spirit in desperate need of liberation.  "Attitude" is the fifth installment in a series of works that Rob Nilsson has created with the Tenderloin Group, an actors' workshop that he helped to create at a halfway house in San Francsico's Tenderloin district.  Largely improvised, the drama evolves before your eyes, sometimes striking directly to a powerful emotion, at other times getting lost in fussy actorish moments. — Dave Kehr

headline: In a World of Extremists, Shades of Gray Add Ambiguity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Traitor
summary_short: “Traitor,” a somber, absorbing and only moderately preposterous new thriller written and directed by Jeffrey Nachmanoff, manages an impressive feat of economy.

headline: The Rest Was Silence, but Then Came the Sequel
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hamlet 2
summary_short: “Hamlet 2” belongs to the school of free-for-all satiric farce whose creators ball up wads of ideas, apply chewing gum and hurl them against the wall to see what sticks.

headline: Heavy Automotive Metal in a Rusty Pileup Soufflé
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death Race
summary_short: “Death Race” is a supercharged junkyard apocalypse powered by an unabashed relish for brutal comeuppance and a flair for delirious vehicular mayhem.

headline: Tossing Around an Old Pigskin With a Rocker, Turned Director
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Longshots
summary_short: Fred Durst of Limp Bizkit fame directs what may be the most formulaic football movie ever made.

headline: A Muddled Walk Through a Segregationist History
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dare Not Walk Alone
summary_short: In the civil rights documentary “Dare Not Walk Alone,” director Jeremy Dean makes a valiant attempt to juxtapose past and present, but his execution is so muddled it’s almost unwatchable.

headline: The Misadventures of an Ex-Centerfold
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The House Bunny
summary_short: Anna Faris proves herself a faux-bimbo par excellence in this breezy, ditzy comedy about a Playboy bunny who goes back to school.

display_title: Richard Serra: Thinking On Your Feet
headline: Watching as Richard Serra Thinks Big and Does Big
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Richard Serra: Thinking On Your Feet
summary_short: Operating at the intersection of art and industrial engineering, Richard Serra is an informative if unanimated guide through “Thinking on Your Feet.”

headline: Middle-Aged Heavy Metal Drummer Meets Under-Age Band
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Rocker
summary_short: Watching Rainn Wilson gyrate in “The Rocker,” you can’t help wondering if Mr. Wilson is inhabiting a role that was originally turned down by Jack Black.

headline: Evil Reflected
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mirrors
summary_short: A possessed nun, an alcoholic ex-cop and a mess of shattered glass drive “Mirrors,” a minor chiller and major downer from the talented Alexandre Aja.

headline: The Portrait of Two Ladies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vicky Cristina Barcelona
summary_short: “Vicky Cristina Barcelona” is a rueful comedy about two young American women who savor many Continental delicacies.

headline: When You Plan to Die Alone, Prepare for Lots of Company
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Henry Poole Is Here
summary_short: With characters named Esperanza, Dawn and Patience, “Henry Poole Is Here” traffics in the kind of inspirational kitsch that only a true believer could swallow.

display_title: One Bad Cat: The Reverend Albert Wagner Story
headline: Painting His Fears
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Bad Cat: The Reverend Albert Wagner Story
summary_short: Directed by Thomas G. Miller, “One Bad Cat” brings fresh light to the artist Albert Wagner.

display_title: The Romance of Astrea and Celadon
headline: Shepherds, Nymphs, Despair and Love
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Romance of Astrea and Celadon
summary_short: The nymphs and druids who frolic through “The Romance of Astrea and Celadon” occupy mythological space between Shakespeare and Greek mythology.

headline: Lives of Real Adolescents, in Very Deep Close-Up
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Teen
summary_short: The documentary “American Teen” is the kind of movie the people in it might have made.

headline: Bright Young Things in Love and Pain
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brideshead Revisited
summary_short: “Brideshead Revisited,” directed by Julian Jarrold, is a strenuously picturesque adaptation of the novel by Evelyn Waugh.

headline: War May Be Hell, but Hollywood Is Even Worse
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tropic Thunder
summary_short: “Tropic Thunder” is a flashy, nasty, on-and-off funny and assaultive sendup of the film industry.

headline: An Action Comedy With a Little Song and Dance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Singh is Kinng
summary_short: “Singh Is Kinng” isn’t a great movie. But the immensely likable Akshay Kumar shines as a Capraesque hero who spreads bedrock Indian values.

headline: In Search of Posthumous Adulation
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What We Do is Secret
summary_short: “What We Do Is Secret” reveals its hero, Darby Crash, as a disaffected egotist and a magnet for needy weirdoes.

headline: Snared in a Dark Labyrinth When His Wife Disappears
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tell No One
summary_short: Guillaume Canet’s delicious contemporary thriller “Tell No One” is “Vertigo” meets “The Fugitive” by way of “The Big Sleep.” That is meant as high praise.

headline: Godmother of Punk, Celebrator of Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Patti Smith: Dream of Life
summary_short: You may not learn everything you want to know in “Patti Smith: Dream of Life,” but you learn just about everything you need.

headline: Stoners Who Put the Bud in Buddies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pineapple Express
summary_short: “Pineapple Express” is a stoner comedy that partakes of a gentle indie vibe before hitting the hard stuff.

display_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2
headline: Four Jills in Jeans (One Pair) Go to College, Find Romance (or Not), Stay Connected
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2
summary_short: This is the movie equivalent of being patted on the shoulder by an encouraging high school guidance counselor and assured that you are doing just fine.

display_title: In Search of a Midnight Kiss
headline: Hopeful Misanthrope Seeks Same
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Search of a Midnight Kiss
summary_short: Lightly sweetened and just a touch bitter, the romantic comedy “In Search of a Midnight Kiss” treads familiar if appealing ground.

headline: Hey, America, This Guy’s for You
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Swing Vote
summary_short: “Swing Vote” is one of the most surprising, politically suggestive movies to come out of Hollywood this year.

display_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor
headline: Curses
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor
summary_short: The third installment of the “Mummy” franchise, “Tomb of the Dragon Emperor,” is by far the weakest.

display_title: Profit Motive and the Whispering Wind
headline: Holding an All Saints’ Day of American Radicals
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Profit Motive and the Whispering Wind
summary_short: “Profit Motive and the Whispering Wind” contemplates the violence and struggle of the past by examining markers and monuments across the country.

headline: Summer of ’94, With Boy, Girl, Love and Dope Sales
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wackness
summary_short: “The Wackness” makes a good-faith effort to steer clear of coming-of-age story clichés, and succeeds and fails in roughly equal measure.

headline: Returning to the Scene of a Crime Movie
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Back to Normandy
summary_short: “Back to Normandy” takes a look at how the making of a film affected the village where it was set.

display_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe
headline: Who’s Afraid of the Darkly Paranormal?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The X-Files: I Want to Believe
summary_short: Baggy, draggy, oddly timed and strangely off the mark, “The X-Files: I Want to Believe” is the generally bad-news follow-up to the show’s first feature-film incarnation.

headline: Once More to the Well of Goofball Comedy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Step Brothers
summary_short: In “Step Brothers,” a middle-aged male arrested adolescent meets same.

headline: In Thailand, Two Lovers Among a Tsunami’s Ruins
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wonderful Town
summary_short: Everything is, for a good long while, very nice indeed in “Wonderful Town.”

headline: Showdown in Gotham Town
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dark Knight
summary_short: Pitched at the divide between art and industry, poetry and entertainment, “The Dark Knight” goes darker and deeper than any Hollywood movie of its comic-book kind.

headline: Plucky Apes Help to Save the Planet of the Humans
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Space Chimps
summary_short: Journalism is all about having the courage to write the truth even if it will get you mocked by your relatives and co-workers, so here goes: “Space Chimps” is hilarious.

headline: Life Penalties
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Take
summary_short: If there is anything the cinema needed less than another angst-ridden, cross-cutting tragedy about crime, fate, memory and redemption, it’s the kind shot in an ugly monochromatic palette like “Take.”

headline: Does Your Mother Know You Sing Abba Tunes?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mamma Mia!
summary_short: You can have a perfectly nice time watching this spirited adaptation of the popular stage musical and, once the hangover wears off, acknowledge just how bad it is.

display_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson
headline: Beyond Fear and Loathing
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gonzo: The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson
summary_short: “Gonzo” is a fascinating history lesson and a bit of a cautionary tale about how fame can turn into the scourge of talent.

headline: The Sex and the Fury, French Aristocracy Style
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Mistress
summary_short: In “The Last Mistress,” the director Catherine Breillat’s explorations of desire are so far from the antiseptic world of most screen depictions as to seem far out.

display_title: Encounters at the End of the World
headline: How Many Goodly Creatures Are There on Mr. Herzog’s Planet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Encounters at the End of the World
summary_short: Few filmmakers make the end of days seem as hauntingly beautiful as Werner Herzog does in “Encounters at the End of the World.”

headline: The Pain Beneath the Pounds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Disfigured
summary_short: A struggling anorexic and her physical opposite form an unlikely friendship in “disFIGURED,” a funny, awkward and often uncomfortable drama.

headline: Hard Look at Tough Times for an Italian Marriage
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Days and Clouds
summary_short: Silvio Soldini’s film “Days and Clouds” suggests that Italy’s middle class is as much under siege as that of the United States.

headline: A Tenacious Matriarch Who Won’t Go Quietly
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Stone Angel
summary_short: “The Stone Angel” is a film of tightly assembled bits and pieces that don’t fit comfortably together despite clever dashes of magical realism connecting past and present.

headline: World War I on Their Minds, ’60s Pop in Their Hearts
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La France
summary_short: In the once-upon-a-time fairy tale called “La France,” French soldiers move through darkly verdant landscapes worthy of Henri Rousseau.

display_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth
headline: Six Flags Subterranean Style, or Something Like It
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Journey to the Center of the Earth
summary_short: If “Journey to the Center of the Earth” is not a ride, then what is it? One thing it may not be, quite, is a movie.

headline: Like Bogey, but With a Really Big Fist
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hellboy II: The Golden Army
summary_short: There are moments in “Hellboy 2: The Golden Army” capable of delighting even the most jaded, comic-book-weary summer-blockbuster conscript.

headline: An Itty-Bitty Brother From Another Planet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meet Dave
summary_short: “Meet Dave,” the latest in a long line of disposable Eddie Murphy vehicles, plays like a half-hour sitcom episode that has been stretched to feature-length running time.

headline: A Prisoner of Normalcy Finds Ways to Escape
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brick Lane
summary_short: At the center of “Brick Lane,” a modest film directed by Sarah Gavron, is a woman for whom modesty is not just a defining character trait but also a moral principle.

headline: Children Without Childhoods
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Very Young Girls
summary_short: Notwithstanding the coyly suggestive title, “Very Young Girls” is very far from exploitative.

headline: A Tale of Two Minds, Spinning Out of Control
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diminished Capacity
summary_short: “Diminished Capacity” touches earnestly on heart-heavy issues of loss: loss of memory, of love and, perhaps because of the local angle, of (or rather by) the Chicago Cubs.

headline: Forge a Unity of Purpose, Then Conquer the World
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mongol
summary_short: “Mongol” is a big, ponderous epic, its beautifully composed landscape shots punctuated by thundering hooves and bloody, slow-motion battle sequences.

display_title: When Did You Last See Your Father?
headline: As a Father Nears Death, a Son Grows No Closer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of When Did You Last See Your Father?
summary_short: “When Did You Last See Your Father?” is grown-up, civilized fare, even though the whole thing might have been improved with a bit of messiness.

headline: Able to Leap Tall Buildings, Even if Hung Over
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hancock
summary_short: “Hancock” makes for one unexpectedly satisfying and kinky addition to Hollywood’s superhero chronicles.

headline: Wholesome Life Lessons for Budding Reporter
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kit Kittredge: An American Girl
summary_short: “Kit Kittredge: An American Girl” appears poised to incite the kind of box-office frenzy more commonly associated with characters named Hannah and Harry.

headline: An Angel Rides in to Preserve a Family (and India)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thoda Pyaar Thoda Magic
summary_short: “Thoda Pyaar, Thoda Magic” (“A Little Love, a Little Magic”) has a buoyancy and optimism that trump the predictability of its story.

headline: When an Eloquent Voice Was Stilled in Hollywood
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trumbo
summary_short: Peter Askin’s stirring documentary “Trumbo” gives you reasons to cheer but also to weep.

headline: In a World Left Silent, One Heart Beeps
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of WALL-E
summary_short: “Wall-E” breaks new ground in giving us a G-rated, computer-generated cartoon vision of our own potential extinction.

headline: Dipping Into Many Modes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of All in This Tea
summary_short: “All in This Tea” is a delicious documentary about a beverage.

headline: You Talkin’ to Me, Boys? (Bang-Bang, My Pretties)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wanted
summary_short: “Wanted” shows life in the killing lane with lots of zippy effects, action and exploding heads.

display_title: Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine
headline: Portrait of a Haunted Artist Who Befriended Giant Spiders
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Louise Bourgeois: The Spider, the Mistress and the Tangerine
summary_short: This uncommonly elegant and evocative portrait of Louise Bourgeois reveals much about the haunting and haunted master while leaving intact the thing you cannot explain.

headline: More Deadpan but Still a Bumbler
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Get Smart
summary_short: “Get Smart” is made up of feeble and funny jokes, brand actors and enough special effects to give you some bang for your summertime buck.

headline: Just Say ‘Mariska Hargitay’ and Snicker
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Love Guru
summary_short: “The Love Guru” is downright antifunny, an experience that makes you wonder if you will ever laugh again.

headline: A May-December Love for All Seasons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chris & Don: A Love Story
summary_short: “Chris & Don: A Love Story” examines a complicated and enduring relationship that raised eyebrows even in Hollywood.

headline: Depending on the Kindness of Strangers
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beauty in Trouble
summary_short: “Beauty in Trouble” uses the changing moods of water as both metaphor and frame for the infinite adaptability of human emotions.

headline: The Mingling of Dreams and Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love Comes Lately
summary_short: Max Kohn (Otto Tausig), the aging Lothario of “Love Comes Lately,” is very much like the movie itself: doddering and milquetoasty, but ultimately disarming.

headline: Homeless but Hopeful
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kicking It
summary_short: So earnest it hurts, “Kicking It” follows a half-dozen homeless men from around the globe as they ready for the fourth annual Homeless World Cup in Cape Town.

headline: Caution: Contents Turn Angry When Shaken
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Incredible Hulk
summary_short: The new movie about Dr. Bruce Banner is called “The Incredible Hulk.” But let’s not get carried away: “The Adequate Hulk” would have been a more suitable title.

headline: Something Lethal Lurks in the Rustling Trees
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Happening
summary_short: “The Happening” is a divertingly goofy thriller with an animistic bent, moments of shivery and twitchy suspense and a solid lead performance from Mark Wahlberg.

headline: Scratching and Clawing Their Way to the Middle
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Promotion
summary_short: “The Promotion” tells you everything you might want to know but were too uninterested to ask about working as an assistant manager in a supermarket.

headline: A Hit Man in a War Zone That Could Easily Be Iraq
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War, Inc.
summary_short: The zany, nihilistic “War, Inc.” is gonzo moviemaking with a bleeding heart.

headline: Invasion of the Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Children of Huang Shi
summary_short: “The Children of Huang Shi” is a Hollywood weepie snuggled inside a humanitarian tribute.

headline: Fresh Produce for Ratatouille, Please, but No Attitude
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grocer's Son
summary_short: “The Grocer’s Son” is a French variation of the fable of the prodigal son.

headline: Fuzzy Outsider, Kicking His Way Toward His Dream
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kung Fu Panda
summary_short: At once fuzzy-wuzzy and industrial strength, the tacky-sounding “Kung Fu Panda” is high concept with a heart.

display_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan
headline: Watch Out, He’s Packing a Blow-Dryer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Don't Mess With the Zohan
summary_short: Let me be blunt: “You Don’t Mess With the Zohan” is the finest post-Zionist action-hairdressing sex comedy I have ever seen.

headline: Sex, Cinema, Marriage and Other Dangerous Activities
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wedding Director
summary_short: In “The Wedding Director,” Sergio Castellitto, the film’s star, is the perfect vessel for the director Marco Bellocchio’s playful, sorrowful sensibility.

headline: Impish Writer on the Edge of Tomorrow
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dreams With Sharp Teeth
summary_short: Directed by Erik Nelson, “Dreams With Sharp Teeth” recalls the career of Harlan Ellison, a runty young geek who evolved into a world-famous artist.

headline: Romance and Ransom in Colombia
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Towards Darkness
summary_short: That someone is kidnapped in Colombia every three hours is a startling statistic that offers many cinematic possibilities. But “Towards Darkness” fails to use any of them to advantage.

headline: A Slow Crescendo of Intimidation
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Strangers
summary_short: “The Strangers” proves adept at eliciting the fear and dislocation that accompany the violation of our most sacred space.

headline: The Girls Are Back in Town
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex and the City
summary_short: A little Botox goes a long way in “Sex and the City,” but a little decent writing would have gone even further.

headline: Broken Spirits on the Mend
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Fall
summary_short: Shot piecemeal over the course of four years on locations in 18 countries, “The Fall” is a genuine labor of love — and a real bore.

headline: How to Rock in Iraq
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heavy Metal in Baghdad
summary_short: Iraq documentary fatigue gets a rock-hard slap in the face with “Heavy Metal in Baghdad,” an intrepid, unlikely and altogether splendid feat of D.I.Y. reportage.

headline: Retrofitted for Revenge
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Machine Girl
summary_short: The Japanese obsession with cavorting ninjas and cunning hardware reaches some kind of climax with “The Machine Girl.”

headline: After Them the Monsoon: Two Worlds Collide in India
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before the Rains
summary_short: The ingredients of the Indian director Santosh Sivan’s period piece “Before the Rains” may be awfully familiar, but the film lends them the force of tragedy.

headline: Lonely Boy’s ‘First Blood’ and First Pal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Son of Rambow
summary_short: “Son of Rambow” is a likable, lightly sticky valentine to childhood, the 1980s and the dawning of movie love.

headline: The Scenery’s Gorgeous. You Want a Plot, Too?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Roman De Gare
summary_short: Claude Lelouch’s “Roman de Gare” is a thriller, a murder mystery and a somewhat self-conscious literary puzzle.

headline: Professor as Student of His Life and Others’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Visitor
summary_short: The curious thing about “The Visitor” is that even as it goes more or less where you think it will, it still manages to surprise you along the way.

headline: Retired, Yes, but Never Too Old to Rock
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Young@Heart
summary_short: To observe a fluctuating group of about two dozen singers whose average age is 80 perform in the documentary “Young@Heart” is to be uplifted, if slightly unsettled.

display_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
headline: The Further Adventures of the Fedora and Whip
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull
summary_short: There’s plenty of frantic energy in “Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull,” lots of noise and money too, but what’s absent is any sense of rediscovery.

headline: Another Abraham’s Story, With a Different Ending
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Father My Lord
summary_short: “My Father My Lord” observes the severe family life of an ultra-Orthodox rabbi.

headline: When Selling a Soul, Consider the Price
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Yella
summary_short: Christian Petzold’s enigmatic thriller “Yella” offers a surreal X-ray vision of cutthroat capitalism in 21st-century Germany.

display_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
headline: Out of the Wardrobe, Into a War Zone
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian
summary_short: “Prince Caspian” is quite a bit darker than “The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe,” both in look and in mood. It is also in some ways more satisfying.

headline: In Paraguay, Time Melts in the Torpid Air
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paraguayan Hammock
summary_short: That “Paraguayan Hammock” happens to be one of the few features to emerge from Paraguay in recent decades in no way diminishes its rarity.

headline: A Family That Surfs to a Beat: Its Own
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surfwise
summary_short: “Surfwise” has a bohemian vibe and a cool sheen, but it’s an eager-to-please, pleasing commercial enterprise with a reassuring narrative arc.

headline: A Dashing Agent in Egypt
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies
summary_short: The hero of “OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies” might be described as a French equivalent of James Bond.

headline: Morning Hangover, Spouse and Jackpot
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of What Happens in Vegas
summary_short: “What Happens in Vegas,” one of those junky time-wasters that routinely pop up in movie theaters, won’t make you laugh much or at all.

headline: Gentlemen, Start Your Hot-Hued Engines
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Speed Racer
summary_short: “Speed Racer” sets out to honor and refresh a youthful enthusiasm from the past and winds up smothering the fun in self-conscious grandiosity.

headline: Dark Memories Abound
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fugitive Pieces
summary_short: For a tale spiked with so much torment, “Fugitive Pieces” feels remarkably soothing.

headline: In a Chokehold, on the Mat and in Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Redbelt
summary_short: “Redbelt” is a satisfying, unexpectedly involving B-movie that owes as much to old Hollywood as to Greek tragedy.

headline: The Biological Clock Is Ticking, the Cause for Much Alarm
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Then She Found Me
summary_short: “Then She Found Me,” a serious comedy, is more impressive for what it refuses to do than for its modest accomplishment.

headline: The Killing of Innocents Faces a Dry-Eyed Dissection
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Battle for Haditha
summary_short: In “Battle for Haditha,” the British filmmaker Nick Broomfield revisits a wretched chapter of the war in Iraq.

headline: Struck by Love in a Moody Underworld
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of As Tears Go By
summary_short: “As Tears Go By,” Wong Kar-wai’s first feature film, heralds a new vision not yet in perfect focus.

headline: Confronting the Perils of Puberty Squared
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of XXY
summary_short: The moody, surreal “XXY” explores the world of Alex, an intersex teenager navigating the treacherous emotional and hormonal rapids of uncertain gender.

display_title: Hollywood Chinese: The Chinese in American Film
headline: Diversity of Talent and Spirit
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hollywood Chinese: The Chinese in American Film
summary_short: A welcome entry in the constituency-cinema canon, “Hollywood Chinese” surveys a century’s worth of Chinese-American entertainers.

headline: Swinging Suburbia and the Sensual City
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Viva
summary_short: “Viva” is a startlingly pitch-perfect reproduction of the kind of gauzy sex movies from the 1960s and early 1970s that preceded the hard-core revolution.

headline: Heavy Suit, Light Touches
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Iron Man
summary_short: “Iron Man” is an unusually good superhero picture. Or at least — since it certainly has its problems — a superhero movie that’s good in unusual ways.

headline: My Best Friend’s Big Fat (Shouldn’t Happen) Scottish Wedding
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Made of Honor
summary_short: The romantic comedy “Made of Honor” adds tart satirical flavors to a cotton-candy formula without sabotaging the sugar rush.

display_title: The Adventures of Monty the Moose: Amazing Alaska Animals
headline: Getting to Graffiti Art’s Roots
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Adventures of Monty the Moose: Amazing Alaska Animals
summary_short: “Bomb It” takes a comprehensively international viewpoint on graffiti culture.

headline: A Sliver of Thrills
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Deception
summary_short: A would-be erotic thriller with no heat and zero chills, “Deception” has a kind of glassy, glossy sheen and risible story.

display_title: Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay
headline: Two Buddies, Several Tokes Over the Line
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay
summary_short: If you think the last seven years have been one long, dumb, dirty joke, then “Harold & Kumar Escape From Guantanamo Bay,” might be the perfect movie for you.

headline: Learning on the Job About Birthing Babies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Baby Mama
summary_short: The new comedy “Baby Mama” never comes fully to term, as it were.

headline: When Love of Religion Leads to Hatred of Others
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Constantine's Sword
summary_short: “Constantine’s Sword” asks: When your core beliefs conflict with church doctrine, how far should your loyalty to the church extend?

headline: Life in the Japanese Mafia
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Young Yakuza
summary_short: Jean-Pierre Limosin’s “Young Yakuza” looks at Japan’s version of the Mafia.

headline: The Allure of Psychological Damage
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Minutes
summary_short: A women-behind-bars plot seething with lesbianism, incest, hanging and catfights — on paper, at least, “Four Minutes” promises more fun than a Roger Corman marathon.

headline: Psychopath Calling: Prepare to Die
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 88 Minutes
summary_short: The execrable “88 Minutes” has many of the main ingredients for a camp lollapalooza.

headline: One More Time, Everybody Is Kung Fu Fighting
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Forbidden Kingdom
summary_short: “Forbidden Kingdom” is a faithful and disarmingly earnest attempt to honor some venerable and popular Chinese cinematic traditions.

headline: There’s Just No Getting Away From an Old Flame, Even in Hawaii
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forgetting Sarah Marshall
summary_short: “Forgetting Sarah Marshall” does not entirely play by the established conventions of its genre.

headline: Trying to Get a Glimpse Inside the Sport of Kings
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The First Saturday in May
summary_short: There are a lot of horses but absolutely no sense in “The First Saturday in May,” a glib, lazy documentary about six trainers on the road to the 2006 Kentucky Derby.

headline: Resentment Over Darwin Evolves Into a Documentary
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed
summary_short: One of the sleaziest documentaries to arrive in a very long time, “Expelled: No Intelligence Allowed” is a conspiracy-theory rant masquerading as investigative inquiry.

headline: The Cost of Collusion, Paid in Phony Currency
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Counterfeiters
summary_short: Like most films about the Holocaust, “The Counterfeiters,” a brisk, tough movie from the Austrian director Stefan Ruzowitzky, is a survivor’s tale.

headline: Music, Corsages and a Killer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Prom Night
summary_short: For a film about erotomania, “Prom Night” is a curiously flaccid affair.

headline: A Disagreeable Academic, and a Tonic Named Sarah Jessica Parker
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Smart People
summary_short: The great virtue of “Smart People” lies in its general preference for small insights over grand revelations.

headline: If You Embrace the Body, the Heart Might Follow
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Never Forever
summary_short: A fearless performance by Vera Farmiga, and glowing cinematography partly camouflage the awkward storytelling of “Never Forever.”

headline: Bad Cops, but Some Worse Than Others
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Street Kings
summary_short: “Street Kings” is an absurd if accidentally entertaining potboiler, based on a story by James Ellroy.

headline: Behold a Dark Horse, Bowing to Everyone
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Campaign
summary_short: This fascinating Japanese documentary is likely to challenge some very basic American assumptions about democracy.

headline: Cherchez le Sugar Daddy (et Sugar Mom)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Priceless
summary_short: Forget reality shows exalting American gluttony and savor the more refined amenities on the coasts of southern France in the cynical Gallic comedy “Priceless.”

headline: With Man’s Disappearance, a Family Assesses Its Faith
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tehilim
summary_short: Modest to a fault, the introverted family drama “Tehilim” circles an unsolved mystery and unresolved emotions.

headline: Watch Out for That Malevolent Jungle Vine
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ruins
summary_short: More disgusting than scary, “The Ruins” is the latest in a long line of horror films about upper-middle-class travelers being terrorized in unfamiliar environments.

headline: An Unlikely Friendship
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nana
summary_short: A spoonful of fashion helps the feminism go down in “Nana,” a delightful pop fairy tale that speaks to young women in the language of sisterhood and self-direction.

headline: Only Rock ’N’ Roll, but They’re Still at It
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shine a Light
summary_short: As the director of the documentary “Shine a Light,” Martin Scorsese is a besotted rock ’n’ roll fan who wholeheartedly embraces its mythology.

headline: Listen Up, Boys: Break Fizzy and Fake Insouciance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Leatherheads
summary_short: “Leatherheads” labors so strenuously to approximate some of the old screwball spirit of the ’30s and ’40s that it winds up in traction.

headline: Missed Adventures
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nim's Island
summary_short: If “Nim’s Island” were anything but a children’s movie, the casting genius who suggested Jodie Foster as a potential love interest for Gerard Butler would be looking for a new occupation.

headline: Mother and Son, Divided by Border, United by Phone
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tenichibo to Iganosuke
summary_short: Directed, with visible earnestness, by Patricia Riggen, “Under the Same Moon” blunts the hard edges of immigration with a thick coating of preciousness.

headline: Up, Up and a Ways Off the Track
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Superhero Movie
summary_short: To call “Superhero Movie” a satire, or even a parody, of the genre specified in its title would be misleading, since those terms imply at least an attempt at wit.

headline: Good-Natured Raunchiness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Four Letter Word
summary_short: “A Four Letter Word” is a surprisingly endearing romantic comedy that explores gay relationships with low-budget verve.

headline: Cut by a Diamond-Crusted Glass Ceiling
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flawless
summary_short: “Flawless” is a mildly diverting period heist movie in which an odd couple conspire to loot an evil London diamond company, for which they both work.

headline: A Run Does the Trick for a Case of Cold Feet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Run, Fat Boy, Run
summary_short: “Run, Fat Boy, Run” is an inspirational fantasy with guy’s-guy banter and gross-out humor. Yet it’s effective and affecting.

headline: Celebrating Masculine Immaturity
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Backseat
summary_short: The flailing, protagonists of “Backseat,” while not exactly 40-year-old virgins, can have avoided that fate only by the tender mercies of women with low expectations.

headline: With Assist From Greed, Money Makes the Man
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 21
summary_short: Greed is good and comes without a hint of conscience in “21,” a feature-length bore about some smarty-pants who take Vegas for a ride.

headline: Back From Iraq, on a Road Going Nowhere
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stop-Loss
summary_short: In some ways, there is a grim, accidental timeliness in the release of “Stop-Loss,” which focuses on the ordeal of American soldiers in and out of combat.

headline: Harry and Pat and Kay and Richard in 1949
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Married Life
summary_short: “Married Life,” a period comedy of manners merged with a suspenseful psychological thriller, aspires to be a hybrid of the sort that Alfred Hitchcock polished to perfection.

headline: Half-Brothers Mired in Full-Blown Hate
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shotgun Stories
summary_short: “Shotgun Stories” defines the classic western phrase “doing what a man’s got to do” as both a moral imperative and a biological compulsion.

headline: Serving a Buffet of Morality and Humor
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry’s Meet the Browns
summary_short: Tyler Perry's work may be rooted in the experience of a particular group, but there is nothing exclusive about it.

headline: A Haunting Intruder From the Darkroom
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shutter
summary_short: Fans of J-horror (for Japan, where the genre was born; its conventions have since spread to South Korea and Thailand) will find “Shutter” familiar; others may just doze.

headline: Break Time
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Planet B-Boy
summary_short: From moment to moment, “Planet B-Boy” is fun, sometimes thrilling and packed with illuminating details and striking personalities.

headline: Protector With Big Shtick for 3 High School Nerds
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drillbit Taylor
summary_short: “You get what you pay for,” the tag line on the advertisement for “Drillbit Taylor” says. I saw it free, and I still feel cheated.

headline: Strangers in a Land That’s Not So Strange
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Band's Visit
summary_short: “The Band’s Visit,” the first feature by the Israeli writer and director Eran Kolirin, flirts recklessly with obviousness, cuteness too.

headline: On Other Side of the World, Life Is Still Upside Down
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ling Yi Ban
summary_short: Ying Liang’s slyly subversive second feature takes awhile to coalesce, but once it does, it becomes an intriguing exercise in juxtaposition.

headline: Confronting a Killer Epidemic That Wouldn’t Die
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doomsday
summary_short: “Doomsday” has an appealing punk-rock sneer, but aside from a few clever music cues, swagger is, unfortunately, its only notable quality.

headline: Remembering a Home for Music and Activism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wetlands Preserved
summary_short: “Wetlands Preserved” is a fond account of the rising, thriving and eventual closing of the TriBeCa club known as the Wetlands Preserve.

headline: Cliques and Fists
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Never Back Down
summary_short: “Never Back Down” offers extreme fighting as the modern-day alternative to sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll.

display_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who!
headline: Saving Who-Ville Is a Big Production
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who!
summary_short: What distinguishes “Horton Hears a Who!” from the other recent Dr. Seuss film adaptations is that it is not one of the worst movies ever made.

headline: Race and Revenge in Lives of Father and Injured Son
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poor Boy's Game
summary_short: “Poor Boy’s Game” is a movie built around a boxing match, but its most powerful scenes involve no jabs or hooks.

headline: Imprisonment and Forced Servitude in Rural China
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blind Mountain
summary_short: “Blind Mountain,” the second feature from Li Yang, is a reminder that art sometimes keeps the truth alive far better than the news.

headline: Rock ’n’ Roll Camp
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girls Rock!
summary_short: Young women find expression for more than their music in “Girls Rock!,” a jubilant documentary about a place where power chords and empowerment go hand in hand.

headline: Love May Not Be All You Need After All
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of J'entends plus la guitare
summary_short: “J’Entends Plus la Guitare,” a film by Philippe Garrel, is a fugue composed in a key of philosophical melancholy.

headline: A Scream
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of College Road Trip
summary_short: Eyes popping and mouths agape, Martin Lawrence and Raven-Symoné mug their way through “College Road Trip” as if it were a silent movie.

headline: Human Civilization: The Prequel
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 10,000 B.C.
summary_short: It’s best not to think too hard about anything in “10,000 BC,” a sublimely dunderheaded excursion into human prehistory.

display_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day
headline: Can a Screwball Fable Have an Eye for Detail and a Heart for Fun? Discuss
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day
summary_short: Acting, of course, has something to do with it. But the charm that emanates from Amy Adams like a perfume in “Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day” is also a natural gift.

headline: Tunneling Thieves Strike a Lode of Loot (and Valuable Smut)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bank Job
summary_short: The workmanlike title “The Bank Job” is a nice fit for this wham-bam caper flick.

headline: An Arrival for the Dearly Departed
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Last Stop for Paul
summary_short: “Last Stop for Paul” follows two goofy dudes, Charlie (Neil Mandt) and Cliff (Marc Carter), as they gallivant around the globe in search of adventure.

headline: 'A/K/A Tommy Chong,' a Documentary About the Comedian and the Law
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of a/k/a Tommy Chong
summary_short: Josh Gilbert's film tells the depressing, often ridiculous and generally enraging story of how and why Tommy Chong ended up doing time in a minimum-security prison.

headline: Cursed With a Face Only a Sow Could Love
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Penelope
summary_short: “Cinderella” meets “The Ugly Duckling” in “Penelope,” a muddled, charm-free fairy tale whose title character is a rich girl born with the snout of a pig.

headline: Exploitation’s Wheel Spins in London
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It's a Free World...
summary_short: It’s a free world, Ken Loach asserts in his latest film with well-practiced disgust and unfortunately little hope.

headline: Brooding on the Bayou
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Chenier
summary_short: Men are men, and women are no end of sorry in “Little Chenier,” a steamy saga of jealousy and revenge set on a waterlogged spit of Louisiana land.

headline: From Ground Zero to Boston
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond Belief
summary_short: This documentary feature follows 9/11 widows from suburban Boston, as they try to raise money to help war widows in Afghanistan.

headline: A Goofball’s Quest: Slam Dunk for Survival
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Semi-Pro
summary_short: Like many of Will Ferrell’s recent films, “Semi-Pro” finds the sweet spot between sports melodrama and parody, and hammers it for 90 diverting minutes.

headline: Rival Sisters Duke It Out for the Passion of a King
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Other Boleyn Girl
summary_short: More slog than romp, “The Other Boleyn Girl” tells the salacious story of two hot blue bloods who ran amok and partly unclothed in the court of Henry VIII.

headline: Hit Men on Holiday Get All Medieval
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Bruges
summary_short: In “In Bruges,” Brendan Gleeson, Colin Farrell and Ralph Fiennes have great fun rummaging around inside Martin McDonagh’s modest bag of tricks.

headline: Two Siblings Stuck in a Junkyard World, Struggling to Survive and Dream
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chop Shop
summary_short: “Chop Shop” is concerned principally with the kind of hard, marginal labor that more comfortable city dwellers rarely notice.

headline: On the List
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sex and Death 101
summary_short: The screenwriter Daniel Waters has some funny films to his name, but “Sex and Death 101” is not one of them.

headline: Is He Insane? No, He’s Larry
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Witless Protection
summary_short: In “Witless Protection,” Larry the Cable Guy plays a small-town deputy, fantasizing about becoming an F.B.I. agent. Sitcom wackiness ensues.

headline: High School’s the Same; the Drugs Have Changed
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Charlie Bartlett
summary_short: Two decades after Ferris Bueller, a new smarty-pants seeks popularity in “Charlie Bartlett.”

headline: One Assassination Attempt, a Multitude of Perspectives
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vantage Point
summary_short: “Vantage Point,” a gimmick in search of a point, is nothing if not, er, timely.

display_title: George A. Romero's Diary of the Dead
headline: Filmmakers Who Become Their Own Zombie Movie
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of George A. Romero's Diary of the Dead
summary_short: In “George A. Romero’s Diary of the Dead,” we meet the enemy and he is us, with video cameras.

headline: More Than Rock ’n’ Roll: U2 on Tour in 3-D Images
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of U2 3D
summary_short: The musical documentary “U2 3D,” which stitches together three performances by this Irish rock band, is  the first Imax movie that deserves to be called a work of art.

headline: In a Flat World, a Rebel With a Cause
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Persepolis
summary_short: “Persepolis,” austere as it may look, is full of warmth and surprise, alive with humor and a fierce independence of spirit.

headline: A Muslim and a Hindu. Let’s Dance.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The High School Experience
summary_short: They may not make ’em like they used to in Hollywood, but sometimes in India they still do.

display_title: The 2008 Academy Award Nominated Short Films
headline: No Mickey Mouse Stuff
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The 2008 Academy Award Nominated Short Films
summary_short: In the 2007 Academy Award nominated short films, digital wizardry meets life-and-death dramas.

headline: Social Equality Comes With a Beat, Again
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Step Up 2 The Streets
summary_short: “Step Up 2 the Streets” posits a universe where racial and class differences are minor obstacles to fun and pretends its clichés aren’t clichés.

headline: A House Divided by Old Magic and New Residents
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Spiderwick Chronicles
summary_short: Instead of the kind of inspired imaginative synergy that distinguished the “Lord of the Rings,” “The Spiderwick Chronicles” feels more like a sloppy, secondhand pander.

headline: How I Met Your Mother: A History Lesson in Love
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Definitely, Maybe
summary_short: “Definitely, Maybe,” written and directed by Adam Brooks, is a nimble and winning little romance.

headline: Time-Space Continuum? No Big Deal. And the Swag...
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jumper
summary_short: “Jumper” is a barely coherent genre mishmash about a guy who transports himself across the globe at will.

headline: Innocence Lost, on a Battlefield Somewhere in Africa
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ezra
summary_short: “Ezra” is a scorching portrait of an African child who is kidnapped and turned into a soldier for a rebel militia.

display_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights--Hollywood to the Heartland
headline: Sharpshooters of Comedy Hit the Road (Duck!)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights--Hollywood to the Heartland
summary_short: “Vince Vaughn’s Wild West Comedy Show” imagines itself a contemporary equivalent of rootin’- tootin’ traveling entertainments like Buffalo Bill’s Wild West Show. That’s a tall comparison to draw.

headline: Southern Discomfort for a Hollywood Talk-Show Host
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins
summary_short: “Roscoe Jenkins” is just a shaggy diversion that gives its energetic star and its populous, accomplished supporting cast a chance to clown around.

headline: Tropical Pursuit of Love, Coins and No Tan Lines
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fool's Gold
summary_short: In “Fool’s Gold” Kate Hudson and Matthew McConaughey, as golden as a pair of rotisserie chickens, squabble and cavort in a tropical paradise.

headline: Attention, Slackers: It’s a Jungle Out There
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strange Wilderness
summary_short: Underachieving even by the standards of stoner comedies, “Strange Wilderness” is so inert that it doesn’t so much unreel on screen as loiter there.

headline: It’s Enough to Make Anyone Blink
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Eye
summary_short: “The Eye” is the latest Western deconstruction of a successful Asian horror movie and it is louder and more literal than its inspiration.

headline: An Obsessive Love of Prayer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Praying With Lior
summary_short: “Praying With Lior” documents the extraordinary life of Lior Liebling, a rabbi’s son with Down syndrome.

headline: Digging for Truth in a Life That’s Built Upon a Lie
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Live and Become
summary_short: Fundamental issues of ethnic and religious identity and the agony of exile are at the heart of “Live and Become.”

display_title: Hannah Montana & Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert
headline: Pop in 3-D
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Montana & Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert
summary_short: “Hannah Montana and Miley Cyrus: Best of Both Worlds Concert” is a diverting 3-D artifact of Ms. Cyrus’s just concluded tour.

headline: A Guy, His Psychic and a Jealous Ghost
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Over Her Dead Body
summary_short: For what it is — a romantic comedy about the rivalry between a jealous ghost and a flaky psychic for the love of a veterinarian — “Over Her Dead Body” is not bad.

display_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly
headline: Body Unwilling, a Mind Takes Flight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Diving Bell and the Butterfly
summary_short: With “The Diving Bell and the Butterfly,” Julian Schnabel demonstrates his own imaginative freedom in every frame and sequence.

headline: Stuck on a Family Hamster Wheel, Mile After Mile, Year After Year
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Savages
summary_short: Tamara Jenkins’s “The Savages” is a beautifully nuanced tragicomedy about two floundering souls.

headline: Doing Battle on the Field of Parody
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meet the Spartans
summary_short: Jason Friedberg and Aaron Seltzer, the team behind “Meet the Spartans,” prove that ridiculing other movies is much easier than making your own.

headline: A Spiritual Fight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Orthodox Stance
summary_short: In the intriguingly layered documentary “Orthodox Stance,” a determined young boxer strives to prove that the laws of God and the laws of the ring need not be at odds.

headline: Dance, Fight, Laugh, Cry and Read Great Literature
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of How She Move
summary_short: The strong acting, spectacular dance routines and culturally specific details in “How She Move” turn clichés into catharsis.

headline: Brutal, Painful Death, Just a Mouse Click Away
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Untraceable
summary_short: Morally duplicitous torture porn: how else to describe “Untraceable,” a bleak, rain-washed horror thriller.

headline: Just When You Thought It Was Safe to Go Back in the Jungle
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rambo
summary_short: “Rambo,” directed by and starring Sylvester Stallone, has its own kind of blockheaded poetry.

headline: An American Primitive, Forged in a Crucible of Blood and Oil
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of There Will Be Blood
summary_short: “There Will Be Blood,” Paul Thomas Anderson’s epic American nightmare, arrives belching fire and brimstone and damnation to hell.

headline: On the Run
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spirit of the Marathon
summary_short: A symphony of snapping sinews and pumping thighs, “Spirit of the Marathon” makes you feel like a slug.

headline: Steroid Myth, Scandals and Dreams
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bigger, Stronger, Faster*
summary_short: Just when “Bigger, Stronger, Faster*” seems content to be an entertaining exploration of the use of anabolic steroids, it turns a corner and plunges into deeper waters.

headline: In Over Their Heads, With Destiny Looming
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cassandra's Dream
summary_short: “Cassandra’s Dream,” Woody Allen’s latest excursion to the dark side of human nature, is good enough that you may wonder why he doesn’t just stop making comedies once and for all.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Man a Fortress of Futility
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beaufort
summary_short: “Beaufort” may be, strictly speaking, a war movie, but for long stretches it feels more like science fiction.

headline: Bank’s Trash Is Treasure for Grabbing
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mad Money
summary_short: In the breezy, amoral heist comedy “Mad Money,” “Fun With Dick and Jane” meets “9 to 5” on the way to recession.

headline: Bridesmaid Revisited, Again and Again
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 27 Dresses
summary_short: “27 Dresses” makes the point that modern American weddings are all pretty much alike. The same could be said about modern American romantic comedies.

headline: We’re All Gonna Die! Grab Your Video Camera!
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cloverfield
