summary_short: “Cloverfield” is nominally a monster movie, but mostly it’s a feature-length gimmick.

headline: Unrest, a Love Triangle and Swinging Hips
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Opera Jawa
summary_short: A colorful and confounding head trip, “Opera Jawa” is guaranteed to test the fortitude of all but the most adventurous viewer.

display_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale
headline: Magic and Mayhem From a Video Game
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale
summary_short: Like actors in an amateur stage play, the large, mostly all-star — or has-been star — cast of “In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale” look, rather dazedly, to be playing dress-up.

headline: A Youthful Awakening to Mother Nature’s Laws in a Turkish Village
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Times and Winds
summary_short: Livestock far outnumber humans in “Times and Winds,” Reha Erdem’s transporting vision of life in a mountain village in northwest Turkey.

display_title: The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie
headline: For Values-Based Produce, a Heroic Seafaring Quest
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pirates Who Don't Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie
summary_short: “The Pirates Who Don’t Do Anything: A VeggieTales Movie” is a rather ordinary film with faith at its core.

headline: Mend Your Foolish Ways, Would-Be Church Bandits
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of First Sunday
summary_short: In “First Sunday,” Ice Cube departs a bit from the upright-citizen persona, playing a man driven to crime by desperate circumstances.

headline: The Ghost Down the Hall Is Scary in Spanish, Too
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Orphanage
summary_short: “The Orphanage,” a diverting, overwrought ghost story from Spain, relies on basic and durable horror movie techniques.

headline: For Geezers Gone Wild, Too Little, Too Late
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bucket List
summary_short: “The Bucket List” operates on the hope that two beloved stars rubbing their signature screen personas together can spark warm, fuzzy box office magic.

headline: From Memories, There’s No Escape
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kite Runner
summary_short: In both novel and film form, “The Kite Runner” recounts a simple yet shrewd story about that favorite American pastime: self-improvement.

headline: Lies, Guilt, Stiff Upper Lips
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Atonement
summary_short: “Atonement” is an almost classical example of how pointless, how diminishing, the transmutation of literature into film can be.

headline: Two Drifting Life Rafts on a Sea of Circumstance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Liberty Kid
summary_short: There’s not a single wrong note in “Liberty Kid,” Ilya Chaiken’s poignant drama about marginal lives strained to breaking by the aftermath of Sept. 11.

headline: Death Is on the Line; Can You Hear It Now?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One Missed Call
summary_short: “One Missed Call” is the latest Japanese knockoff to fetishize death by technology.

headline: Aliens and Predators Still Can’t Seem to Get Along
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aliens vs. Predator: Requiem
summary_short: The second “Aliens vs. Predator” film is, like its predecessor, one very dark movie. Not psychologically dark; dark  dark, as in not very generously lighted.

headline: Fearsome Nessie Started Out as a Good Egg and Playmate
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Water Horse
summary_short: Many lonely children yearn for a pet to call their own. In “The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep,” based on a novel by Dick King-Smith, a boy finds not only that, but a best friend as well.

headline: Leading the Charge to Inspire Underdogs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Great Debaters
summary_short: There are enough things to admire about “The Great Debaters,” the heavily fictionalized true story of The Little Debate Team That Could, that your impulse is to forgive the movie its shortcomings.

headline: Seeking Mr. and Mrs. Right for a Baby on the Way
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Juno
summary_short: “Juno” respects the idiosyncrasies of its characters rather than exaggerating them or holding them up for ridicule.

display_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street
headline: Murder Most Musical
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street
summary_short: “Sweeney Todd” is as much a horror film as a musical. It is also something close to a masterpiece.

headline: Good-Time Charlie’s Foreign Affairs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Charlie Wilson's War
summary_short: “Charlie Wilson’s War” may be more of a hoot than any picture dealing with the bloody, protracted fight between the Soviet Army and the Afghan mujahedeen has any right to be.

display_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story
headline: Behind the Music, This Time for Laughs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story
summary_short: “Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story” has a good beat and you can dance to it, though mostly you’ll probably just tap your foot.

headline: Racing Around the Globe, Solving a History Mystery
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of National Treasure: Book of Secrets
summary_short: The hyperactive sequel “National Treasure: Book of Secrets” sends its archaeologist hero on a globetrotting quest that might have been devised after a long night of Wikipedia surfing.

headline: P.P.S. Take Tissues to This Weepy About a Romance Tested by Death
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of P.S. I Love You
summary_short: “P.S. I Love You” looks squeaky clean and utterly straight. Yet as directed by Richard LaGravenese, it has a curious morbid quality.

headline: A Goofy Scheme to Get the Girl
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The District
summary_short: The Hungarian cartoon feature “The District!” is a last-minute shoo-in for the title of 2007’s most original animated film.

headline: Harsh Realities and Mystical Power
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Half Moon
summary_short: For his poetic fourth feature, “Half Moon,” Bahman Ghobadi returns to the desolation of the Kurdish borderlands and the enduring optimism of his people.

headline: Out of Warhol’s Inner Circle Into the Void
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Walk into the Sea
summary_short: “A Walk Into the Sea” is Esther B. Robinson’s documentary about Danny Williams, a former Harvard student who was a part of Andy Warhol’s Factory scene.

headline: Man About Town, and Very Alone
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Legend
summary_short: In spite of its third-act collapse into obviousness and sentimentality, “I Am Legend” is among Will Smith’s better movies.

headline: Familiar Faces With a Digital Makeover
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alvin and the Chipmunks
summary_short: Hollywood continues its tired milking of old television properties with “Alvin and the Chipmunks,” a slick updating of the musical-cartoon franchise.

headline: Dearly Beloved, We Are Gathered Here Today to Rend One Another Apart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Margot at the Wedding
summary_short: When it comes to emotional violence, “Margot at the Wedding” is hard to beat.

headline: For a Single Mother, Mr. Claus Is Mr. Right
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Perfect Holiday
summary_short: “The Perfect Holiday,” directed by Lance Rivera, is that most dispiriting product, a formulaic movie that doesn’t believe in itself.

headline: A Career Circling Fame and the Drain
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Holy Modal Rounders
summary_short: As much the chronicle of an era as of a band, “The Holy Modal Rounders ... Bound to Lose” casts an affectionate eye on the kind of hedonism no one is meant to survive.

display_title: The Other Side of the Mirror: Bob Dylan Live at the Newport Folk Festival, 1963-65
headline: The Young Bob Dylan, Charismatic and Electric
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Other Side of the Mirror: Bob Dylan Live at the Newport Folk Festival, 1963-65
summary_short: If you were not at the Newport Folk Festival in the ’60s — or, for that matter, if you were — “The Other Side of the Mirror” places you in perfect seats.

headline: Bless the Beasts and Children
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Golden Compass
summary_short: “The Golden Compass” has many of the virtues of a faithful screen adaptation and many of the predictable flaws.

headline: Another Side of Bob Dylan, and Another, and Another ...
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I'm Not There
summary_short: Among its many achievements, Todd Haynes’s “I’m Not There” hurls a Molotov cocktail through the facade of the Hollywood biopic factory.

display_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead
headline: Robbing a Mom and Pop Store, Too Close to Home
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Before the Devil Knows You're Dead
summary_short: “Before the Devil Knows You’re Dead” is a chronicle of destruction — physical, spiritual and moral.

headline: Forget It, Jake, It’s Koreatown
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Undoing
summary_short: “Undoing,” by the writer and director Chris Chan Lee, buries a potentially haunting pulp thriller beneath flashy tics.

headline: Songs for a Brighter Tomorrow
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Singing Revolution
summary_short: Can singing change history? “The Singing Revolution,” a documentary by James Tusty and Maureen Castle Tusty about Estonia’s struggle to end Soviet occupation, shows that it already has.

headline: Down but Not Really Out
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Awake
summary_short: If you are one of those who viewed Hayden Christensen’s portrayal of Anakin Skywalker as the ne plus ultra of lifelessness, prepare to be proven wrong with “Awake.”

headline: Christmas Is Almost Here and Santa Is in Her Sights
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Be My Oswald
summary_short: A seriously deranged dramedy about finding yourself through terrorism, “Be My Oswald” attempts high-wire artiness on a bargain-basement budget.

headline: An Urban Fairy Tale
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bella
summary_short: “Bella” is a movie that wears its bleeding heart on its sleeve and loves its characters to distraction.

headline: Surviving in That Rain Forest East of the Delaware River
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fierce People
summary_short: When F. Scott Fitzgerald remarked that the rich “are different from you and me,” he might have been thinking of someone like the moody billionaire from “Fierce People.”

headline: Food and Fun
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nina's Heavenly Delights
summary_short: A cloying blend of Bollywood sentiment and “Amélie” whimsy, “Nina’s Heavenly Delights” is a lesbian-foodie fairy tale that keeps its appetites well under control.

headline: Someday My Prince Will ... Uh, Make That a Manhattan Lawyer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Enchanted
summary_short: “Enchanted” works its magic largely by sending up some of the very stereotypes that have long been Walt Disney Pictures’ profitable stock in trade.

headline: Something Creepy This Way Creeps, and It Spells Bad News
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Mist
summary_short: Until the director Frank Darabont decides that he’s saying something important instead of making a nifty horror movie, “The Mist” isn’t half bad.

headline: Slaughter on Parade, Without Joystick
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hitman
summary_short: Based on the video game franchise of the same title, “Hitman” exploits every action-flick cliché imaginable and still manages to be dull.

display_title: It is Fine! EVERYTHING IS FINE.
headline: Fantasies Without Bounds for a Lothario With Limits
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of It is Fine! EVERYTHING IS FINE.
summary_short: Crispin Hellion Glover’s planned trilogy of blatant weirdness continues with a second installment, “It Is Fine! Everything Is Fine.”

headline: A Stocking-Stuffer Idea: Lots of Old Resentments
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Christmas
summary_short: “This Christmas” includes more family melodrama than all the holiday-homecoming flicks from the past decade combined.

headline: Is That Music We Hear or a Tyke’s Beating Heart?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of August Rush
summary_short: To describe “August Rush” as a piece of shameless hokum doesn’t quite do justice to the potentially shock-inducing sugar content of this contemporary fairy tale.

headline: He Found a Bundle of Money, and Now There’s Hell to Pay
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Country for Old Men
summary_short: For formalists — those moviegoers sent into raptures by tight editing, nimble camera work and faultless sound design — “No Country for Old Men” is pure heaven.

headline: Cherishing the Fantasy in 6-Year-Olds of All Ages
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium
summary_short: If the concept of “Mr. Magorium’s Wonder Emporium” is ingenious, its execution is erratic.

display_title: Love in the Time of Cholera
headline: 50 Years and 600 Women Later, True Love
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love in the Time of Cholera
summary_short: “Love in the Time of Cholera” is faithful to the outline of the novel but emotionally and spiritually anemic.

headline: Confronting the Fabled Monster, Not to Mention His Naked Mom
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beowulf
summary_short: You don’t need to wait for Angelina Jolie to rise from the vaporous depths naked to know that this “Beowulf” isn’t your high school teacher’s Old English epic poem.

headline: Home Is Where the Heart Is, but Then the Heart Moves
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I for India
summary_short: In “I for India” Sandhya Suri offers her family’s immigrant experience as a springboard for questions of nationality and  filial responsibility.

headline: Repressed Desires and Sexual Frankness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sacred Family
summary_short: The off-putting, sometimes dizzying visual style of “The Sacred Family” settles down enough to reveal elements of absorbing drama.

headline: A Bad Day at the Office
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of P2
summary_short: Swift and stealthy “P2” is a canny exploitation of one of the urban woman’s greatest fears: the after-hours parking garage.

headline: Hearts and Minds: Senator Meets Reporter, Selling a New, Improved War
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lions for Lambs
summary_short: Career Politicians, the Fourth Estate and Disaffected Youth all earn a stern knuckle rapping in “Lions for Lambs.”

headline: The Dependent Claus
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fred Claus
summary_short: “Fred Claus” is a tacky would-be comedy about family dysfunction that fronts some Scrooge attitude only to dissolve into slobbering sentimentality and canned uplift.

headline: A Scrappy Tale of a Presidential Campaign
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cocalero
summary_short: “Cocalero,” Alejandro Landes’s documentary about the presidential campaign of Evo Morales in Bolivia, seems to mirror the campaign itself: ragged and bare-bones.

headline: Free-Jazz Pioneer, Aware of His Legacy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Name Is Albert Ayler
summary_short: The Ohio-born tenor saxophonist Albert Ayler probably would have gotten a kick out of Kasper Collin’s documentary about his life.

headline: Telling a Tale of Torment, Wordlessly
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Glass Lips
summary_short: The pungent layers of narrative that make up “Glass Lips” may cross and collide — and occasionally confuse — but the intelligence behind them is clear.

headline: This Is Basketball, Boys; It’s Not Rocket Science
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quantum Hoops
summary_short: “Quantum Hoops” tells the story of the California Institute of Technology’s men’s basketball team, a farcical topic in the context of college sports.

headline: Cut the Scary Music: Here Sharks Are More Endangered Than Dangerous
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sharkwater
summary_short: The ocean is just large enough to contain the ambition of “Sharkwater.”

headline: Man Meets Boy, Surrenders Heart
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Martian Child
summary_short: There’s nothing wrong with the setup of “Martian Child,” but there’s little right about the delivery.

headline: Struggling Against Circumstance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Love and Honor
summary_short: “Love and Honor,” the final episode in Yoji Yamada’s samurai trilogy, maintains the grace and resonance of its predecessors as well as their focus on class inequality.

headline: Sweet, Bloody Smell of Success
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of American Gangster
summary_short: Greatness hovers just outside “American Gangster,” knocking, angling to be let in.

headline: Of Birds and Planes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Confessions of a Superhero
summary_short: Superman doesn’t solicit donations, but he accepts tips in “Confessions of a Superhero.”

headline: A Drone No More: No Hive for Him!
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bee Movie
summary_short: The most genuinely apian aspect of “Bee Movie” is that it spends a lot of its running time buzzing happily around, sniffing out fresh jokes wherever they may bloom.

headline: Life’s a Little Bit Worse Now That They’re Dead
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wristcutters: A Love Story
summary_short: “Wristcutters: A Love Story” has an offbeat, absurdist charm that turns a potentially creepy conceit into an odd, touching adventure.

headline: A Lonely Guy Plays House With a Mail-Order Sex Doll
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lars and the Real Girl
summary_short: “Lars and the Real Girl” is part comedy, part tragedy and 100 percent pure calculation.

headline: Dismemberment Entree, Heaping Side of Screams
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saw IV
summary_short: “Saw IV” is bloody proof that Jigsaw may be dead, but his well of corporeal abuses has yet to run dry.

headline: A Family Just Like Yours (if You Lived in a Movie)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dan in Real Life
summary_short: “Dan in Real Life” is neither wildly farcical nor mockingly cruel, but rather, for the most part, winningly gentle and observant.

headline: A Cad and a Femme Fatale Simmer
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lust, Caution
summary_short: “Lust, Caution” is a sleepy, musty period drama about wartime maneuvers and bedroom calisthenics, and the misguided use of a solid director.

headline: Brothers, and Their Baggage, in India
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Darjeeling Limited
summary_short: Wes Anderson’s main characters share with him a passion for collecting rare objects and unusual experiences, all of which they handle with exquisite, jealous care.

headline: Chanel’s Visionary, Holding Forth From His Designer Throne
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lagerfeld Confidential
summary_short: Those seeking career advice about how to become an emperor of fashion will find little if any useful information in “Lagerfeld Confidential.”

display_title: Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour
headline: This Is, Like, Spooky Stuff
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour
summary_short: “Sarah Landon and the Paranormal Hour” swan-dives into the tween-teenage market dominated by the behemoths Disney and Nickelodeon.

headline: Stumbling at the Goal Line
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Comebacks
summary_short: “The Comebacks” is one of those parody movies that presume that merely making reference to another film constitutes a joke.

headline: Trapped by Circumstance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of DarkBlueAlmostBlack
summary_short: If peace lies in acceptance, then no one told the filmmaker Daniel Sánchez Arévalo, whose first feature portrays repressed longing with been-there, done-that assurance.

headline: Human Frailty and Pain on Boston’s Mean Streets
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gone Baby Gone
summary_short: With “Gone Baby Gone,” Ben Affleck has taken a satisfyingly tough look into conscience, to those dark places where some men also go astray.

display_title: Things We Lost in the Fire
headline: An Addict and a Widow With a Lot of Pain to Heal
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Things We Lost in the Fire
summary_short: “Things We Lost in the Fire” bends over backward to prove that serious American movies can hold their own with the best films from overseas.

headline: Seeing Red in the Darkness
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 30 Days of Night
summary_short: “30 Days of Night” is a series of gory set pieces that seems to have been edited with a meat ax.

headline: When a Single Story Has a Thousand Sides
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rendition
summary_short: “Rendition” tries to be thoughtful and respectful of complexity while at the same time honoring the imperatives of commercial entertainment.

display_title: Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe
headline: A Collector and His Polaroid Passions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black White + Gray: A Portrait of Sam Wagstaff and Robert Mapplethorpe
summary_short: James Crump’s documentary is a potent exercise in art-world mythography that might be nicknamed “The Prince and the Punk.”

headline: Following His Trail to Danger and Joy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Into the Wild
summary_short: There is plenty of sorrow to be found in “Into the Wild.” But though the film’s structure may be tragic, its spirit is anything but.

display_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
headline: Good, Bad or Ugly: A Legend Shrouded in Gunsmoke Remains Hazy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford
summary_short: “The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford” adds another gauzy chapter to the overtaxed James myth, if not much rhyme or reason, heart or soul.

headline: Sometimes in the Woods, Hunters Become the Hunted
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Trigger Man
summary_short: Devised for minimum fuss and maximum tension, “Trigger Man” is the little thriller that could.

headline: Four Couples Gather to Ask One Question: Can’t We All Just Get Along?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Why Did I Get Married?
summary_short: Couched in a familiar language of hope and redemption, “Tyler Perry’s Why Did I Get Married?” benefits from one of the strongest casts of Tyler Perry’s career.

headline: 2 Brothers, and the Mob in the Middle
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of We Own the Night
summary_short: “We Own the Night” is a bloody, passionate melodrama, self-consciously Shakespearean — or Biblical, or Greek, take your pick of atavisms — in its intentions.

headline: Now, Warrior
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Elizabeth: The Golden Age
summary_short: “Elizabeth: The Golden Age” is a kitsch extravaganza aquiver with trembling bosoms, booming guns and wild energy.

headline: They Call Him the Fixer in a World That’s a Mess
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Michael Clayton
summary_short: Dark in color, mood and outraged worldview, “Michael Clayton” is a film that speaks to the way we live now.

headline: Lovers in the ’60s Take a Magical Mystery Tour
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Across the Universe
summary_short: Somewhere around its midpoint, “Across the Universe” captured my heart, and I realized that falling in love with a movie is like falling in love with another person.

headline: Rapper Meets Reggaetón (and Girl)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Feel The Noise
summary_short: There’s a lot going on under the surface of “Feel the Noise,” far more than its indefensibly generic title suggests.

headline: Suspicious and Curious Acts
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Strange Culture
summary_short: Somewhere between documentary and dramatization, fact and impression, “Strange Culture” molds one man’s tragedy into an engrossing narrative experiment.

headline: Fighting for the Light
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Seeker
summary_short: The forces of Light and Dark are at it again in “The Seeker,” David L. Cunningham’s stilted fantasy about a pubescent lad charged with defeating evil.

headline: B. C. in 3-D
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sea Monsters: A Prehistoric Adventure
summary_short: The new National Geographic documentary “Sea Monsters” is a parade of special-effects money shots with academic credentials.

headline: The Seven-Year Itch, Days After the Wedding
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Heartbreak Kid
summary_short: If you haven’t seen the 1972 version of  “The Heartbreak Kid,” you’re missing a minor classic. If you haven’t seen Peter and Bobby Farrelly’s new version, I’m jealous.

display_title: For The Bible Tells Me So
headline: Bible Lesson in Gay Rights
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of For The Bible Tells Me So
summary_short: “For the Bible Tells Me So” is, strictly speaking, an educational film, but there is no denying that it fills a need.

headline: Lost in Utah
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Desert Bayou
summary_short: “Desert Bayou” recounts the experiences of African-American survivors of Hurricane Katrina who were evacuated to Utah.

headline: Bibliophiles With Pride and Prejudice, Some in Need of Gentle Persuasion
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Jane Austen Book Club
summary_short: “The Jane Austen Book Club” is such a well-acted, literate adaptation of the 2004 best seller that your impulse is to forgive it for being the formulaic chick flick that it is.

headline: EXPOSURE (MOVIE)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Exposure
summary_short: Vengeful American photographer in Rio. Moody, ambitious thriller, caught between studied reflectiveness and sadism.

headline: The Voice of a Rock Star in His Twilight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kurt Cobain About A Son
summary_short: It’s hard to know who the audience might be for the documentary oddity “Kurt Cobain About a Son,” but I bet its subject would have hated it.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Solve the Terrorist Problem
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Kingdom
summary_short: “The Kingdom” takes aim at the ethical nuances and ideological contradictions of the war on terror and blasts away.

headline: Quarterback With a Parenting Knack
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Game Plan
summary_short: “The Game Plan” is so likable that it glides over its many plot holes.

headline: What Kind of Fool Is Love? No Matter, the Search Is On
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Feast of Love
summary_short: Playing a canny old papa bear dispensing nuggets of advice to a flock of unruly cubs in “Feast of Love,” Morgan Freeman has a role he could act in his sleep.

headline: Seeking Clues to a Son’s Death and a War’s Meaning
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Valley of Elah
summary_short: Underneath the deceptively quiet surface of “In the Valley of Elah” is a raw, angry, earnest attempt to grasp the moral consequences of the war in Iraq.

headline: Las Vegas Under Siege by Zombies and a Mutant
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Resident Evil: Extinction
summary_short: The third installment in the video-game-derived series of films is not exactly dull but never interesting either.

headline: Rap Away the Tears
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antonia
summary_short: A bold Brazilian melodrama that moves to the rhythm of the streets, “Antonia” traces a year in the lives of four young women who form a rap group and fend off tragedy.

headline: A Bashful Young Fairy Tale
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sydney White
summary_short: There’s nothing sophisticated about the comedy in “Sydney White,” a peppy, ultra-P.C. variation on “Snow White.”

headline: Reflections of Don Quixote
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Quixotic/Honor de Cavalleria
summary_short: Elmore Leonard once said that the key to telling an exciting story was leaving out the parts that people skip.  “Quxiotic/Honor de Cavalleria” is composed of little else.

headline: Old-Style Male Bonding Turns Toward the Tender
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Man of My Life
summary_short: In “The Man of My Life,” the French director Zabou Breitman and her screenwriting partner Agnès de Sacy examine male bonding from a feminine perspective.

headline: Topless Girls! (And Other Things Far Too Wildly Hilarious to Mention)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good Luck Chuck
summary_short: The main audience for “Good Luck Chuck” wants to confront one of the central cultural questions of our time: Will Jessica Alba take her top off?

headline: On London’s Underside, Where Slavery Survives
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eastern Promises
summary_short: Even as the turns of its narrative and the contours of its characters are recognizable, very little about “Eastern Promises” feels predictable or secondhand.

headline: To Japan and Back for Eggs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silk
summary_short: “Silk” is the latest casualty in a line of films with a David Lean glint in their eye that aspire to elevated popular art but that come across as kitsch.

headline: Three Journalists Find Fear and Loathing on a Serbian War Criminal’s Trail
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hunting Party
summary_short: “The Hunting Party” is a misfired, misguided would-be satire set in postwar Bosnia.

display_title: My Name Is Alan and I Paint Pictures
headline: Using Art to Exorcise His Demons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Name Is Alan and I Paint Pictures
summary_short: There is no shortage of documentaries about mentally ill artists, but “My Name Is Alan and I Paint Pictures” finds a fresh way into the subject.

headline: Who Needs Plot When You’ve Got Dragons?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dragon Wars
summary_short: “Dragon Wars: D-War”  is such a breathless, delirious stew, it’s impossible not to be entertained, provided — this is crucial — you have a sense of humor.

headline: A Saloonkeeper Extraordinaire
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Toots
summary_short: Toots Shor’s name hasn’t lighted up a New York sign for more than 30 years, but thanks to Kristi Jacobson, his granddaughter, it will now grace movie marquees.

headline: A Challenged Existence and a Ray of Hope
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Angels in the Dust
summary_short: In “Angels in the Dust,” Louise Hogarth reveals a heart-wrenching facet of the H.I.V./AIDS pandemic by turning the camera on a group of innocent children in South Africa.

headline: Gym Class Becomes Boot Camp
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Woodcock
summary_short: Between Billy Bob Thornton’s wry performance and Tami Reiker’s nuanced photography, you half-expect “Mr. Woodcock” to deliver more than formulaic laughs.

headline: Packing Heat After a Coldhearted Crime
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brave One
summary_short: “The Brave One,” though well cast and smoothly directed, is just as crude and ugly as you want it to be.

headline: The Life and Times of a Typeface
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Helvetica
summary_short: Overlong but fascinating, Gary Hustwit’s documentary posits Helvetica — a sans-serif typeface developed in 1957 — as an emblem of the machine age.

headline: Beauty and Art, Among the Dead in Paris
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Forever
summary_short: Death, beauty and the persistence of art are the vast topics addressed in Heddy Honigmann’s frustrating documentary “Forever.”

headline: The Warmth of Comfort Zones
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bubble
summary_short: Vacillating provocatively between romantic comedy and political tragedy, “The Bubble” is photographed with a sunny brightness that belies the gravity of its intentions.

headline: In the Ol’ West, a Very Tough Commute
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 3:10 to Yuma
summary_short: Russell Crowe and Christian Bale are the main reasons to see “3:10 to Yuma,” a serviceable addition to the current western revival.

headline: Sexually Inexperienced and Repellently Awkward
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brothers Solomon
summary_short: The spirit of Steve Martin’s early hit-or-miss slapstick oddities lives on in the crass goof “The Brothers Solomon.”

headline: Disturbing the Guilty Archives of the Wehrmacht
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Unknown Soldier
summary_short: “The Unknown Soldier” takes on the idea that ordinary German soldiers were for the most part unaware of and uninvolved in the worst crimes of the Nazi regime.

headline: Never Mind Those Bullets, a Newborn Needs Rescuing
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shoot 'em Up
summary_short: “Shoot ’Em Up” is a witless, soulless, heartless movie that mistakes noise for bravura and tastelessness for wit.

headline: Death ’n’ Yucks, Hallucinogens ’n’ Stiff Upper Lips
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death at a Funeral
summary_short: “Death at a Funeral” stands apart from other movies with rude humor because its characters are determined to keep a stiff upper lip no matter what.

headline: Even if You Do Great Art, the Bills Must Still Be Paid
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Musician
summary_short: Daniel Kraus’s “Musician” feels radically fresh: It simply observes its title character in the manner of a 1960s fly-on-the-wall documentary.

headline: Clinging to Memories of a Ghost Who Haunts Chile
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Salvador Allende
summary_short: One from the heart, “Salvador Allende” is a plaintive look back at the rise and violent fall of the world’s first democratically elected Marxist president.

headline: One Part Evil Killer, One Part Case Study
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Halloween
summary_short: Rob  Zombie’s movie, which he wrote and directed, wants us to care about the future serial killer Michael Myers even while it depicts him as a mute, literally faceless grim reaper.

headline: A Fairy Tale From India
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vanaja
summary_short: “Vanaja” is a coming-of-age tale that is engrossing, if slightly overlong, and absolutely timeless.

headline: Violence in the Name of Justice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Death Sentence
summary_short: James Wan’s film is a middle-class white man’s payback fantasy, leavened with phony references to class difference.

headline: Schemes in Spanish
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ladron Que Roba A Ladron
summary_short: This film is like “Ocean’s Eleven” if directed by Robin Hood and financed by Telemundo.

headline: Comprenez-Vous Woody Allen Films? Here’s a Paris Version
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 2 Days in Paris
summary_short: In “2 Days in Paris,” Julie Delpy’s and Adam Goldberg’s performances are so assured and spontaneous that they don’t even seem to be acting.

headline: Seeking Glory, and Fighting Evil, With a Paddle
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Balls of Fury
summary_short: “Balls of Fury” is raunchier and somewhat more imaginative than “Hot Rod,” and it will be must viewing for Christopher Walken completists.

display_title: The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun
headline: A Misanthrope and His Crumbling Castle
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Monastery: Mr. Vig and the Nun
summary_short: In “The Monastery: Mr. Vig & the Nun,” Jorgen Lauersen Vig comes across as a hybrid of quasi-Dickensian curmudgeon and modern grumpy old man.

headline: Martial Arts With a Gun Instead of a Kick
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War
summary_short: Today, it seems, anyone seeking a pleasant summer afternoon of Asian-style fisticuffs must settle for the kind of urban-action/martial-arts hybrid that is “War.”

headline: A New Home With a Stepford Vibe
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bothersome Man
summary_short: A surreal nightmare of gleaming surfaces and razor-sharp edges, “The Bothersome Man” unfolds in a sterile city where nothing is quite as it seems.

headline: The Gritty City
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skid Row
summary_short: More vérité than cinema, the documentary “Skid Row” is so raw that it’s virtually unwatchable.

headline: Heroes and Has-Beens in Redemption City
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Resurrecting the Champ
summary_short: “Resurrecting the Champ” is a cautionary fable that every journalistic go-getter dreaming of front-page bylines would do well to heed.

headline: The Devil Wears Down Her Nanny
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Nanny Diaries
summary_short: As “The Nanny Diaries” wobbles along uncertainly, it rests on the tense, squared shoulders of Laura Linney.

headline: Losing Gun Contol
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Illegal Tender
summary_short: Luridly earnest and laughably immoral, “Illegal Tender” is an old genre movie with a new look. Call it Hispanixploitation.

headline: Mormons Who Massacre
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of September Dawn
summary_short: The maudlin, grotesque western “September Dawn” apes “Schindler’s List” in hopes of creating a Christian Holocaust picture.

headline: Pratfalls in Every Language
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Bean's Holiday
summary_short: With “Mr. Bean’s Holiday,” the British comedian Rowan Atkinson continues a tradition that in the right hands never gets stale: comic pantomime.

headline: Three Relationships, Seen Through a D.I.Y. Lens
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannah Takes the Stairs
summary_short: “Hannah Takes the Stairs” is notable for what the movie represents: an evolutionary entry in the Do It Yourself (or D.I.Y.) independent film movement.

headline: He Came, He Saw, He Wimped Out
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Legion
summary_short: This sword-and-sandal spectacle from those epic-loving De Laurentiises might have made a good children’s film.

headline: For Three Virgins, the Path to Sunrise Is Paved With Excess
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Superbad
summary_short: Horny is as horny does in the sweetly absurd high school comedy “Superbad.”

headline: Life and Country in Upheaval
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sunflower
summary_short: Like Douglas Sirk without the throw pillows, “Sunflower” is a shamelessly old-fashioned melodrama performed with such sincerity that resistance is futile.

headline: Ordinary People With Extraordinary Stories
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Primo Levi's Journey
summary_short: Vividly impressionistic and delightfully curious, “Primo Levi’s Journey” retraces the writer’s arduous return from a liberated Auschwitz to his home in Italy.

headline: A Bratty American Star in Bollywood
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Marigold
summary_short: In “Marigold,” the first United States-India co-production, India provides one of its biggest stars, gorgeous scenery and even the daughter of a Nobel Prize winner.

headline: Pod People Propagating With a Fierce Indigestion
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invasion
summary_short: The latest and lamest version of Don Siegel’s 1956 pulp classic “Invasion of the Body Snatchers”  might have been an accidental camp classic if its politics weren’t so abhorrent.

headline: A Lesson in Global Warming From Two Cold, Cute Critters
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arctic Tale
summary_short: Displaying more corn than is usually found at the North Pole, “Arctic Tale” documents the travails of a polar bear cub and a walrus pup as they struggle toward adulthood.

headline: He’s Doing Whatever a Zebra Can
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zebraman
summary_short: A downtrodden schoolteacher, a disabled boy and a government agent suffering from an embarrassing itch are the unlikely heroes of “Zebraman.”

headline: A Werewolf War in Need of a Silver Bullet
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skinwalkers
summary_short: Splitting hairs both morally and literally, this human-inhuman hybrid movie pits good werewolves against bad — even if the distinction is fuzzier than their hides.

headline: When Stars (Celestial) Fall, and Stars (Hollywood) Fly
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stardust
summary_short: “Stardust” is a sprawling, effects-laden fairy tale with the thundering stamina of a marathon horse race.

headline: It’s Tucker vs. Chan, Round 3
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rush Hour 3
summary_short: The junky, clunky, grimly unfunny “Rush Hour 3” isn’t the worst movie of the summer. But it’s an enervating bummer nonetheless.

headline: A Defector’s Second Life, Embracing North Korea
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crossing the Line
summary_short: “Crossing the Line” tells of four American servicemen who defected to North Korea, with a focus on Joseph Dresnok, who became a privileged North Korean citizen.

headline: Our Wit-Lit Heroine Avoids Marrying a Juiceless Man
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Becoming Jane
summary_short: “Becoming Jane” is an imitation screen adaptation of an Austen-like novel that imagines the author’s romantic life at 20.

headline: Hey, Kids, Is Everybody Up for Some Guerrilla Warfare?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Daddy Day Camp
summary_short: “Daddy Day Camp” is a recruiting poster for kids, insisting that there’s no domestic problem that military values can’t solve.

headline: He’s Still No Seer, but Underdog Is Here
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Underdog
summary_short: A motherless boy, a graceless dog and a witless script propel “Underdog,” a live-action resurrection of the 1960s television series.

headline: Bollywood Goes on a Trip to the A.T.M.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cash
summary_short: “Cash,” a Bollywood caper, provides abundant proof that Hollywood pictures have no monopoly on ostentatious wealth, or, to use a spent expression, bling.

headline: Still Searching, but With Darker Eyes
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Bourne Ultimatum
summary_short: For Jason Bourne, who rises and rises again in this fantastically kinetic, propulsive film, resurrection is the name of the game, just as it is for franchises.

headline: Blind Man’s Dark Paradise, Laid to Waste by the Gift of Sight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Willow Tree
summary_short: “The Willow Tree” examines the traumatic shocks experienced by a blind professor of literature whose eyesight is miraculously restored.

headline: Never Pick a Fight With a Washing Machine
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hot Rod
summary_short: “Hot Rod” might be called the poor man’s “Eagle vs. Shark.” Poor certainly describes the quality of the filmmaking.

headline: Big Money, Big Houses and Big, Nasty Demons
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of If I Didn't Care
summary_short: “If I Didn’t Care,” a noir set in the Hamptons, stokes the tempting fantasy that this elite enclave on the southeastern shore of Long Island is the seat of all evil.

headline: When the Salsa Throbs, a Singer’s Soul Is Revealed
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of El Cantante
summary_short: Whenever Marc Anthony takes the stage as Héctor Lavoe in “El Cantante,” he unleashes his charisma and shows that, whatever his limitations as an actor, he is a brilliant performer.

headline: Tender Hearts and Lip-Gloss Dreams
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bratz: The Movie
summary_short: Arriving as inevitably as puberty, “Bratz” introduces the swollen-headed, fashion-addicted dolls of the title to a live-action movie.

headline: Repression and Oppression Collide
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Total Denial
summary_short: In “Total Denial,” Milena Kaneva’s incisive look at Myanmar, one thing is unmistakable: Its central figure, Ka Hsaw Wa, is the stuff heroes are made of.

headline: Lindsay Lohan’s New Role: I’m Not Who They Think I Am
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Know Who Killed Me
summary_short: Pretentious and inane, “I Know Who Killed Me” arouses unexpected sympathy for its embattled star.

headline: Storming the Country Club in a Helicopter
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Who's Your Caddy?
summary_short: There’s probably more wit and pointed social commentary in the average four-minute OutKast song than in the entirety of “Who’s Your Caddy?”

headline: We’ll Always Have Springfield
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Simpsons Movie
summary_short: “The Simpsons Movie” is full of the anarchic, generous, good-natured humor that is the show’s enduring signature.

headline: If You Can’t Stand the Analysis of Work and Parenthood, Get Out of the Kitchen
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Reservations
summary_short: “No Reservations” is a factory-sealed romantic comedy. But the emotional details of its characters’ journeys are surprising, honest and life-size.

headline: On a Mission to Replace the Sun, Fighting Demons From Inner Space
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sunshine
summary_short: The end may be nigh in “Sunshine” — the Sun is dying, as is, alas, poor Earth — but director Danny Boyle is having a grand old time.

headline: A Vietnam P.O.W. Story, Tangling With the Vines of Convention
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rescue Dawn
summary_short: “Rescue Dawn” is a satisfying genre picture that challenges the viewer’s expectations.

display_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry
headline: Dude (Nyuck-Nyuck), I Love You (as If!)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry
summary_short: “I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry” is sporadically funny, casually sexist, blithely racist and about as visually sophisticated as a parking-garage surveillance video.

headline: A French Songbird’s Life, in Chronological Disorder
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Vie En Rose
summary_short: “La Vie en Rose” shows that we Americans don’t have a monopoly on singers and composers who emerge from personal troubles and win the hearts of millions.

headline: A Supermodel Captured, but Not by a Camera
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captivity
summary_short: “Captivity” the movie has been thoroughly eclipsed by “Captivity” the marketing.

headline: He’s a Very Good Pianist, but He’s a Very Bad Boy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Joshua
summary_short: Uneasily straddling age groups and genres, “Joshua” is a highly effective family drama cloaked in the stale tropes of the demon-seed thriller.

headline: One Day (and Dead Body) at a Time
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You Kill Me
summary_short: With its shadows and gallows humor, “You Kill Me” goes about as dark as a comedy can go before turning into tragedy or self-parody.

headline: Back in Iraq, Unearthing Old and New
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nice Bombs
summary_short: With “Nice Bombs,” Usama Alshaibi, a Chicago-based filmmaker, adds his noncommittal voice and unsteady camera to the Iraq conversation.

display_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
headline: Hogwarts Under Siege
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix
summary_short: The latest Harry Potter movie begins with a spot of unpleasantness at the Dursleys and ends with Harry facing down Lord Voldemort.

headline: Ready to Put This Union Asunder
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of License to Wed
summary_short: If the beloved with whom you see “License to Wed” can’t stop talking about how great it was, you might want to cancel the nuptials.

headline: Car Wars With Shape-Shifters ‘R’ Us
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Transformers
summary_short: Boys and their toys are in full formation in “Transformers,” a movie of epically assaultive noise and nonsense.

headline: Open Wide and Say ‘Shame’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sicko
summary_short: Michael Moore has never before made a film that stated his bedrock ideological principles as clearly and accessibly as “Sicko.”

headline: Voilà! A Rat for All Seasonings
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ratatouille
summary_short: Displaying the usual meticulousness associated with the Pixar brand, “Ratatouille” is a nearly flawless piece of popular art.

headline: Sustained in Death by the Memory of One Great Love
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Evening
summary_short: At first, second and final glance, Susan Minot’s “Evening” doesn’t seem as if it would translate easily to the big screen. It hasn’t.

headline: Pick Your Poison: Fists or Fireballs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Live Free or Die Hard
summary_short: In “Live Free or Die Hard,” Bruce Willis is ready to earn our love again by performing the same lovably violent, meathead tricks as before.

headline: Niceness Counts in Ark-Building, Too
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Evan Almighty
summary_short: “Evan Almighty,” in which Steve Carell is commanded by God (Morgan Freeman) to build an ark, is a movie far less interesting than its premise.

headline: An Unlucky Number
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 1408
summary_short: A Stephen King short story is adapted and brought to the screen in “1408,” more psychological thriller than outright horror.

headline: In a Crowded Anime Dreamscape, a Mysterious Pixie
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paprika
summary_short: In “Paprika,” a gorgeous riot of future-shock ideas and brightly animated imagery, the doors of perception never close.

headline: Bollywood Goes to Europe and Finds Love
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jhoom Barabar Jhoom
summary_short: “Jhoom Barabar Jhoom” is a giddy romantic comedy with star power, wanderlust and a charming can-do, why-not-the-kitchen-sink spirit.

headline: Video Game Arrives in the Flesh (Lots of It)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of DOA: Dead or Alive
summary_short: There was a time when movies like “DOA: Dead or Alive” lurked sheepishly at schoolboy height on video store shelves, spines straining to accommodate the charms of their actresses.

headline: Junior Sleuth Finds Her Way to the Screen, With Knee-Socks Pulled Up High
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nancy Drew
summary_short: In “Nancy Drew,” the titular girl sleuth is decked out with air quotes and the full complement of knowing pop-culture accessories.

headline: Four Countries, Five Bands, One Coast-to-Coast Party
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gypsy Caravan
summary_short: As a music document and as a labor of unabashed love, the nonfiction feature “Gypsy Caravan” could hardly be better; as a movie, it could stand some improvement.

display_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
headline: Armageddon Comes Knocking
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer
summary_short: “Rise of the Silver Surfer” is an existentially and aesthetically unnecessary sequel to the equally irrelevant if depressingly successful “Fantastic Four.”

headline: The Comedy of Capitalism
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Czech Dream
summary_short: In the documentary “Czech Dream,” two students at the Prague Film Academy use state money to stage an elaborate consumer hoax.

headline: Rejoining the Champions of Light and Dark
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Day Watch
summary_short: Unfolding in a decrepit, present-day Moscow, “Day Watch” dazzles and confuses with equal determination.

headline: Those Tired, Those Poor: A Journey as Important as Its Destination
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Golden Door
summary_short: Some version of the immigrant’s tale told in “Golden Door” is part of the family history of millions of Americans.

headline: Paris as Cinematic Soufflé, From Quartier to Quartier and Director to Director
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paris, I Love You
summary_short: “Paris Je T’Aime” could be described as a cinematically literate travel brochure. But the Paris we see is not so prettified that it looks and feels unreal.

headline: They Always Come Out Ahead; Bet on It
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ocean's 13
summary_short: With “Ocean’s Thirteen,” the gang’s all here, looking fighting trim and Hollywood beautiful, at your disposable pleasure.

headline: Birds on Boards
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surf's Up
summary_short: This addition to the kiddie canon follows a young Rockhopper penguin with surfing in his blood and dreams of greatness in his head.

headline: Inside the Torture Factory
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hostel: Part II
summary_short: Eli Roth’s “Hostel: Part II” may sport glossier production values than the first in the series, but its driving motivation remains just as low.

headline: Bye-Bye, Bong. Hello, Baby.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Knocked Up
summary_short: It may be a bit, um, premature to say so, but Judd Apatow’s “Knocked Up” strikes me as an instant classic, a comedy that captures the sexual confusion and moral ambivalence of our moment.

headline: Tragedy, Too, Is in the Eye of the Beholder
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Crazy Love
summary_short: Love is blind, and so too is Linda Pugach, one of the loony-tuners in the somewhat sickening, mildly gonzo documentary “Crazy Love.”

headline: A Father With Two Careers, in Business and in Murder
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mr. Brooks
summary_short: In “Mr. Brooks,” serial killing is an addiction that sufferers hope to overcome by attending 12-step meetings.

headline: Soccer Dreams and Family Tensions
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gracie
summary_short: A familiar underdog story told with unusual sensitivity, Davis Guggenheim’s “Gracie” depicts the obstacles faced by a young girl who dreams of playing on her high school soccer team.

headline: Beating Writer’s Block
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Four Lane Highway
summary_short: “Four Lane Highway” stars Frederick Weller as Sean, a famous (dead) writer’s son who became a writer himself but has been blocked for some time.

headline: Wanted: A Third Party to Complete Love Triangle
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Valet
summary_short: If you love to hate the superrich, “The Valet” is a sinfully delicious bonbon.

headline: Life in the Sprawling Suburbs, if You Can Really Call It Living
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Radiant City
summary_short: Blending documentary elements and some dramatic material, “Radiant City” is an acerbic position paper on the cultural damage done by postwar architectural fads.

headline: Movie Memories and Gender Confusion
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hollywood Dreams
summary_short: A gentler, more wistful Henry Jaglom wrote and directed “Hollywood Dreams,” his 15th and perhaps most accessible film.

headline: Creepy Crawly Conspiracies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bug
summary_short: With “Bug,” William Friedkin continues to be more fascinated by the evil inside our heads than the boogeyman outside.

display_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
headline: Back to the Bounding Main
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pirates of the Caribbean: At World's End
summary_short: “At World’s End” is the third and perhaps final episode in the swishy, swashbuckling “Pirates of the Caribbean” saga.

headline: A Grumpy Green Giant Who Would Not Be King
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shrek the Third
summary_short: There is a feeling of finality about “Shrek the Third,” a sense that the tale has at last reached a state of completion.

headline: Bedding That Nice Nazi, and Other Wartime Perils
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Black Book
summary_short: Paul Verhoeven’s “Black Book” encompasses the best and very worst of its director’s signature pulp brutalism, which means it’s pretty much a hoot.

headline: War on Terror Takes a Detour
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delta Farce
summary_short: With “Delta Farce,” his second movie vehicle, the Southern-fried comedian Larry the Cable Guy takes ever greater risks to advance his career.

headline: Hey, California Girl, Don’t Mess With Grandma
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Georgia Rule
summary_short: “Georgia Rule,” directed by Garry Marshall from a script by Mark Andrus, swerves and spins, taking its predictable plot in some surprising directions.

headline: Chasing an Old Flame, Taking No Prisoners
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ex
summary_short: The best jokes in “The Ex,” a scattershot screwball satire of job insecurity, upward mobility, political correctness and yuppie marital tensions, have claws that leave scratches.

headline: A Sense of Purpose Takes Flight
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Duck
summary_short: In “Duck,” Philip Baker Hall is a lonely widower who finds a purpose in life when an orphaned duckling comes his way.

headline: In a Lonely Place, Saved by Puppies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Year of the Dog
summary_short: “Year of the Dog” is funny ha-ha but firmly in touch with its downer side, which means it’s also funny in a kind of existential way.

headline: Shifty Wedding Crashers: Secrets From the Past
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of After the Wedding
summary_short: “After the Wedding” is a modern creation with a classic theme involving haves and have-nots, bloodlines and family ties.

headline: When Images Take on Lives of Their Own
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Looking for an Icon
summary_short: This documentary about four World Press Photo contest winners defines icon to mean a still image so searing that it supplants memories of the event it was supposed to record.

headline: Superhero Sandbagged
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spider-Man 3
summary_short: If ever a movie had a case of the blues and the blahs, it’s “Spider-Man 3,” a sequel that is fizzled rather than fizzy.

headline: The Poker’s High Stakes, the Couple’s in Love and the City Is Mostly Sin-Free
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lucky You
summary_short: Even though “Lucky You” is sometimes dull and generally thin, there is something winning about the movie’s genial lack of ambition.

headline: Breaking for Laughs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kickin' It Old Skool
summary_short: “Kickin’ It Old School” is actually much more amusing than it has a right to be, considering that you know exactly what’s coming.

headline: Transdimensional Romance
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invisible
summary_short: “The Invisible,” the latest recycling of foreign-grown frights, shows less interest in horror than in healing.

headline: Glimpsing the Future (and a Babe)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Next
summary_short: In “Next,”  Nicolas Cage plays a guy who can see into the future. It’s too bad that Mr. Cage couldn’t tap into those powers to save himself from another bad choice in roles.

headline: Wrestling With Action
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Condemned
summary_short: “The Condemned” is tailor-made for those who like their violence multifaceted and their women monosyllabic.

headline: A Collision of Role Players on the Busy Avenue of Life
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Avenue Montaigne
summary_short: A film about love and art, about passing time and time passing, “Avenue Montaigne” is a humble pleasure.

headline: Banished to the Country, a Too-Good Cop Finds an Action-Movie Parody
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hot Fuzz
summary_short: Think of “Hot Fuzz,” a British parody of Hollywood-style action flicks, as “The Full Monty” blown to smithereens.

headline: A Mixed-Up Son of ‘The Graduate’
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Land of Women
summary_short: The meek, mopey comedy “In the Land of Women” is the film equivalent of a sensitive emo band with one foot in alternative rock and the other in the squishy pop mainstream.

headline: Playing a Game of Cat and Mouse Without Breaking a Sweat
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fracture
summary_short: “Fracture” offers the spectacle of that crafty scene stealer Anthony Hopkins mixing it up with that equally cunning screen nibbler Ryan Gosling.

headline: Checking In and Not Checking Out
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vacancy
summary_short: This banal horror retread involves a couple of critters flailing inside a sticky trap for what is, in effect, the big-screen equivalent of a roach motel.

headline: Fallen Angels With Fuzzy Halos
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Downtown: A Street Tale
summary_short: “Downtown: A Street Tale” is a hackneyed melodrama partly redeemed by a cast convinced that it’s performing Tennessee Williams.

headline: True Story of a Fake Story About Hughes (Really)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hoax
summary_short: The literary and journalistic frauds of the present era are small potatoes compared to the work of Clifford Irving, the subject of “The Hoax.”

headline: A Hotel Room With Views of 5 Couples’ Relationships
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Room 314
summary_short: “Room 314” cracks open the door of an anonymous hotel room where, at different times, five couples navigate critical moments in their relationships.

headline: Kiss Kiss, Vroom Vroom: They Were Born to Drive
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Redline
summary_short: The movie “Redline” is all about surfaces, for young men with testosterone to burn.

headline: Nose With an Imagination, and Hard-Boiled Crime
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Slow Burn
summary_short: “Slow Burn” is a wooden police thriller that is as dull as it is impenetrable and ultimately beyond ludicrous.

headline: Surveillance and Subterfuge in Corporate Shadows
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Perfect Stranger
summary_short: Even after it lurches from the far-fetched into the preposterous, “Perfect Stranger” leaves a clammy residue of unease.

headline: Norsemen of the Apocalypse
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pathfinder
summary_short: All grunting, all goring, the witless action flick “Pathfinder” has little to recommend it.

display_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters
headline: Meaty Comedy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters
summary_short: The point of “Aqua Teen Hunger Force” is not “South Park”-style topical satire, but rather endless riffing on pop culture minutiae.

headline: The Joys of Teaching? Get Lost, Mr. Chips
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chalk
summary_short: The loose-jointed ensemble comedy “Chalk” follows three teachers and one administrator over nine months.

headline: Inside Story of a Hip-Hop Return to Glory
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rock the Bells
summary_short: The lively hip-hop documentary “Rock the Bells” demands neither familiarity with the music nor a hankering for rhyme.

headline: Back to the (Double) Feature
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grindhouse
summary_short: “Grindhouse” is soaked in bloody nostalgia for the cheesy, disreputable pleasures of an older form of movie entertainment.

headline: Film Review: Modernity and Tradition at a Cultural Crossroads
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Namesake
summary_short: Mira Nair’s “The Namesake," based on Jhumpa Lahiri's novel, conveys a palpable sense of people as living, breathing creatures who are far more complex than their words might indicate.

headline: Under the Spanish Moss, a River Runs Blood Red
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Reaping
summary_short: The only remotely notable thing about this particular jumble of boos, bangs and door creaks is that it tries to wed the horror trend with the heated-up God market.

headline: Star Dog Loses His Way but Still Leads Humans
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Firehouse Dog
summary_short: In “Firehouse Dog” a pampered Hollywood pooch trades his movie-star lifestyle for a run-down firehouse sadly in need of a mascot.

headline: Hammer, Nails, Dry Rot and Do-It-Yourself Trouble
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Are We Done Yet?
summary_short: The rapper Ice Cube returns to the multiplex with “Are We Done Yet?,” a feeble fable of better parenting through home improvement.

headline: Higher Self-Esteem Through Robbery
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lookout
summary_short: “The Lookout” is a new version of a very old story: A nobody falls in with scuzzball crooks who make him feel like somebody.

headline: Live From the Rink, It’s Will Ferrell on Ice
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blades of Glory
summary_short: With “Blades of Glory,” Will Ferrell and Jon Heder stake an early claim to being the comedy couple of the year.

headline: It Came From the River, Hungry for Humans (Burp)
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Host
summary_short: “The Host” is a loopy, feverishly imaginative genre hybrid about the demons that haunt us from without and within.

headline: A Fugue for Good German Men
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lives of Others
summary_short: “The Lives of Others” is a supremely intelligent, unfailingly honest look at a shadowy period in recent German history.

headline: Forget the Eyes. The Teeth and Tongues Are Worse.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Hills Have Eyes 2
summary_short: “The Hills Have Eyes 2” is essentially a catalog of transgressive images, lighted and edited like a heavy-metal video.

headline: When the Snow Begins to Fall, He May Not See It Stop
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of First Snow
summary_short: A pointed little thriller with metaphysical pretensions, “First Snow” is shrewd enough to approach basic philosophical questions in sneaky, offhand ways.

headline: Load Up. Remove Clothes. Then Try Not to Lose Head.
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shooter
summary_short: Muscles bulge and heads explode in this thoroughly reprehensible, satisfyingly violent entertainment about men and guns and things that go boom.

headline: Who Else but an Old Buddy Can Tell How Lost You Are?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reign Over Me
summary_short: “Reign Over Me” uses the rhythms and moods of comedy to explore, and also to contain, overpowering feelings of loss.

headline: Making Waves in a Tough Community
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pride
summary_short: In the idealistic “Pride,” a swim coach leads an inner-city recreational center’s swim team to victory.

headline: Turtle Power of the CGI Variety
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of TMNT
summary_short: In “TMNT,” these superheroes in a half shell have firmly been co-opted by the industry their creators once sought to spoof.

headline: Box to the Future
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Mimzy
summary_short: Invoking Lewis Carroll, “E.T.” and Tibetan Buddhism, “The Last Mimzy” is an overstuffed yet warmhearted sci-fi drama.

headline: Murder by Dummy
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dead Silence
summary_short: The playfully self-aware touches of “Dead Silence” distract from its leaden pacing, three too many final twists and various behavioral idiocies.

headline: A Happy Housewife Does the Time Warp, and Madness Ensues
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Premonition
summary_short: The sloppy, absent-minded “Premonition” is a step back in time and a giant leap backward for Sandra Bullock.

headline: Orphans Searching for Hope
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Brother
summary_short: “My Brother” is billed as the tale of two poor, orphaned siblings, but it wants to be much more than that.

headline: Setting Sail on a Bumpy Cruise With the Shadowy Shostakovich
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich
summary_short: A documentary grab bag of film clips, diary readings and desultory narration, “A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich” peeks at the politics of this controversial composer.

headline: Grandpa’s Legacy, Beyond Cash
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ultimate Gift
summary_short: Reeking of self-righteousness and moral reprimand, “The Ultimate Gift” is a hairball of good-for-you filmmaking.

headline: Multiple Choice Love Quiz
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starter For 10
summary_short: “Starter for Ten” tackles a lofty subject — the allure of knowledge — with down-to-earth charm.

headline: Once Upon a Time, Flopsy and Mopsy, There Was a Plucky Proto-Feminist Who ...
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miss Potter
summary_short: This film is the cinematic equivalent of a delicate English tea cake whose substance is buried under too many layers of icing.

headline: Hunting a Killer as the Age of Aquarius Dies
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zodiac
summary_short: David Fincher’s magnificently obsessive new film, “Zodiac,” is part police procedural, part monster movie, a funereal entertainment that is a testament to this cinematic savant’s gifts.

headline: Hitting the Road for Some Hot Man-on-Bike Action
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wild Hogs
summary_short: The main thing about the guys in “Wild Hogs” — the main source of the movie’s fumbling attempts at humor — is that they’re not gay. Really. Seriously. No way.

headline: A Place for Rebirth
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kamp Katrina
summary_short: “Kamp Katrina” chronicles a married couple who  opened their backyard to displaced people on the condition that they find jobs.

display_title: I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life and Legacy of Simon Wiesenthal
headline: Unimpeachable Bravery
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Have Never Forgotten You: The Life and Legacy of Simon Wiesenthal
summary_short: “I Have Never Forgotten You” effectively sketches Simon Wiesenthal’s life, from his tenacity in surviving  genocide, to his determination to find and punish ex-Nazis after World War II.

headline: Haunted by Ghosts of the Past, Beckoned by a Homeland
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Abandoned
summary_short: Through the murk and gloom of “The Abandoned,” a mystery emerges: Why didn’t this go straight to DVD?

headline: Laying Down the Law, Just for Laughs
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reno 911: Miami
summary_short: “Reno 911!: Miami” is slapdash, on-and-off funny and exceedingly lazy.

headline: A Man, a Book, a Number: What Does It All Mean?
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Number 23
summary_short: “The Number 23” is an accidental comedy starring a deadly serious Jim Carrey.

headline: The Imperfect Soul Who Helped Bring an End to the Slave Trade
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amazing Grace
summary_short: “Amazing Grace,” a prettified take on the life and times of the 18th-century reformer William Wilberforce, carries a strong whiff of piety.

headline: The Devil Made Me Do It
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Rider
summary_short: Is the world ready for a flaming Nicolas Cage?

headline: Transcending Pain, a Friendship Fed on Imagination
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bridge to Terabithia
summary_short: “Bridge to Terabithia” is a movie whose emotional depth could appeal more to adults than to their offspring.

headline: What Will My Spy Be? Capitalist, Drone, Deviant...
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breach
summary_short: The thriller “Breach” manages to excite and unnerve despite our knowing the ending.

headline: Warhol’s Anointed Starlet, Drowning in the Glitterati
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Factory Girl
summary_short: “Factory Girl,” a biography of Edie Sedgwick, the most glamorous of Andy Warhol’s so-called superstars, suggests a magazine layout masquerading as a film.

headline: Higgins, Meet Eliza, but It May Be Too Late
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Venus
summary_short: A modest, diverting, touching tale of a young woman who attracts the interest of an aging actor, played with effortless aplomb by the great Peter O’Toole.

headline: A Very Busy Father
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's Daddy's Little Girls
summary_short: The hamfistedness of “Daddy’s Little Girls” ultimately shatters its charms.

headline: Melodic Guy, Verbal Gal Meet Cute and Get Lyrical
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Music and Lyrics
summary_short: “Music and Lyrics” aspires to nothing more than the competent dispensing of mild amusement and easy emotion.

headline: The Hemingway Effect, From Recent Battlefields
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Operation Homecoming
summary_short: “Operation Homecoming” is a spinoff from an anthology of essays, e-mail messages, poems and letters from soldiers in Iraq.

headline: That Was No Elephant, That Was My Wife
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Norbit
summary_short: Too many of the gags in the sloppy comedy “Norbit” are lumbering and graceless, more fun to anticipate than to witness.

headline: Sins Devoured, Hope Restored
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Sin Eater
summary_short: “The Last Sin Eater” is religious art for mainstream consumption.

headline: How He Arrived at That Acquired Taste
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hannibal Rising
summary_short: The new prequel  “Hannibal Rising” provides  a back story that ought to have remained firmly in our imaginations.

headline: Playground Rules: No Hitting, No Sex
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Children
summary_short: Todd Field’s superb film adaptation of the novel by Tom Perrotta  is challenging, accessible and hard to stop thinking about.

headline: The Recurring Stain Should Be a Tipoff
link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Messengers
summary_short: With “The Messengers,” the Pang brothers devise scenes so scary that they stain the imagination and never scrub out.
